PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

the Australian Broadcasting Corporation intends to transmit television programs into Asia

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Wanted: our future, a report on the implications of sustained high levels of unemployment amongst young people 15 to 24 years old, together with the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate my tabling speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING
Report
Mr President,

The matter addressed in the report I have just tabled was referred to the Committee in June this year. Since that date we have received 112 submissions and held public hearings in five States and the ACT covering urban, regional and rural centres. In addition, individual Committee members have talked to a large number of young unemployed people, youth workers, teachers and counsellors as well as employers, trade unionists, government officials and academics throughout the country.

I would like to emphasise at the outset the Committee's unanimous endorsement of the Report's recommendations. Such agreement is perhaps surprising given the highly political nature of unemployment issues. It has been achieved because each individual member of the Committee has recognised that the future of our young people will not be secured by slogans or political grandstanding. It is a serious issue which demands non-partisan responses. Committee members acknowledge that there is no single solution to the complex problem of youth unemployment and that any approach which is to have a hope of succeeding will need to transcend party political considerations and draw upon the goodwill and resolve of all sectors of the community.

Youth unemployment is everybody's problem. It is the Committee's hope that this Report will serve both to emphasis this perspective and to suggest practical means by which the worst features of the impact of sustained unemployment might be alleviated. We stress this, given that a more permanent solution, in the form of full employment, is unlikely to be achieved in the short or medium term.

There can be hardly a family in Australia today that is not affected in some way by youth unemployment. Although concentrated among disadvantaged groups, youth unemployment is by no means confined to them. It affects people from all social and economic backgrounds and from all regions of the country. It afflicts people with PhDs and those who are illiterate. Their numbers are growing, as is the length of their unemployment.

Because today almost everybody knows a young unemployed person, most people also realise that the term "dole bludger" is now wholly unacceptable. The community seems generally now to recognise that most unemployed young people are eager to work and that many are making tremendous efforts to do so. The Committee was heartened by the resilience and energy of many of the young unemployed people it met during the course of this Inquiry.

We would also like to pay tribute here to the efforts of many individuals—parents, employers, teachers and landladies among others—who have recognised the plight of young unemployed people and are doing what they can to alleviate individual cases of hardship. The Parliament and the community generally would do well to reflect that, were it not for their generosity, the costs of youth unemployment, both to the individuals concerned and to the community generally, would be even greater. We should note here that the cost of unemployment generally is currently running at around $20 billion per year.

Before turning to our recommendations it is important to stress that the Committee does not wish to suggest that the personal consequences of unemployment are any less tragic for mature aged people than for young people. Our focus on young people is dictated by our terms of reference. As well, we are acutely aware of the potentially disastrous impact on our society of a sizeable group of alienated young people who have never worked and perhaps will never have the opportunity of doing so. They are cut off from the benefits bestowed by full time jobs and lack any commitment to the values espoused by mainstream society.

Our recommendations are based on the assumption that unemployment levels will remain high in the medium term and that, as the causes of youth unemployment are so complex and intractable in the prevailing economic situation, a range of approaches is required. The recommendations are focused around three main approaches.

The first relates to income support. Current income support arrangements have grown out of policies developed at a time of high employment. They were designed to assist small numbers of people for short periods as they moved between jobs. These arrangements are inappropriate for current conditions. While efforts have been made to modify income support arrangements in recent years, they remain complex, and often unnecessarily punitive and demeaning.

The Committee has recommended a number of changes designed to reduce their complexity. These include: the centralisation of income support arrangements in one department; the coalescing of all income support payments for eligible young people into a unified youth payment and simplification of the eligibility criteria for independent Austudy. In recognition of the need for a less punitive approach to the payment of income support the Committee has recommended that waiting periods for benefits be reduced; that greater flexibility be introduced into activity/work tests; that the "free area" of income which beneficiaries are allowed to earn before losing benefits is extended and that income support levels are increased to the revised Henderson Poverty Line in the first instance.

Our second group of recommendations relates to job creation. These recommendations are based on the view that we need a more creative and visionary approach to this task than has been evident in attempts to date and that we should build upon community concern and goodwill. We have recommended therefore that: employers should be assisted to take on additional employees through a 150% tax deduction on wages, replacing existing wage subsidy schemes; the establishment of a national employment corps, funded by the Commonwealth and the States and managed at local or regional level; that strategies be developed for the rapid expansion of job sharing and other proposals geared to a broader distribution of available work.

Finally, our Report discusses at some length the link between employment and training. While generally supportive of Carmichael and other proposals relating to vocational education and training the Committee is mindful of the fact that these proposals assume the availability of jobs (the so-called labour market entry points) so that proper, work-based training can be implemented. No attention has been paid to that significant group who will be unable to obtain jobs and thus will be denied opportunities also to participate in further training. Our recommendations are directed to addressing this discrepancy and to supporting and extending existing programs for enhancing links between schools and the work place. A national, competency-based approach to training is desirable, but the complexities of its implementation are considerable, and the Committee is not convinced that the implications for resources and coordination have been fully thought out.

I conclude, on behalf of the Committee, with an affirmation of the value of all of our young people. We believe that they all have something to contribute. If they are denied the opportunity to do so our society will be poorer for it, and ultimately we all will feel the consequences of this neglect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I intend to seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour of the day. I simply commend this report to the Senate. I realise that we are pressed for time today. Can I say in passing that this is a unanimous report of the Committee. In many ways it deals with a tragic subject—the future of those of our younger generation who are suffering from the effects of sustained unemployment.
—Have you sent it to Mr Keating?

—Senator Macdonald asked the right question: but he asked it from a biased political viewpoint. This is a unanimous report of all members of the Committee. We set aside our political backgrounds and biases in an attempt to come to grips with this pressing issue. We do not mention Mr Keating and Dr Hewson. We do not mention political parties.
—Order! Senator Aulich, will you address the Chair and, Senator Macdonald, will you cease interjecting.

—In response to Senator Macdonald, I simply state again: this is a unanimous, all-party—Democrats, Liberal and Labor—report. It addresses an extremely serious issue that affects all of us in a variety of ways, and I commend it to the Senate. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later hour of the day.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum, an additional supplementary explanatory memorandum and a replacement supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the Government amendments to be moved to the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992.

—The amendment in the Bill to the Special Broadcasting Service Act 1991 seeks to reimpose the blackout on television and radio advertising three days before an election campaign. When the Government introduced its ill-fated ban on political broadcasts and advertising, one of the consequences of that Bill was that it removed all the bans on advertising by reimposing a total advertising ban. I suppose one could call it yet another unintended consequence.

PARA.TAB: The Political Broadcasts Bill was subject to a High Court challenge. The High Court struck down, or found invalid, the ban on political advertising. The Bill was opposed very strenuously by the Opposition because we took the view that it was an unprecedented attack on freedom of speech and freedom of political expression in Australia. As I indicated, the High Court struck down this attempt to attack freedom of speech. The Government has had to bring in legislation that reimposes the three-day blackout. As a matter of principle, the Opposition will oppose this amendment to the Special Broadcasting Service Act.

I do not intend to go on. This issue was canvassed very strongly over the last 12 months and we have had the decision from the High Court. The question that should be asked of the Minister is: in view of the High Court decision, does he have an opinion that this amendment is valid? If so, could the chamber have a copy of that opinion? If not, should we be passing a Bill which could again be subject to a High Court challenge and which will yet again be found to be invalid?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the High Court case referred to by Senator Parer, known as the political broadcast case, the High Court held that there is a freedom of communication in relation to political matters inherent in the Constitution and based on the Constitution's establishment of a system of representative democracy. However, all of the Justices who recognised the existence of this implied freedom also recognised that the freedom was not absolute and could be restricted to the extent that other legitimate public interests required.

PARA.TAB: The three day broadcasting blackout has been in place under Commonwealth legislation for many years—in fact, 50 years—and has operated as an unchallenged element of representative democracy without compromising the system of government. It has enjoyed bipartisan support as being a sensible relief from the jingles, for at least a couple of days before polling day, for half a century. I must say that in my early discussions with senior members of the coalition, they indicated to me that they had no difficulty at all in supporting the return of the ban. For an early form of the ban, I would refer senators to section 89 of the Australian Broadcasting Act 1942, that is Act No. 33 of 1942.

It is the Government's view that the blackout period performs a useful function, as I have just said, in enabling electors to decide upon their votes in the last two days before polling day without being bombarded by electronic media advertising. It is certainly my experience that at that stage of the campaign most people in the electorate loathe it, and love to see the end of it, rather than its enhancing representative democracy by allowing the electorate to be misled when there is then very little time for any response.

Although the legislation would clearly be a restriction on the freedom of communication on political matters, in the Government's view the blackout period serves a legitimate public purpose in the manner in which the High Court described it. It is non-discriminatory in its application and it is of a very limited duration. In my view, and I have no hesitation in saying this, it is a very minor restriction on television electronic political advertising, which the majority of Australians would not only be comfortable with but also, at that stage of an election campaign, would support.

Senator Parer asked whether the Government had sought legal advice on this. Yes, of course the Government has. The advice that the Government has received from the Attorney-General's Department is that this legislation is legally sound and would have a very good chance of success, which is as strongly put as I imagine any wise counsel would put it, if it were put under challenge.

If Senator Parer asked me for my opinion, I would say that I am not a lawyer, thank God, but I was interested enough to read the judgments in this case. Personally, I was comfortable with the High Court's interesting exercise of drawing lines in the sand, which is what it did in that very creative decision. The High Court found that there was an inherent right to freedom of speech in the Constitution and, in relation to that aspect of the case, it was a piece of creative law making, which I support. But the High Court did—and it acknowledged that it did—draw a line in the sand. It did not say that this was an absolute proscription; it said that further lines, I guess, could be drawn in the sand at future times if legislation were taken to the High Court as a challenge.

For what it is worth—and it is worth nothing, because I am not a lawyer—from my own reading of the High Court's judgments I would say that this would have every chance of being upheld in the High Court as being constitutional. In direct response to Senator Parer's question, yes we have sought legal advice and the legal advice is to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: The majority of the amendments are minor technical matters. The substantive amendments relate to the new classification proposals. So these will be the only amendments that I will now address myself to for the sake of brevity.

PARA.TAB: On 24 November I announced the Government's intention to apply a uniform classification scheme to films televised by commercial and community broadcasters and to provide for restrictions on M and MA classified material. The proposed amendments result from extensive discussions with the Australian Broadcasting Authority, the Office of Film and Literature Classification and industry groups on the most effective way of giving effect to the Government's intention. I would like to thank the officers of all those organisations for the intense amount of effort that has been put in to present what I think is an extremely reasonable and balanced proposal.

The issues raised are not simple. It is probably a common failing of most politicians, because it is inherent in the process, that we are always looking for simple solutions to complex problems. The issues here are not simple. No matter what one tries to do, one will never satisfy everybody. One can only try to provide a reasonable result that will satisfy reasonable people.

After two all-night sessions in a row, this morning I particularly feel like poor old Sisyphus who had to roll a rock up a hill for the whole of his life. I feel condemned to debate this for my entire parliamentary career, and here we are again. I emphasise that these are not simple issues. Broadcasters have accepted the need for programs displaying the stronger forms of violence, sex and crude language to be shown after 9 p.m. and the codes they are currently developing will so provide.

The added factor in this debate was that it occurred at a time when the new Australian Broadcasting Authority had just been established and was operational and these codes were in the process of preparation. In fact, the main worry of the broadcasters was that they should retain the right to modify those programs further to ensure that they meet the stricter ideas of what should be shown on television.

We are proposing that the codes of practice should allow for modification of films to ensure that they at least meet the OFLC classifications for the time slots shown, knowing that in many cases the versions of films shown as M or MA on television will have been modified to remove scenes which would be acceptable to the Censor under the classification for cinema display. That is the current procedure and the television industry has been observing it for years. There is a very tiny percentage indeed of feature films classified under the film classifications as R that are ever modified for television. Indeed, they have to be heavily modified. The majority of those modified feature films would come from the M classification.

Coupled with improved consumer advice—which I am delighted to see in terms of the proposals which have come forward from the industry—the system will enable viewers, and particularly parents, to have a better idea of the content of films. They can be confident that films shown on television are at least within the OFLC guidelines for cinema display. I might also add that the research that has been done clearly shows that a very substantial number of people who watch television place high value on the assistance given to them by those classification symbols. One of the very positive things that has come out of this will be the enhanced regime that will be introduced by the broadcasters in that respect.

The restrictions will be imposed by codes of practice which must be developed within the framework of the Broadcasting Services Act. This amendment ensures that these codes apply the OFLC guidelines. The current provisions of the Act ensure that codes must take into account community attitudes to the portrayal of violence, sexual conduct and nudity, use of drugs and offensive language. The code dealing with the suitability of programs for broadcasting, the protection of children or the classification of programs which did not make adequate provision for these issues would not be registered.

I remind the chamber that under section 123 of the Act the ABA will only register a code if it is satisfied of three things: firstly, and most importantly, that the code `provides appropriate community safeguards for the matters covered by the code'; secondly, that the code is endorsed by a majority of the providers of broadcasting services in the relevant section of the industry, thus ensuring a commitment to the code by the broadcasters themselves—a very sensible provision—and, thirdly, that members of the public have had an adequate opportunity to comment on the code. This is no behind closed doors exercise, but a full, open and cooperative effort to protect important cultural values.

Honourable senators may also be assured that the standards of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on programming classification and timing will still apply under the Broadcasting Services (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Act until replaced. If they are not replaced by a code, they will be replaced by an ABA standard under section 125 of the Broadcasting Services Act.

The ABC and SBS are not subject to the Broadcasting Services Act but are required by their own Acts to develop codes and notify them to the Australian Broadcasting Authority. The ABC code has been approved by its board and notified to the ABA, and the SBS board will consider a draft code on 19 December. Those codes will apply the OFLC guidelines. The ABA can deal with complaints about breaches of the Act of the ABC or SBS code. If a national broadcaster fails to implement recommendations made by the ABA within 30 days, the ABA may report that fact to the Minister who is obliged to table the report within seven sitting days in both Houses of Parliament. No further legislative sanctions are necessary.

I am convinced that these proposals will meet the legitimate concerns of senators while maintaining the flexibility essential to effective regulation of a diverse industry such as broadcasting. I must also say again that I have been pleased by the cooperative attitude of the broadcasters on this issue. The level of commitment they have displayed—perhaps reluctantly at certain times during this process; they certainly cooperated fully in attempting to work with the regulators to come up with what is now before the chamber—convinces me that we will have no problems in the actual broadcasting of M and MA material. I am particularly pleased to see the move taken in the split of the M classification into a far more sensible split and the enhanced provisions that will be made by the broadcasters to actually display for the benefit of the viewer far more detail about what will be contained in the program about to be shown.

—I ask the Minister for some explanation of the matters now before us. If we are dealing with the whole of the amendments, and I suppose we are, the recommendations relating to M and MA made by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in September 1992 state on page 23:

SPEECH.PARA: There is also a certain amount of confusion surrounding the AO (television) and M (cinema/video) classifications caused by the fact that the AO classification, designated as being for 18+ years, is more restrictive than for all but the mildest M classified films, which are designated for 15+ years.
The third paragraph down from that—and I do not miss out anything relevant—states:

We propose that, for the purposes of television broadcasts of M classified material under self regulation, broadcasters adopt a system which splits the M classification into two categories, with milder material in the lower M range being equated to the current AO classification, and thus able to be shown from 8.30pm, and material in the M classification which includes stronger depictions of sex, violence or coarse language being restricted to broadcast in an unmodified form only after 10.30pm.
The Government's amendments mean in effect that M material will be able to be shown after 8.30 p.m. and stronger material rated MA will be able to be shown after 9 p.m.

PARA.TAB: I cannot understand what will be in the M material. The ABT committee that dealt with this comprised Sue Brooks, Bruce Allen and David Haines from the OFLC. The words they use for AO make it more restrictive than all but the mildest M classified films which are designated for 15-plus. Is that statement correct? I should like to know just what these people are saying.

I know the classifications; I have had a look at them and I have compared them. But I also have had a look at what the ABT has indicated and at the views of each of the television stations. I would like the Government to answer this question: should we now expect stronger depictions of sex, violence or coarse language on television?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is categorically no. The points Senator Harradine raises are very valid. I am familiar with that original recommendation of the ABT, which we do not accept. We do not support it, and we did not then. Can I say for the advice of the chamber that suggestions were made during this process of negotiation that that could perhaps be reconsidered, and they were rejected. The Government expressed the very strong view to the industry that that would not be permitted.

PARA.TAB: Basically, what Senator Harradine has said is correct. Fundamentally, the proposal—and the word is `unmodified'—is that those classifications could be broadcast on free to air television at those later hours. So that, basically, after half past ten—whatever the hour was—it would be a case of letting it rip. One could have broadcast on free to air television the same material in most classifications unmodified on television that one could see at the cinema. That was not and is not accepted. Indeed, the Opposition's amendment, which the Government intends to support, moved by Senator Alston, reflects that. But so does the industry's letter which has just been tabled and which Senator Harradine has just seen. The answer to Senator Harradine's question is categorically no.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you incorporate that letter?
—I seek leave to incorporate the letter just tabled.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 14 December 1992
Senator The Honourable Bob Collins
Minister for Transport and Communications
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
We understand that the Government proposes to introduce legislation to establish the framework for the revised program classification system agreed last month with the commercial television industry.

Within that legislative framework, the industry will develop detailed code requirements for classifying, modifying (where necessary), scheduling and promoting programs in all classification categories, i.e. G, PG, M and MA. Those code requirements will be developed in consultation with the Australian Broadcasting Authority. The codes will apply the OFLC's classification system to films, and to M and MA programs which are given their initial classification by stations. We would expect to be able to release a draft code for public comment within the next month, and to present it to the Australian Broadcasting Authority for registration in February 1993.
The industry has already advised the Government that it proposes to incorporate the following measures in its self-regulatory codes:

mandatory standardised indications of the levels of violence, sex and coarse language in television M and MA films and in other M and MA programs as required. These announcements will be broadcast before films in both audio and visual form, and there will be clear visual indications at the start of each segment of the film's classification and nature.
Further restrictions on early evening promotions for films.
The industry also committed itself to taking the following steps to support these code measures:

regular on-air announcements explaining the meaning of classification symbols and content descriptions, and encouraging viewers to use them in planning their viewing and their children's viewing. The frequency of these announcements will be stepped up during school holidays, paying particular attention to times when parents are watching in large numbers.
A continuing high visibility press campaign to support these on-air announcements—again focussing on school holidays
stations will include program classification symbols and content descriptions in press advertising of programs
stations will urge newspapers and magazines to display and explain program classification symbols and content descriptions in program guides.
In the light of points raised in Parliament in recent weeks, we want to emphasise several points about the way in which programs will be classified under the proposed code:

The industry intends that the new television M and MA categories should together correspond exactly to the AO classification. The industry has no intention—or wish—to introduce "tougher" material to television, as some Senators have feared. The codes will require films classified MA or M for cinema to be modified to make them suitable for the television medium. In broad terms, the top end of the television MA category will correspond to the bottom end of the MA cinema classification.

Television networks will continue to edit most cinema films for television, with the result that cinema/video and television versions of a film will rarely be identical. In the case of R and MA classified cinema films, the modification for television will invariably be extensive, so as to bring the product within the television MA or (in some cases) M category. This is something which the industry has done effectively and responsibly for many years with the small number of R cinema films modified for television.

the industry recognises the potential for confusion where, say, a cinema MA-classified film is modified for television to the extent that it may quite properly be classified television M. Accordingly, the industry intends to label as "Modified for Television" all such reconstructions which result in a lower television classification. This will apply to all films having a cinema R classification, and all cinema MA-classified films which are edited down to television M level.

Minister, we believe that these measures are carefully focused and comprehensive, and will ensure that community concerns about children's viewing in mid-evening are fully reflected in the industry code.
Yours faithfully
R.B. CAMPBELL
Chairman
Ref: AB236.92

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be absolutely no broadcasting on television in the combined new M-MA of any material at any hour which is currently not broadcast under the existing AO classification.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I could explain to Senator Bourne, and other honourable senators, the point of the subsequent amendment that the Government intends moving to Senator Alston's amendment. I know that Senator Walters has had a strong role to play in bringing this Opposition amendment to the chamber. We absolutely support the principle on which this is based. That is to provide an assurance that there will be no broadcasting whatever of any material that is not in the current AO classification. That is the reason why we have deleted from the original circulated Government amendment its first section—because we will now support the Opposition's amendment.

The Government considers the effect of the second amendment, however, to be extremely important. It does not subvert or overtake the Harradine amendment, which is still in force. It properly restores the correct role of the ABA as the routine monitor of the standards in the community. That is precisely the reason why we set up the Australian Broadcasting Authority—to act as the daily monitor and regulator. It is not a role that the Parliament—because of the mass of business that it deals with, apart from anything else—can routinely exercise. For that reason I had hoped that the Opposition would have felt that it could have supported that addition, seeing as that is the only effect of it—in other words, to simply put into legislation the role the ABA already has—in the same way as we intend to support the Opposition's amendment in terms of the principle that nothing in the new MA and M classifications will go beyond AO.

All the Government amendment does is reassert what the ABA does now under the principal Act. That is, the ABA will continue to monitor community standards, will review them regularly and will report directly to the Minister. It does not overtake or supplant—how can it?—the Harradine amendment, which is still in force. In addition to that process, which simply encapsulates in legislation the role of the ABA, Parliament at any time can intervene under the Harradine amendment and impose its own will or collective view on this matter if it wishes to do so. So the amendment is not a substitute for the Harradine amendment. It simply reiterates in legislation the primary function of the ABA to oversight these codes of practice and to routinely review them, as it must do if it is doing its job, and to report the results of those reviews directly to the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very much in favour of having one classification across the board for television, film and video. I understood that there would have been a great deal of difficulty in doing that. We have now ended up with an M classification and an MA classification which cover both television and film. I understand very clearly what the Minister is saying. But we now have four different M classifications: we have an M for film and video, we have an MA for film and video, we have an M—which is totally different because it has been modified considerably—for television, and we have an MA which is totally different from the other MA because it has been modified for television. That would be very confusing for a mother, who may say to her children, `On Saturday night you can watch a film on television so long as it is all right'. A film then comes up, the name of which that mother has seen on a video under M. She may say, `No, you can't watch that'. She does not know how it has been modified for television. She just knows that when she saw that M video it was not suitable for her children to watch. So we have the dilemma of a mother saying to her children, `No, I have seen that film and you are not going to stay up and watch that sort of film'.

PARA.TAB: However, in point of fact, because it has been modified so greatly—all or most of the violence has been taken out—it could be quite suitable for the children to see. How on earth do parents understand the new system? At least in the previous system they knew that AO did not equate with M and M videos that they had seen. But under the new system, parents might see an MA or an M on the video and say, `No, I'm sorry, you can't watch that, it is too violent. I'm not having that on at this hour in this home'. The parents could be totally wrong; they have no idea how the video has been modified because the same term is used. Therefore, I think the films have to be called M film, M television, MA film and MA television. Otherwise parents will not have any way to be able to judge what is going to come across the screen in the home at night.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, quite the contrary will be the case. I understand the point that Senator Walters is making, but the Government anticipated the need to do this right from the first time that we started debating this proposed change here in Parliament. There is no question that free to air television is considered to have a greater opportunity to access viewers than the cinema where some supervision is exercised. In most cinemas there is such supervision.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that I really do commend to the Senate is what I believe to be a greatly enhanced sensible regulatory regime at cinemas, which I know has worried cinema owners. What happens in the real world—and there is no question that it happens—is that parents drop their kids off at a multi-cinema complex, which is the norm now, even in small towns like Darwin, where four or five cinemas are served by the one front door. Children go into the cinema to watch Never Ending Story and end up watching something a lot more violent.

If Senator Walters looks at the fundamental change between M and MA, which I am told will be of great assistance to cinemas in providing better supervision, she will find that the difference is that the M classification will be fundamentally for 15 years and over, and the MA classification will be for children accompanied by an adult. I am not talking about television for the moment, but I am just saying that I think that the broad new classification has provided a better classificatory regime for film.

What the television industry is doing is no more than it has already done. I said a few moments ago that the actual percentage of R rated films that can be modified without completely losing the story and the continuity is very small. From memory I think only about 2 to 3 per cent of material broadcast is R modified. R rated films are currently broadcast on television under the AO classification, because they have been heavily modified for television, but there is no special classification or advice to the viewer that that modification has been carried out. This causes confusion now to an informed viewer. It does not matter that there is an R classification on the film because people know that the movie they are watching on TV has been broadcast at their local cinema in an R rated category. People are very broadly aware of those classifications.

As I said before, research has shown that people place a high value on classifications. The new proposals will in fact give better protection and better advice for parents in this sense. Currently, the only way for a concerned parent to access the detailed codes—and Senator Walters is one of these people who wants this in detail, and many people do—is to access the material which is made available by the Office of Film and Literature Classification. Senator Walters would know that it tries to promote this material as much as it possibly can. A recent series of national seminars has been run at cinemas. I attended the one that was held in Darwin to launch the office's published material so that parents who really want to know the detail of how these classifications are made—none of which could actually be put on the screen because it would take too long—can access this material from the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

The modification classifications that will be made for television will be made available in exactly the same way but with one additional benefit. The television operators have already made it clear—this is contained in the letter that has now been incorporated—that detailed code requirements for classifying and modifying where necessary will be published. So as well as the classification divisions, which, as Senator Walters knows, are quite complex in terms of their determinants, these requirements will be published in precisely the same way as the Office of Film and Literature Classification publishes the current material. But instead of it being done without any publicity, as it currently is in terms of R films being modified for television, that advice to the viewer will be put on the screen. What it does provide is at least broad similarity between the classification structures in cinemas and the classifications structure on television, which is currently absent.

We conceded from the first jump in this debate that one could not get a total classificatory regime, and I do not think it is desirable to have it. The television operators believe that further modification is required to most of these films if they are to be broadcast at all on television. So a national television campaign will be run by the broadcasters explaining in detail the new classifications, how they are going to work, and the modification differences with television. They will give advice to viewers as to where people who are interested can access the detailed material. This will be done in the same way as the Office of Film and Literature Classification does that now. Of course, when being broadcast the material will actually have the tag attached to it. So there will not be any confusion that the material has been modified for television. If viewers are watching a program for which an M classification has not been qualified, they will know that that is the same M classification that applies to the material being shown at the cinema.

The tag `modified for television' may be put on a program. Anyone concerned enough—and I will be one of them—to want to know what that means will have easy access to the detailed classificatory standards that will be applied to effect that modification. In essence, this will not be more confusing. It will provide a far more specific and far more information rich, if you like, regime for parents who are seriously interested in what their children are going to watch.

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that absolutely. Perhaps the Minister can give me a yes or no answer to my question. Will the Minister guarantee that media advertisements will specify whether the program to be shown is modified for television, violent or whatever? If this were done, mothers would not have the problem of saying to their children who are sitting in front of a television set, `Sorry, it has not been modified enough for me; I am turning off the television now'. I do not think the ensuing brawl happened only in my family when the children were young. I think the children of most families have said, `You promised us that we could watch it and now you are not letting us.' Parents would be satisfied if this could be done.

—In accordance with Senator Walters's strictures that she wants me to give a categorical yes or no answer, I have taken advice on this and I can advise Senator Walters that the answer to her question is a categorical yes, that will be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —To follow up on what Senator Walters has said, I go to the amendment that is before us. That amendment indicates that section 123 of the principal Act will require the industry to develop codes of practice, including codes to provide for the methods of modifying films having particular classification under that system so that the films are suitable to be broadcast or broadcast at particular times.

PARA.TAB: There are two issues to which I want to refer. Firstly, in respect of modification, are we really being asked to buy a pig in a poke here? I want to say something about the OFLC. I think the OFLC has not done its job in certain areas. I fear that what is happening here is that, if the OFLC has a final say on this matter, we will end up with worse material on television than we have now—and that is despite the statement made by the OFLC to our Committee. I am not impugning the OFLC's integrity in any way, shape or form. I think it is horses for courses and that the OFLC is the body to be dealing with classifications for film and video, but I do not think it has had the expertise or experience or longstanding knowledge of this area that the staff of the ABA and the previous ABT have had.

What I am getting at is that, when we talk about methods of modifying films, I have had a look at the current methods of modifying films that are undertaken by three of the major networks. Frankly, in some areas they are as different as chalk is from cheese. With material that is classified and is able to be shown as an AO film or an AO program—bearing in mind that they have AO programs as well as AO films—one network will not show those films and another network will.

The Minister has given to the chamber two undertakings: the first is that there will be no worse material shown than that which is currently shown as AO material; and, secondly, that there will be no worse material than that which is classified as AO material. That is the point—classified by the classification officers in the various networks. Our problem is—and it is a problem not only for us but also for the industry—that the various networks classify these in different ways. I understand what the Minister said before, that it has to be the majority view of the industry as to what the methods of modifying films will be, but at the present time we are being asked to buy a pig in a poke in respect of that issue because we do not know what the methods of modifying films will be.

I do not suggest we hold this up because I think it is an improvement along the way, but I believe that the Parliament in the final analysis has to have a look at that. The Minister says, `If you are not satisfied with that, then you can go for the Harradine amendment'. I do hope that, if anybody goes for that, that motion is not put at the bottom of the Notice Paper. I do not want to go over those arguments, but the Minister did make some interesting observations and I have had a look at them since. When I put the two effective parts of that motion—namely, the 15 days—the Minister said that they were `horrific' proposals—

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a favourite word of his; don't worry.
—Yes. He said that they would undermine the democratic process. The Minister stopped short of saying that it would undermine civilisation as we know it.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Committee that unless the industry gets it right, action will be taken in the Parliament. I hope that the Government will not stand in the way of serious action—I am not talking about flippant action—that might be taken. I am not reflecting on the industry because, to be fair to the industry, the day that the ABT committee, comprising those three persons whom I mentioned, came down with its recommendations, Mr Branigan, who is FACTS director, came out with a statement saying that the industry did not want to go to that extent. I commend the industry for that decision. I really want to know when these methods of modifying films will be able to be exposed, if I can use that word, for public viewing.

The second matter involves the film classifications M and MA. We are not told in this legislation what M and MA really mean. I suppose we are really being told that only the very mildest films will be included in the new M category. The document that was tabled by Senator Tate in the Parliament some time during the week following the meeting of the Premiers included a draft document by the OFLC about what it thought. It said that the M classification will be recommended for mature audiences 15 years and over and that MA will be restricted to mature audiences 15 years and over, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian. I will not go into what the film classifications will be because I presume that the States will apply certain restrictions to the entrance of persons into the cinemas to see MA classified material.

The Film Censorship Board has put forward some proposals on language in MA classified material. As I read what the Board is proposing, the language allowed will be worse in the M category than is currently available under AO. The Film Censorship Board of the OFLC says that crude language for the M category may be used, but not if overly frequent or impactful. But the current AO classification says that the occasional use of offensive language must be appropriate to the story-line or program context. The M classification says nothing about that. So on the face of it that proposal will allow worse language to be used in M than is currently able to be used in the AO category.

I appeal to the Minister to look at what the OFLC is proposing and to request the ABA or some group that has more expertise in the area of broadcasting to look at these things. Similarly, in respect of sexual material for television, the term `sexual intercourse' is being used for the first time in this document which has been provided by the OFLC.

The current provision relating to AO says that intimate sexual behaviour may only be discreetly implied or simulated and must be relevant to the story-line or program context, et cetera. I have looked at the guidelines used by some of the television stations and it is clear to me that they would exclude simulated sexual intercourse that is now suggested by the OFLC to be acceptable under the MA classification.

Similarly, there is a problem with violence. The OFLC appeared before the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies on 1 June 1992. The OFLC was questioned about what it had been doing to tighten up the M classification. It asserted that it had been tightening up on the M classification so far as violence was concerned. It was not obvious how that was being done. The OFLC said that it had applied stricter guidelines for violence. We all thought that the States had recommended that the OFLC tighten up on violence and that that would mean it would bring out a tighter definition in its classification. Page 1630 of the Hansard of 1 June reads:

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it also included tightening it up.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dickie—No. What happened in 1988 was that when the guidelines were presented to the Ministers, they then asked us to tighten up the application of those guidelines to films at the top end of the M and at the top end of the R—that is to apply them strictly. That was a request to both my Board and also the Film Board of Review. My Board then took up the request of the Ministers, which was reiterated by the Ministers last year, and we have been applying that way since.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you have been applying them since, the proof of the pudding is in the eating. What have you done with that material which had been classified as M which you would not now be classified as M? Have you recalled it?

PARA.TAB: Mr Dickie—We have recalled some.

TALK.START.PARA: —But have you done anything about them?

PARA.TAB: Mr Dickie—Of the ones that were out there before 1987, no.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are still there. Why?

SPEECH.PARA: It is instructive to look at some of the statements made to us by the OFLC. Without delaying the Committee, I ask the Minister whether the ABA will be consulted authoritatively by the industry for the purpose of drawing up what will be contained in MA and M so far as television is concerned. When are we likely to get the details of the methods of modifying films? I also want to refer to the ABC before we finish the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to keep my comments brief so as not to delay the Committee unduly. I agree fundamentally with what Senator Harradine had to say about the appropriate role for the ABA rather than for the Office of Film and Literature Classification to supervise the television side of it, and that is what will happen. PARA.TAB: In relation to the last part of Senator Harradine's question, everybody is determined to expedite this matter—everyone is very anxious to get it done—but it has to be done consistent with the undertaking that has been given generally in terms of how the ABA operates, very specifically in this case, to have full community consultation on the preparation of these codes. It is not a pig in a poke, as Senator Harradine would know better than anyone, courtesy of the Harradine amendment, because after that full community consultation occurs and after the codes of practice are prepared which will lay out all the details Senator Harradine seeks the ABA will be the agency that enforces it, not the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

Senator Harradine is aware of the penalties. The ultimate sanctions for breaches of those arrangements are very severe—a $2m fine in the case of a network, $5,000 in the case of a community broadcaster and so on. Those codes will be subject to the purview of this Parliament. As a result of the Harradine amendment—this certainly removes the pig in the poke aspect of it—those codes can now be amended by this Parliament if the Parliament is not satisfied with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Film Censorship Board, headed by Mr Dickie, is responsible purely for films; it has nothing to do with television. Did the briefing say that we would get the codes from the industry in January?
—Yes.
—If we are getting the codes from the industry in January—we were assured that the industry would have them ready by then—would the Minister allow the chamber to look at those codes—
—We may not be here.

—I am presuming that Mr Keating will use his brains and put off calling an election for as long as he can. If not, we will be where the Government is sitting and that will be fine. We would like to look at the codes in February so that the Senate is satisfied that the undertaking the Minister has given and the amendment that the Opposition is putting are being abided by in the division of the present AO classification. The present AO classification criteria will be divided between M and MA. We would like to look at the guidelines and perhaps discuss the matter here if we have any concerns. Could we have a guarantee that we could discuss it here if we have any concerns? I do not think we will have.

—I do not want to be difficult about this, but I am just the Minister for Transport and Communications. I am not in a position to guarantee what the Senate will or will not do. That is entirely in the hands of the Senate. If the Senate determines what the order of business is next year—
—But you wouldn't oppose it.

—No. I can certainly indicate to Senator Walters that not only would I not have any objections to having the matter debated but also I would welcome it being debated in the Senate.
