DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992HOUSING ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate on Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992 resumed from 24 November, and debate on Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1992 resumed from 10 November, on motions by Senator McMullan and Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak first to the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1992. In doing so, I point out that the coalition has always been very strongly committed to the principle of home ownership. That is why we have exempted the final sale price of a house from the proposed goods and services tax in the Fightback document. We have included measures in Fightback to put home ownership within the reach of a greater number of Australians. The Fightback proposals to establish two million jobs over the decade will help those Australians who aspire to own their own home but who are suffering the scourge of unemployment and therefore are unable to achieve their dream of home ownership.

PARA.TAB: We will be reintroducing the first home owners scheme. We will be providing access for first home buyers to up to 75 per cent of their accumulated superannuation contributions for use as a deposit or part deposit on a home. That was a recommendation of the Lavarch committee which has not been addressed by the Government. We will be introducing a tax-free savings scheme which will, in a very important way, help people who are trying to achieve home ownership. Our substantial income tax cuts and the increases to family allowances and other government payments will mean that individuals and families will have higher after-tax income with which to service their mortgages. Last but not least, our commitment to a low inflation rate policy will help to ensure that housing prices remain stable.

I say all that because it is very important in a debate on housing to understand the position from which members of the Senate are debating the issues. We, as an opposition, have a very strong commitment to home ownership, which we have always had, which we will maintain and which the Fightback document enshrines. The Bill before us today amends the Housing Assistance Act 1989 and extends the period of the guaranteed funding under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement for a further three years. The Bill also improves the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement financial management procedures by making the States more accountable for their housing plans and for their funding priorities, by encouraging them to more finely target their activities and by making them more responsive to the needs of the community.

Given that the States have largely had a free rein in spending public housing funds, we believe that these reforms are long overdue. They are certainly supported by the coalition. There is an appropriation of $4.7 billion to the States over four years. The Bill also implements the Government's Budget announcement to bring forward some Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement expenditure to generate employment—not before time. $75m has been brought forward for expenditure in this financial year and $25m in 1993-94.

Understandably, the housing industry is in favour of this measure, as it will guarantee some work to an industry which has suffered badly under the recession. This measure is, however, a damning indictment of the Government and the economic policies which have left nearly one million Australians unemployed. The proposal will not have any impact on the total three-year allocation, as the amounts brought forward have been offset by reductions in subsequent years. The Housing Assistance Amendment Bill enables any Commonwealth grants allocated to a State in a particular grant year but not paid in that year to be held over until the following year. This measure will encourage more discretionary spending patterns, ensuring that the States better meet the housing needs and get value for money.

In making these changes to the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, the Minister should have taken the opportunity to undertake more far reaching changes which would meet the growing demand for public housing. I draw to your attention the fact that public housing waiting lists grew by a massive 20,750, that is, 10.2 per cent, over the last financial year. I notice that in New South Wales, for example, the housing list at 30 June last year was 64,895 and that this year it grew to 71,458. In Victoria last year it was 38,935 and it has increased to 50,482. Here in the ACT there has been an incredible growth from 3,832 to 6,852. These figures very much reflect what is happening to Australians in their need for public housing.

The lucky country which, at the beginning of the decade, was the third richest in the world, now has a massive and growing public housing waiting list. It is extraordinary that this should be the harvest we are all reaping as a result of the policies of a Government which has been in power for 10 years. Those figures are tangible proof of the devastation caused by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and his colleagues and their economic policies. Do not let us forget the record high interest rates, the economic recession and those nearly one million Australians who are unemployed, all of which has pushed many a family into housing poverty. The public housing system is not working and the Keating Government has failed to recognise that there must be other ways of providing affordable accommodation.

It should be understood that, in our support for home ownership in Australia, the coalition also recognises the need for public housing, and we will retain the fundamentals of the current public housing system. I have noticed a cruel smear campaign of recent times—

TALK.START.PARA: —Typical.
—In every portfolio, Senator, we are finding more and more that the vulnerable are being frightened by this Government—
—The big bogy.

—As to what the big bogy of the coalition is likely to do in government, let it be clearly on the record that we believe that we can produce more public housing and reduce waiting lists by a more imaginative use of public funding. I am surprised that the Government itself has not been prepared to adopt the sorts of measures that we are talking about because, in the Defence Housing Authority area, for instance, it has been doing exactly what we propose to do with the States under the Commonwealth-State housing arrangements.

PARA.TAB: We will shift the responsibility for the purchase, construction and ownership of new dwellings in which public tenants are housed from the public to the private sector, with the States effectively leasing these dwellings on a long term basis. That will provide more housing—not less—for those in housing crisis, but without the associated high capital costs. The States will also be given the flexibility to develop other innovative funding proposals in conjunction with the private sector.

I do not propose to speak any more on that Bill, because in the limited time that we have available I wish to turn to the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. Speaking briefly to the question of hostels, the amendments to the Aged or Disabled Persons Care Act allow for the introduction of sanctions against hostels which fail to comply with standards of care and quality of life for residents. They also provide for the establishment of hostel standards review panels. The amendments bring hostels into line with procedures for nursing homes whereby the Commonwealth can take action if nursing home proprietors are not providing residents with the quality of life required by gazetted standards.

The amendments provide the Commonwealth with the ability to suspend payments in respect of new residents to an organisation operating a hostel not complying with the standards. They also provide a peer review mechanism, the hostel standards review panels, for hostel operators who seek review of the assessment of the hostel's compliance with standards. If the panels recommend to the Minister that a declaration of failure to comply is appropriate, they may also recommend that the Commonwealth suspend the payment of financial assistance to the hostel for new residents. A similar sanction has been available in parallel circumstances for nursing home proprietors since 1991, and during that time the Department has taken this course of action against 12 nursing homes. These amendments were expected by the industry; they present no real problems and so I do not propose to discuss that issue any further.

Turning now to nursing homes; funding is provided for upgrading. The Bill seeks to amend the National Health Act in order to implement a 1992-93 Budget initiative providing funding to upgrade nursing homes. Many nursing home proprietors, while aiming to provide good quality care, have difficulty in meeting the Government's outcome standards or health and fire safety standards because they are operating in old or unsuitable buildings. The initiative in this Bill will enable nursing home proprietors to apply for funds to undertake substantial upgrading work which has been identified as necessary for the well-being of their residents and which they might not otherwise be able to afford. The benefit is to be paid as a monthly recurrent benefit over a period of 10 years. It will be calculated in accordance with a formula based on a maximum cost per bed.

These amendments are generally welcome, but the funding is limited and not all those seeking upgrading funding will get it. I ask the Minister to consider these questions which are being asked by the industry: will applications be considered on a first come, first served basis? Will conditions such as the signing of residents' rights agreements be attached? Sceptics are saying that the funding will go to nursing homes in marginal electorates. I would like to see whether the Government can give us any indication at this time about where that funding is going.

It is important that we acknowledge that the provision for nursing home advisers to be appointed to nursing homes which have breached the conditions of approved nursing homes is one which is of concern to some parts of the industry. The role of the adviser will be to assist the proprietor of the home to comply with the conditions of approval. It will usually be someone with experience in the management of aged care facilities. If the proprietor was unwilling to accept and pay for an adviser, the normal sanctions process would continue, including closing the home if that became necessary.

The coalition supports measures which are designed to enforce high standards of care for elderly Australians. We do, however, share some concerns as to how the nursing homes advisers proposal will actually be implemented. I understand that one of the peak bodies has been successfully involved with a number of homes which failed to meet the standards and, in those situations, trained staff and members of the association have worked with the nursing home and the Commonwealth-States monitoring team to sort through issues regarding practical requirements and nursing care issues. That method of rapidly helping the nursing home to achieve the standards has not only been most satisfactory but also occurs no additional cost to the nursing home and consequently does not affect the standard of care that the home is able to maintain.

Before the end of the debate in this place I would like the Minister to put on the record where these advisers will be drawn from and who they will be. Will they come from private industry; will they come from the Department; what will their qualifications be; which funding component will the money to pay them come from; and, could not the standards monitoring teams do the job at less cost? I suppose it is indicative of the lack of information which is available to the industry that these questions need to be asked in the debate. Perhaps it is a failure of adequate consultation that they need to be asked at this time.

There is some concern in the industry that these changes will give the Minister and the Department more power over a nursing home which it considers is breaching standards. As I have said, I hold no brief for an institution which is breaching standards. The appointed advisers will have no legal responsibility or liability under the Act, apparently. There are no safeguards on cost imposts on the proprietor or the nature and qualifications of the adviser. The current procedure, if a nursing home is considered not to have met outcome standards, is for the Minister to impose financial sanctions on the home and it is no longer funded for new admittances.

The amendments will result in the proprietor, who already has reduced funds—that is, no funding for new admittances—having to maintain staffing levels and services in addition to paying an indeterminate amount to an adviser. The amendments are silent on whether the payment for services of an adviser is claimable under CAM or SAM, or how it will be treated in terms of NH20, reconciliation and validation. Clearly, there is more information needed on all these areas. Let us not forget that one major reason why nursing homes fail to meet standards is related to cash flow, and that seems to be something which is not well understood in the Department, as I said in this place only recently. The best people to sort out these problems are those with a background in the nursing home business and with a knowledge of standards. There are major doubts as to whether the Department could find the practical employees who are needed.

Before I conclude, I draw attention to something which is symptomatic of the problem being faced by the industry. I have been very concerned and outspoken about the heavy hand of regulation, bureaucracy and bureaucratic control on this industry. Standards need to be maintained and the taxpayer also needs to be protected in terms of the revenue, but I think things are getting out of hand when one gets a nine-page document like the one that I have here with me—nine pages all to address a very specific aspect of funding. This is just one part of the funding process. This document is entitled `Nursing Home Additional Recurrent Funding for Enteral Feeding Additional Information'. The nine pages are going to all non-government nursing homes for the aged, excluding adjusted fee government nursing homes, all State and Territory offices from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. One wonders how many trees got chopped down to do it. I would love to be able to read it all to honourable senators because it is in great bureaucratese. Maybe we could have plain English classes in the Department.

It is an indication of why senior nursing staff are tearing their hair out as a result of the Government's bureaucratic demands, and we heard evidence of this in the committees recently. There are myriad forms to fill in. This matter of enteral feeding goes on for nine pages of instructions and requires an NH22 schedule to be filled in; then it requires an NH3A form entitled `Nursing and Personal Care Details' to be filled in; the schedule must be attached to the monthly NH3 claim for Commonwealth benefits forms; then at the end of the financial year the nursing home will need to complete a NH24 `Finalisation of Enteral Feeding Expenditure for Non-government Nursing Homes for the Aged' giving details of the amounts actually spent. There are myriads of these forms that have to be filled out constantly by directors of nursing in these organisations all around the country. They are saying they do not have the time to give the nursing care and the personal attention that the residents need. The reason they do not have the time is the unrealistic demands that are being imposed on them from Canberra.

Something has to call a stop to the process. I just do not know that people here are aware of what they are doing to nursing homes and, increasingly, to hostels. Anybody who has had any contact with the aged care industry would acknowledge the growing and excessive regulation and bureaucratic control of the funding program. It is leading also to uncertainty in the funding system and to an unacceptable reduction in the amount of time available for the nursing and personal care staff to care for frail aged Australians. It is time that the funding became more certain and for the onerous demands of government on the nursing staff in the nursing homes and hostels to be reduced. I make a plea for the Department and the Government to undertake a New Year resolution to reduce the bureaucratic burdens that they are placing on this industry so that older Australians can get all the care they so badly need.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Before calling Senator Spindler, who is going to speak on the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill, I understand that the Minister has a correction to an explanatory memo to table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a correction to the explanatory memorandum relating to the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. It seems to be a very minor and technical matter.

—The main purpose of the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill is the allocation of additional government funds to the community housing area pursuant to measures contained in the Government's 1992-93 Budget. The legislative package provides for more than $4 billion to be spent over the next four years on public housing measures under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and it seeks to increase the quantity of public housing available in that period.

PARA.TAB: Some of the amendments will allow States and Territories more flexibility in the planning stages of public housing programs, and this is something that obviously has been needed for some time in the public housing funding area. Nevertheless, I would like to express a concern that has been brought to us by the community that is concerned with the provision of public housing and by people who rely on public housing, and that is that this should not become a trend towards totally untied grants by the Government to the States. I would like the Minister to give us an assurance that this loosening of the provisions will not mean that moneys provided to the States for public housing purposes could, under certain conditions, be spent in other ways.

Concern has also been expressed about the internal flexibility, which is, on principle, welcome. However, there must be some concern when you look at the fact that some State governments might be pursuing a different philosophical agenda in line with the Fightback package and some assurance would be needed, for instance, that the funds could not be used to provide, say, vouchers for rental assistance. Those methods have been shown internationally to be ineffective in helping the people concerned who are looking for housing assistance but rather have increased the cost of housing in a market economy.

To that extent, I take with a grain of salt the assurance that Senator Newman has given on the public housing aspects of the Fightback package because it is quite clear that the philosophy that is being pursued is to shift public housing into private enterprise hands and to give rental subsidies to people looking for public housing. I refer again to research which is on the table which shows that this is not a very effective way of providing public housing assistance. It is also quite clear that shifting the ownership and control of the public housing stock away from governments and into private enterprise will considerably reduce control of the direction of priorities as to the location and other decisions that have to be made on the basis of social considerations. I believe that it is not a trend that is to be welcomed and I can fully understand the concerns expressed by sections of the community about this trend and about the proposals in Fightback—to a large extent the Australian Democrats share them.

Returning to the Bill, the $4 billion allocation over four years includes additional funding of $123m to be directly allocated to community housing. Despite the amount of funding contained in this legislative package, however, it is necessary to assess the measures against the general background of consistent government cutbacks in the housing area over a long period of time.

Since 1983, when the Australian Labor Party came to office, housing has been treated, at best, as a low priority by this Government, particularly under the strict economic rationalism practised by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) when he was Treasurer. In the past, the Federal Government has attempted to throw much of the blame for our present housing crisis on State and local governments. This has been a rather devious strategy, I submit, since it is only the Federal Government which has had the full economic and taxation powers to deal with Australia's mounting housing crisis.

In my own State of Victoria, we now face a major housing crisis, with homelessness having reached unprecedented levels and the number of people on public housing waiting lists having increased from 38,000 to over 55,000 in the past two years, according to a report recently released by the Victorian Council of Social Service.

The Government claims that the Bill before us increases public housing funding in a very real way. To some extent that is true but, as I have said before, it must be seen against the reduction of expenditure in this area during the last four years. In the period between 1986 and 1990, funding under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement was effectively reduced by up to 40 per cent in some cases.

Even if one were able to take into account the increases before us in this Bill, government funding to housing programs would still be well below the levels of allocation in the Budgets handed down in 1983-84 and 1984-85. The cuts have had a severe effect on the public housing programs currently in place. I suspect that the Government's fairly recent conversion to bolstering public housing with funding injections, as set out in the legislation before us, is founded on the wish to get the economy going rather than to supply more public housing to the people who need it.

The Australian Democrats recently released a policy statement entitled Getting to Work. It is founded on the principles and values of a fair go and the responsibility of the Government to intervene in the day to day implementation of economic and social policies, which are fundamentally different from those of both the Government and the Opposition.

The fact remains that Australia has never had an integrated set of housing policies coordinated within its broader social and economic framework. The national housing strategy, which was launched two years ago under the present Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) offers, in that sense, a limited but still welcome prospect in this regard. The Democrats will ensure that the strategy is used to achieve improvements in this area in line with the proposals of the Democrats in Getting to Work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Originally, I was only going to speak on the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992 but, given what Senator Spindler has said, I cannot resist also speaking on the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1992. Yesterday in the chamber, Senator Lees outlined some aspects of the package of the Liberal Party of Australia which are not correct. Today, again, Senator Spindler has said that the Liberal Party plan will not work.

PARA.TAB: I want to put the record straight. With respect to public housing, the Defence Housing Authority has agreements with organisations in the private sector which build housing. The Defence Housing Authority rents those houses at full commercial rates, and then it sublets them to Defence families. Defence pays the Housing Authority the subsidy, which is the difference between the commercial rent and what the tenant pays. It is not like the old subsidised rental scheme in which the subsidy went to the tenant and the private landlord increased the rent.

Under our policy, the system for those people who require public housing would operate in a similar fashion to that which was introduced by the Labor Government, and which is very successfully operating under the Defence Housing Authority. If the Democrats are going to talk about policies, they should actually get them right. That would be most helpful and it would save us time in here in that we would not have to rectify what they are saying.

With respect to the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), Senator Newman has outlined the parts of the Bill which relate to funding hostels, upgrading nursing homes, and also the provision which enables an adviser to be appointed to a home that has breached the conditions of approval. I will not go over those because we are running out of time.

The final amendment proposed by this legislation will rectify an anomaly which disadvantages pathology practices that choose to merge. Currently, when two or more practices merge, the resulting approved pathology authority loses the right to temporary licence collection centres. Clearly, a fundamental commercial activity such as a merger should not be discouraged in this way. The Government has also claimed that this amendment will do much to discourage unnecessary over-servicing.

The coalition supports the amendments contained in this Bill. However, it must be pointed out that we do have some concerns, as Senator Newman has said, about the allocation of sufficient funding to nursing homes seeking upgrading. As she has already said, we are highly critical of the many inadequacies in the Government's aged care health policies which are highlighted in this Bill.

Concerning the pathology amendments, it must be noted that the Bill does not do anything to address the massive blow-out in expenditure under Medicare. I guess we will be discussing that in further detail when the Auditor-General's report that we are awaiting eagerly reaches our desks.

In the financial year 1991-92 the total expenditure on benefits under Medicare increased by 8.2 per cent to a staggering $4.6 billion. This is compared with a total expenditure on Medicare benefits of $2.2 billion in the first financial year of Medicare in 1984-85. This means that, since the inception of Medicare in 1984, benefits paid under Medicare for services ranging from general practice to optometry have risen by 101.1 per cent. Despite this increase we still have a health care system which is incapable of delivering an efficient, effective and timely health service to all Australians.

The pathology amendments also do nothing to meet the criticisms levelled at the Government by the Australian Association of Pathology Practices. The peak industry body has stated that it has been subjected to continual changes in its legislation resulting in anomalies and ambiguities that the Government has been very reluctant to address. We hear this over and over again. It has happened with a number of the health professions, including the pharmacy profession, and we see it now happening with pathologists. The pathologists' amendment we are discussing provides a good example of the Government's reluctance to listen to the industry.

The legislation has been changed in haste, and might I add that we spend an awful lot of time, especially at this time of the year, patching up legislation that was put through this place in haste. I have said this to Senator Tate before. The legislation affects people's lives and their livelihoods. The Government has been tardy in addressing this and correcting it, and then we waste time in the Senate going back over it. We ought to be getting it right in the first place. There is an army of people who should be able to go through it and think about all the consequences and maybe try to generate some of the unintended consequences to ensure that people are not affected, and especially that their livelihoods are not affected.

Having changed the legislation in haste, it was then discovered that pathology practices would be discouraged from merging because they would lose their temporary licences. This was pointed out to the Government but it has taken some time to convince it to make this necessary amendment. In the meantime the Government's inaction has meant that pathology practice mergers have been on the brink, on the edge, waiting, as some of the pathologists said to me this morning. It has been at some expense to their operators.

While the coalition supports the amendments in this Bill, we are disappointed that the Government has once again failed to provide any long term assistance for our failing health and aged care sectors. It again has demonstrated its lack of consultation with the health professions, and also its inability to get its act together to amend legislation when it is wrong to make sure that these people who have been affected by it do not have to wait the length of time they have waited in this instance.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be speaking on the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill, which contains several measures relating to hostels and nursing homes. Some of these were announced in the Budget and others have been on the drawing board for quite some time.

PARA.TAB: The Bill sets up a mechanism for establishing hostel standards review panels in each State, the ACT and the Northern Territory. These panels will provide additional peer review in the process of hostel monitoring. At present, departmental monitoring teams measure a hostel's performance against a formal set of standards and this has been in effect since 1 January last year.

Under this Bill, the Minister may make a declaration stating that a particular hostel operator is not complying with the standards. Once the declaration has been made, the Minister has the power to suspend payment to the operator, although that suspension applies only to hostel places that are unoccupied or become unoccupied after the declaration is made. At this point, the hostel operator can apply to the hostel standards review panel for a review. The panels will have the power to review the operation of the hostels, either at the direction of the Minister or as a result of a written request from the hostel operator.

After conducting a review, the panel will then recommend to the Minister whether a declaration should be made or not, whether Commonwealth payments should be suspended—and, if so, for how long—and whether the panel's report should be released to the operator, the staff and the hostel's residents.

We have some concerns about the last provision. We are talking about a panel which has the power to recommend to a Minister that Commonwealth payments be suspended. Furthermore, if the Minister goes ahead and makes a declaration based on the panel's review, information about the hostel can be made public. The information includes the name and address of the hostel; the name and address of any other hostel that the operator owns and runs; the operator's business name and address; details of the operator's failure to meet the standards; and what actions the Minister has taken.

So we can see that it is a very important panel and it could well result in the closure of a hostel. Certainly that is fair enough if it is providing inadequate care, but I would have thought that simple natural justice would have meant that the operators have an automatic right to actually see a report from the panel. It also should be quite reasonable to expect that the staff automatically would get a look at the report and, perhaps even more importantly, that the residents and their relatives should have a right to see it. I would appreciate some clarification from the Minister as to why this provision appears in the Bill as it does because, on the face of it, it appears to be rather unfair.

The Bill also provides for Commonwealth grants to be paid to proprietors of nursing homes to enable them to substantially upgrade their premises. This extends to the private for profit sector, an arrangement which has been available to the voluntary sector for several years. From now on, a proprietor can apply to the Minister for specific assistance from the Commonwealth, where she or he believes that upgrading of the premises will increase the well-being of the home's residents. I know from visiting some of the homes that there are some proprietors who are very keen to see the physical upgrading go ahead to improve the standard of their premises, so this proposal, which was announced in the Budget, will be good news for all those proprietors and their residents.

The Bill also provides for a nursing home adviser to be appointed to a nursing home where the home has breached its conditions of approval. The adviser's role will be to assist the proprietor to move to a situation where the home does comply with the conditions of approval. The proprietor will continue to be responsible for the home. In effect, the Government is saying to these homes, `Instead of us shutting you down, here is an opportunity to cooperate with us to try to fix the problem'. I am aware that there are some in the industry who are concerned about this provision. I do not believe that it is a particularly draconian arrangement, although I do see some problems with how it is actually going to work in practice.

I am well aware of the excellent work done in the vast majority of nursing homes by dedicated staff and also by proprietors who are committed to providing the best possible care for their residents. However, we have to keep in the back of our minds that there are some homes where we really do have some major problems and which certainly need to be brought up to standard.

We have to acknowledge there is a level of accountability here. Firstly, nursing home proprietors are accountable for Commonwealth funds and, therefore, the Commonwealth has every right to actually impose some quite strict conditions and standards on them. Secondly, there is surely a level of accountability to a group of people who are amongst the most vulnerable in our society: the residents. They are often powerless themselves to assert their rights, and I think the Commonwealth, whether or not it is handing out the funds, certainly has an obligation to look after this group of people.

As I said, I have two particular concerns about these provisions which I raise now, and I look forward to the Minister's response. Firstly, one of my concerns is that the appointment of an adviser may slow down a process which should, in fact, be speeded up. I would not like to see advisers appointed in situations where a nursing home is so bad that it ought to be closed down, or to have sanctions immediately applied to it. I would not like to see the appointment of advisers result in the duplication of work which should be carried out by the standards monitoring teams. Secondly, I know the industry is concerned about the fact that this provision is open-ended. In other words, there is no time limit and no financial figure put on the appointment of an adviser, and indeed, no details as to how that adviser is to be paid for.

Presumably, the process cannot drag on and on forever. It is not fair to residents if the adviser fails to meet with success and the nursing home goes on continuing to operate and providing that inadequate standard of care. Surely, there needs to be either a time limit or some trigger which will move the process into a new phase, possibly at the application of further sanctions and possibly closure.

From the opposite point of view, it is not fair on proprietors if they have done everything they possibly could to fix the breaches of conditions but are still financially saddled with an adviser. Again, I thought it would have made some sense to have a provision terminating the appointment of the adviser where the original breach of conditions has been rectified. It may well be the Government's intention that that is how these provisions will work in practice, but it certainly is not clear in the legislation; and I ask for some clarification.

Finally, on the other issue in this legislation in relation to pathology and the merger of practices, these patch-up amendments are welcomed by the Democrats and certainly by the industry, but I foreshadow that early in the new year, when we resume in this place, we will need again to look at the whole issue of the delivery of pathology services, particularly regional and remote services.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—The Senate is discussing the Health and Community Services Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1992. Much of the discussion has centred on perhaps some elements rather than others. In particular, the first discussion concerned the proposal to provide for hostel standards review panels and for sanctions for failure to meet standards. I believe that, in so far as those measures work well in nursing homes, we have reason to be confident that they will also work well in relation to hostels. Certainly, it is important that the Government does protect residents by imposing sanctions on hostels which are providing poor standards of care and quality of life and then, of course, enable operators to have an avenue of appeal through the hostel standards review panels. I do not think there was a great deal of argument about that measure which I picked up.

PARA.TAB: As to the nursing home upgrading, obviously it is very important to have a provision coming out of the Budget which will allow for the payment of a benefit in respect of upgrading nursing homes where they are run by proprietors who at the moment are not eligible for funding for such capital upgrading. I believe that these private homes will, of course, welcome this particular measure. It is a substantial one indeed. The element of that particular discussion which attracted attention I do not think needs very much comment by me.

The further element in relation to nursing homes, though, was the provision which allows a nursing home adviser to be appointed to a nursing home that has breached the conditions of approval of approved nursing homes. This particular adviser will, of course, be appointed—that is true—from a list approved by the Secretary to the Department, but it is intended that there be very full discussion with the industry before drawing up a list of persons who could act as advisers. They would certainly be people experienced in management of age care facilities. They would not be departmental officers and they will be put on a list only after consultation with the industry as to suitable persons.

The appointment of such a person will, of course, be in a sense offered as an alternative to closure or a very heavy sanction being imposed in relation to the management of the nursing home concerned. It is, therefore, quite clearly going to be in the interests of the nursing home proprietor to take up that particular possibility as an alternative to a more draconian sanction. It is expected that the nursing home will pay for the person who is put in for that purpose. I think Senator Newman asked about whether there could be reimbursement under the CAM system or SAM funding or whatever. The fact is that it will be a cost that will be borne by the nursing home, and I think the cost is to be agreed between the two by way of contract. Something will emerge, I suppose, as the norm, though one would hope that this will be a fairly rare event.

Senator Lees asked some questions about whether a person ought to be appointed at all where it might be better to grasp the nettle and close down the nursing home if in fact it is being run in a way which is really putting the well-being of the residents in true jeopardy. I think that would be a matter that would be taken into account in the process. Senator Lees also asked about a time limit, particularly where the problem has been rectified. I would imagine—just off the top of my head—that it would be possible to write into the arrangement between the nursing home and the adviser that the arrangement would cease when the reason for which the person having been brought in had itself ceased to exist. These are matters which are of true concern and I will seek assurances from the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, that he will endeavour to meet those concerns that have been raised by Senator Lees, and those concerns should be dealt with.

In relation to the pathology matters, I do not think there is anything much that requires discussion there. It is, as has been mentioned, a patch-up provision. Where two and more pathology practices merge, the resulting improved pathology authority that emerges loses the right to temporary licensed collection centres, and that has to be remedied. I understand that the Australian Association of Pathology Practitioners, which is the industry association, has stated that it supports the amendments, as you would expect. Just in relation to one point that Senator Patterson made—I am always interested in her contributions—I understand that pathology has had a negative growth in outlays. I do not know quite what that means, how you have a negative growth, but I presume that it means no growth at all or that in fact it has gone down slightly. It must be relevant to something that Senator Patterson has said.

As to the Housing Assistance Amendment Bill 1992, this is a very important earnest of the Government's commitment to public and community housing, with a Budget provision of $4 billion over four years to 1995-96. Another $4 billion will be provided in the same period for rent assistance, together with $816m for the building better cities program and $25.5m for the national urban development program. I believe that, contrary to some of Senator Spindler's concerns or fears about the implementation of these particular programs, the major theme of the strategy is to recognise the need for housing variety and choice, given the very many different types of households and differing needs at different points in the lives of individuals. I think it is also important to say to Senator Spindler that the Commonwealth will have control of the principles which underlie the provision of this type of accommodation under these arrangements by the States. The States will not be able to impose their ideological or political agenda on the provision of such housing or accommodation if it departs from that which commends itself to the Federal government as it may be from time to time. I think that that is an important matter to reaffirm.
I believe that these Bills deserve the support of the Senate and I commend them to the chamber.
Bills read a second time.
The Bills.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer to some of my questions relating to the adviser. I am just looking for clarification that when the contract is drawn up, all the time lines and the actual aims and objectives and everything will be very clearly stated so that the home knows where it is going as well as the adviser. Also, with relation to the hostel standards review report, is that going to be automatically available to the operator, to the staff and in particular to the residents and their relatives?

—I understand that I can give an assurance that it will be available before it is made public. As to the first question, it is an arrangement which will be made between the home and the adviser in order to stave off a terrible fate. It is up to the contracting parties to determine the terms, but I cannot see any reason why they would not embrace a specifying of the problem and an indication of the nature of the task to be undertaken by the adviser by way of reaching a situation which overcomes the problem. I do not see why the contract would not come to an end when that problem had been satisfactorily resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to raise in the Committee as a whole some of the matters that were discussed in the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training in relation to the Australian National Training Authority Bill. I am not convinced that this Bill properly addresses all the concerns involved in the operation of the new Australian National Training Authority. In the Committee hearings we had representatives from industry express concerns about the operation of ANTA. These primarily involved: firstly, the problem of bureaucracy and centralism; secondly, the danger posed by State training profiles; and, thirdly, the seeming lack of industry consultation in the setting up of ANTA. It is absolutely critical that ANTA avoids excessive bureaucracy and allows existing State agencies to respond flexibly to local need.

PARA.TAB: It was very clear from all the witnesses called before the public hearings that planning nationally and doing locally was the critical balance that had to be achieved in this area. I am not completely convinced that the structure of ANTA will be able to achieve this. I am aware that it is not ANTA's role to be directly involved in curriculum, nor will it in any way impose curriculum or training on the various agencies and States. However, there is a need for State training profiles and this seems to me to be potentially intrusive and could easily place unnecessary burdens on training agencies.

When these concerns were raised in the Committee hearings, officers from the Department assured us that these profiles applied at the whole of the State level and not at the level of individual institutions. Therefore, we were told that our fears were totally unfounded. But I dispute this. As these proposals stand, ANTA will require State training profiles to be developed. These profiles will provide a broad indication of the training operations at the State level which should be consistent with the national training direction set by the Ministerial Council. The Ministerial Council will then formally approve the State profiles.

The only way for the States to develop profiles is to require individual institutions to provide information on their curricula. Thus, although the bureaucracy in paperwork is not imposed directly from ANTA, it is required by ANTA indirectly. From this, it is only a small step for ANTA and associated bureaucrats to start imposing on the individual training institutions requirements which would create a centrally structured bureaucratic and inflexible system. This is what happened with the Dawkins national unified system disaster at the university level. We certainly do not want to see this repeated in any other area of education. If it happens to the training sector, it could overstep that very important balance that I alluded to earlier—the balance between planning nationally and doing locally.

The other important issue to arise out of the Committee's hearings was the extreme importance of industry involvement. Industry must be involved in all the stages of establishing and operating ANTA. It is disconcerting, therefore, that there has been virtually no consultation with industry bodies in the development of the legislation that is before us today. This is just another area where the operation of ANTA needs very close observation. It will be important for the ANTA board members to ensure that industry is closely consulted. To this end, it is very good to see that Mr Brian Finn has been appointed as the chairman.

While I support the establishment of the Australian National Training Authority, I believe that the concerns I have raised are very valid. To this end, it is very important that ANTA and its operations be reviewed by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, and the Committee has proposed that this be done one year from now. In this way, we can ensure that ANTA is operating to the satisfaction of industry, government, training organisations and the students it serves. If it is not, we will be able to correct the situation before ANTA becomes just another arm of centralist government in the education sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 20, page 16, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Prohibition of re-exportation of failed food

SPEECH.PARA: "20A. The re-exportation of failed food is prohibited where the food is failed on public health grounds as defined in subsection 3(2).

This amendment seeks to prohibit the re-exportation of food that has failed on public health grounds, as specified in clause 3(2) of the Imported Food Control Bill, because it contains pathogenic micro-organisms or their toxins, and high levels of chemicals or additives or non-approved chemicals and additives. Basically this is food not fit for human consumption. So I do not see why Australia should say, `This food is not good enough for us to eat, but we do not mind you shipping it out to some other country for people there to eat, because they have lower standards or poorer inspection processes'. I feel quite strongly that Australia should not be part of that practice that leads to port hopping for substandard food.

PARA.TAB: Under my amendment, the exporter will still have the opportunity to rework the food into something else. For example, the food can be reworked into animal feed or fertiliser, or the importer can have the food destroyed and the importer should be carrying insurance for that. As it stands, there is absolutely no incentive for importers to lift their game. They know that if Australia rejects the food on public health and safety grounds, they can just ship it elsewhere. I take the view that once we allow the food to enter Australia we are then responsible for it.

Senator Boswell, in his press release of 9 December, said that this Bill will end the practice of importers port hopping until they find where they can avoid the inspection process. I say to Senator Boswell, who is not here, that is absolutely wrong. As long as the provision remains for failed food to be re-exported in its failed state, the practice of port shopping will continue and Australia will be a willing part of that.

Why should we not take a stand? For goodness sake, look how long it has taken this Parliament to properly grapple with issues such as appropriate labelling. Why do we always allow ourselves to stand back, wait for the obvious problems to happen, and then spend years trying to fix up the consequences? I believe this is a very sensible amendment. I believe we should be pro-active and that we should intervene. I commend this amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose the amendment. I understand the idealistic sentiment behind it, and I commend that sentiment, but the view the Government takes is that if an importer brings in food that does not meet our standard that does not mean that the Government should seize that food or direct how it should be dealt with, except for one important qualification I will come to. If the owners of that food can export it elsewhere and meet the qualifications of another country, or return that food to source and have it involved in another process that makes it acceptable, they should be able to have that choice.

PARA.TAB: If we were to prohibit that choice, my kerbside view—not, I might say, as a lawyer—is that there may well be an action open to the owner of the property to the Commonwealth, on the grounds that compensation is payable and I do not think it is desirable that that chink should be opened. The one exception we see to that rule is that if the food clearly cannot be utilised in any other fashion and is, for example, toxic then its re-export should be prohibited. The way we have proposed the Bill it would be. If the food does not meet our standards but meets some other standards, the owner of the food should be able to have the choice of how to deal with it and we should not impose the standards that we want for Australians on the rest of the world simply by saying, `You cannot do that and you cannot have that option despite your investment in the product'.

While I understand the idealistic plane from which Senator Kernot addresses this matter, there are some practical questions that have to be considered and, for that reason, the Government will not support the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I share the views and concern expressed by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) that, in normal manner, the Australian Democrats, once again, seek to regulate everything they can get their hands on. In this particular instance we are looking at some very important commercial principles that have to be underpinned. Similarly, we would expect reciprocal arrangements internationally that could be quite important with regard to Australian marketing at the same time. The coalition will not be supporting the amendment and in general terms I share the views of the Government.

—I understand and I acknowledge the possibility of compensation being payable, but it comes back to the age-old argument: those who own and those who invest have rights which are more important than those who have to consume. What about people in Third World countries? What about people who just do not have appropriate standards? We stand back and take no moral responsibility at all for shipping off to them food which is not fit for human consumption. It is just too easy to always raise practical considerations. The scales are unfairly balanced in this case and Australia should be taking a stand on it.
