TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the decision by the Government's Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics to slash its 1992-93 estimate of growth for the Australian economy by almost one-third down to 2 1/2 per cent. I also refer to the State Bank of New South Wales-New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures December quarter survey of manufacturing which forecast that another 73,000 jobs could be lost in 1993 because small manufacturing companies simply do not believe the Government's predictions of economic recovery. Does the Minister agree with ABARE's downward revision of growth or does he continue to share the Prime Minister's totally cloud-cuckoo-land assertion that economic growth of 4 per cent is achievable this year? When will he recognise that his Government's policies have failed and that the recession was not over long ago, as the Prime Minister asserts. I ask again: when will the Government release its policies?
—Order! The time for the question has expired.
—Of course the honourable senator runs out of time; that is because he always turns Question Time into rhetorical speeches.
—Two days and you are finished.

—Senator Macdonald says in two days I will be finished. Senator Macdonald will be here forever—over there, in the same seat if he is lucky, but I think further back is more likely on the basis of his performance as shadow Minister. He has asked eight questions this year and only one of them was devoted to his policies.
—Did you count them all, and are you sober?
—I have not seen the ABARE growth estimate. As the honourable senator says, the ABARE figures for this year are 2 1/2 per cent but—
—Are you sober?
—Order! I ask that you withdraw that.
—I withdraw, Mr President. But are you going to protect me in regard to those gratuitous comments that are quite untrue?
—Yes.
—You are going to protect me?
—If the same comment was made about you, Senator Macdonald, I would ask for it to be withdrawn. I ignored the first time that you said it.
—What about the questions that I raised with you yesterday, Mr President?
—Order! I have asked you to withdraw.
—I have withdrawn. I am now asking whether you will protect me.
—I answered that.
—Mr President, Senator Macdonald uses this place in order to try to get himself a spot on Townsville radio, for goodness sake. That is not what Question Time is about.

PARA.TAB: I am aware of a 2 1/2 per cent estimate and I am also aware of ABARE's estimates for out-years, which are much more encouraging. As far as the State Bank of New South Wales-Chamber of Manufactures survey is concerned, I think we have always had a little difficulty with the methodology of that survey—I nearly said `mythology'—because they multiply a situation in their own State across national boundaries and try to achieve a result in that way. I much prefer the surveys which have been done—and there is a bit of selective survey in this business—by a variety of other organisations, including, of course, the Opposition's own very busy think-tank, Access Economics, which recently made the point that growth was taking place in the smaller business area, not amongst larger businesses where a considerable degree of disemployment was still taking place. Access Economics is supported in that survey by a survey done by the David Syme Business School at Monash University and by others.

So there are different views about these issues. I understand that Senator Short will naturally clutch at the most pessimistic one, being as he is buoyant with gloom and dedicated to catastrophe. Forecasting is always difficult. I will await the JEFG forecasts which will be published by the Treasurer in due course before making any comment on the Budget prediction in relation to growth rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Yet again the Minister has absolutely refused to attempt to answer the question. I will put it to him in simple terms again: does he still agree with the Prime Minister's assertion that 4 per cent growth is achievable this year? Does he agree with the Budget forecast that 3 per cent is achievable? If he does not agree with either of those figures, when will he produce a figure that he does agree with? I ask him again: when will this Government be releasing its policies to address the fundamental crisis now facing the Australian economy?

—We have been through all this before. The Government will announce any new policies that it may wish to announce at the appropriate time. Senator Short attributes to the Prime Minister the statement that a 4 per cent growth rate is achievable this year. That is not my recollection of what he said. He said that a 4 per cent growth rate is achievable and desirable in this economy. I have already answered earlier the question about the Budget forecast of 3 per cent.

—Has the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce seen a report called The challenge of leadership: Australia's emerging high value-added manufacturing exporters published yesterday by the Australian Manufacturing Council? This report results from a study of 700 companies. Can the Minister inform the Senate of details of this report and the importance of the companies surveyed to future economic growth?

—The point of Senator Devereux's question is important following on Senator Short's question. The McKinsey report, commissioned by the Australian Manufacturing Council, was a survey of 700 new exporting companies in Australia. It underlines the importance of small to medium size manufacturing exports. These exports are increasingly important. Increasingly, the wealthy countries of the world are the ones that produce sophisticated manufactured goods. Unless we in Australia produce more of these goods and sell them internationally, we will not be able to pay our way in this world.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition, of course, will not like this report because it threatens to puncture its present euphoria about Australia's current economic difficulties. The report shows that many small and medium sized companies are recording significant successes in international markets. The survey identified 700 of these manufacturers which have rapidly increased exports over the past five years. These companies now earn Australia about $8 billion a year. McKinsey predicts that this export income will grow to $15 billion over the next five years.

The 700 companies concerned are companies which have a new export culture. I have visited and talked to many of them. They are high value-added manufacturers, innovative young companies, run by a new generation of business people. Many of these companies once concentrated on the domestic market only but, in recent years, they have got into exports. There are plenty of examples of those. The Opposition, which gets all its policies from a paid think-tank, would probably not be aware of the existence of many of these companies. The fact of the matter is that they are there and I have visited many of them. They are very important in the changing and diverse pattern of Australian trade, particularly in the Asia-Pacific region.

I commend the survey for serious study. If members of the Opposition can get a look at it before Friday, it would be very good for them; it would be very helpful. It would save them visiting any of these places. They might understand some of the problems which are realistic problems as distinct from theoretical ones identified by paid policy providers of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Did the report provide any information on the importance of Asian markets to the 700 countries surveyed? As the economic recovery gathers pace, is there a danger that these companies will refocus on the domestic market at the expense of exports?

—It is the historic experience under conservative governments in this country that new exporting companies tend to fall back into supplying the domestic market in a period of growth. That was not the experience from 1985 to 1990 in a period of high economic growth in Australia. Manufacturing exports grew by approximately 15 per cent a year throughout that period—a period when one would normally have expected them to fall backwards.

PARA.TAB: Most of the companies surveyed, as the senator points out by implication in his question, are committed very strongly to Asian markets. There are a variety of reasons for that, including niche opportunities and the same time zone. These companies now see exports as critical to their success and survival. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for every other company in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government to last night's evidence to the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council by the Treasury Secretary, Mr Cole, in which he confirmed that in the months of May and June this year the Treasurer made clear his desire to be kept fully informed of the extent of the former Victorian Government's financial derelictions. Mr Cole also confirmed that from 17 June onwards, he and the Treasury were of the view that Victoria was guilty of a $1.3 billion breach of the global borrowing limit requirements and yet the Treasurer was not informed until 6 July. In view of this extraordinary behaviour, what action is the Government taking against the Treasury for deliberately withholding such vital information for a period of almost three weeks, despite the fact that Mr Cole met with the Treasurer on a number of occasions during that period?

—This just highlights that, in the eyes of the Opposition, this whole issue is a political stunt. The Opposition asked for an inquiry, but before the inquiry was even launched, Senator Bishop pronounced on its findings. Halfway through the inquiry, Senator Alston, a member of the Committee—

—On a point of order, Mr President; Senator Button is clearly debating the issue. I draw your attention to standing order 73(4). I am prepared to debate that issue with Senator Button any time. I will speak for myself. I do not need my views to be distorted and misrepresented by him. I would ask you to call him to order.
—Mr President, I am making a point in answer to Senator Alston's question. Before this Senate inquiry was set up, even before it had held a meeting, Senator Bishop described it as a cover-up.
—Order! A point of order was taken. I ask Senator Button to answer the question that he was asked. I point out that he is not being helped by consistent interjections.
—If ever there is a cover-up, it is a point of order device—a double cover-up.
—On a point of order, Mr President; Senator Button is now reflecting on your ruling, calling it a cover-up. I ask you to ask him to withdraw that implication against your ruling.
—Mr President, on the point of order; that was the world record, most vexatious, provocative point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 203 and ask you to enforce it in future.
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Alston should have a look at the terms of reference of the inquiry of which he is a member. The terms of reference require the Committee to investigate a variety of matters and report to the Senate. When the Committee is halfway through the inquiry—because this is a political stunt from A to B in the hands of the Opposition—Senator Alston gets up in Question Time and asks me what judgment we will make about Treasury officers on the basis of some evidence which has been given to the Committee. It is a totally irresponsible question, a totally irresponsible attitude, and indicates the desperation of this Opposition to turn every procedure into a political stunt.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Leader of the Government seriously saying that, despite evidence being presented in a public hearing to a Senate committee that the senior Treasury officer deliberately refused to bring serious matters to the attention of the Treasurer, somehow these matters should not even be canvassed until the Committee has finally delivered its report? I should have thought that is a preposterous proposal. If that is the extent to which the Government takes these matters seriously, the sooner it gets out the better.

—The supplementary question reveals the angst, the emotion, the upset, the need to make this into a political stunt—approaching every issue with an open mouth rather than an open mind. I would not get into it if I were Senator Alston, because he said that this inquiry should report by a certain date to the Senate with its conclusions drawn.
—What about answering the question?

—I am not going to answer a question about an inquiry which is part heard. It just indicates the political desperation and irresponsibility of this Opposition that Senator Alston, who is a shadow Minister in this place, should be allowed to ask a question like that. His real motives were revealed in his shot at me at the end of his question—smouldering with hate, desperation and frustration. Bad luck. Have your inquiry and produce your conclusions.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Given the fact that there are currently a number of High Court challenges and threatened High Court challenges to recent Federal Government industrial relations initiatives, and given that several interest groups and State governments are attacking these policies with great vigour, can the Minister inform the Senate whether such opposition in any way weakens this Government's resolve to maintain and further develop a strong industrial relations system that is fair, flexible and equitable?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Our resolve is undiminished. Our resolve is not weakened. We intend to press ahead and lay the foundation for the continuing access to fair arbitration to make awards by an independent arbitral authority should there be a dispute between employers and unions. This morning I met with Ministers for Labour from the States and Territories or their representatives at a meeting to consider what the Prime Minister and I announced over a fortnight ago. We announced then that we would present legislation to the Parliament, which we did last night in this chamber, concerning the ability of people who do not have access to independent arbitration to access independent arbitration at a Federal level should they opt to do so.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister and I also announced a fortnight ago that we would seek to encode ILO conventions as international minimum labour standards as a safety net to underpin the Australian system so that no employer could force a worker to work for conditions below those approved of by the International Labour Organisation agency of the United Nations. In particular, we specified that the minimum wages convention, the equal pay convention and the unfair dismissals and redundancy convention would be priorities but that we would deal with conventions at a later time concerning hours of work, leave, and parental and maternal leave.

The outcome of today's meeting is that all of the States and the Commonwealth unanimously agreed to proceed by way of the Commonwealth producing a draft Bill so that the States at officer level can examine the black letter of our proposals and then meet again in late January or early February to conclude this round of consultations. That is a process of consultation with the States that a Commonwealth government, in a federation of States, I think rightly, has engaged in. But it does not mean that in any way we intend to back off from our determination to ensure that all Australians, whether they be employers or workers, are protected by a safety net of fair standards to ensure fair dealing, fair bargaining and, in the absence of agreement, fair arbitration between those parties to settle their differences.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. I refer to the nuclear research reactor review. Does the Minister think it is reasonable or fair that the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation has not yet provided a full submission to the review panel upon which the public could comment? Secondly, what mechanisms will the Minister put in place to ensure that the public has an opportunity to fully respond to the forthcoming ANSTO submission? Thirdly, will the Minister release the minutes of the meetings of the Australian Science and Technology Council at which the new high flux reactor was discussed, and prepare and release an index and guide to the documents written during that process?

—The first task of the review is to examine whether Australia has a need for a nuclear reactor. It will not use as a starting point a proposal to build such a facility. However, the Government's view is that it is reasonable that all interested individuals and groups should be able to provide comments on any proposal once it is on the table. For that reason, all submissions, including that of ANSTO, will be made widely available and will be placed, for example, in public libraries in each State.

PARA.TAB: Public hearings will commence in March and the first party to appear will be the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation. Review members will ask the questions, but any member of the public may attend. After hearing the evidence of ANSTO, or any other party, people wishing to provide further comment will be able to forward it to the secretariat within seven days and the review will consider whether the comments raise any issues requiring further investigation. No important information will be ignored. All material relating to the reactor can be made available.

In so far as the second part of Senator Sowada's question, relating to the release of the minutes, is concerned, she will appreciate that I will have to refer that to the Minister because it is a State-Federal body. I will provide her with an answer as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The Government decided yesterday that the licence for Australia's third public mobile telecommunications services carrier would be allocated to Arena-GSM. What benefits does the Government foresee in this decision for users of mobile telecommunications in Australia, the Australian telecommunications industry generally, and South Australia in particular?

—The decision yesterday to allocate the third PMTS licence to Arena is a significant one. This licence allocation marks another successful conclusion to what has been a raft of reforms in telecommunications from the Government. Arena is an innovative new-look telecommunications company with a great deal of drive and enthusiasm. Arena combines the impressive skills of Vodafone, which is a major British carrier, and the local expertise of an Australian company, AAP Information Services Pty Ltd.

PARA.TAB: Arena is committed to covering 80 per cent of Australia's population by 1996 including all capital cities and major towns. Arena expects a 25 per cent drop in mobile call charges as a result of its competition. Arena will be a big promoter of the Australian telecommunications industry and this is a particularly pleasing part of its bid. Up to 5,000 new jobs will be created through the operation of the Arena network and associated business.

Arena will establish its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Australia and will use Australian telecommunications expertise as it embarks on the operation of overseas mobile telecommunication networks in the region. Arena will spend about $400m on its network development and is committed to achieving 60 per cent local content on this capital expenditure. Training also has a high priority for this company. It is committed to spending $1.2m on training each year and it will establish a youth training scheme.

Senator Schacht asked about benefits for South Australia. There is good news there. The company is committed to spend $25m on research and development. The company will establish an R&D centre in Adelaide. This group will comprise Arena, its suppliers and major tertiary institutions. Arena has guaranteed an expenditure of a minimum of $1m per annum for five years as seed funding for this activity in South Australia. The significant benefits to consumers and the Australian telecommunications industry resulting from yesterday's decision, in addition to the $140m that Arena will pay the Government for the licence, mean that there has been a particularly successful result to this licensing process.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. I draw the Minister's attention to the peripatetic $4m-odd debt owed by Mr Keating's piggery group to his former ministerial colleague, Mr John Brown, and to the fact that there are now three different versions of this debt. Can the Minister advise what action can be taken to establish which version of the Keating piggery group's unsigned, unaudited accounts, all of which are in breach of ASC requirements, should be believed: that showing the group owing Mr Brown a debt of about $4m; that showing the debt shuffled out of the group's liabilities into shareholders' equity; or the latest corrected return required by the ASC showing the debt reshuffled into a contingent liability? I ask the Minister whether the present corporations law permits this kind of paper shuffling that significantly alters a company's apparent financial position? If it does, what action does the Government intend to take to ensure that people doing business with companies getting away with similar paper shuffling devices receive a true and fair view of their financial strength?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of a series of questions that have been posed by Senator Baume. I notice in today's Canberra Times an article by Crispin Hull, who says in his final paragraph:

ANSWER.PARA: The onus now is on the Opposition to put the questions in the House of Representatives. If they have not got the courage or conviction to do that, then they cannot be in a position to raise the issue in the election campaign and should leave it alone in the Senate.

I absolutely agree with that remark. If Senator Baume is asking for a legal opinion in regard to the corporations law, of course I will not offer it. He is a member of the Senate of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia which has passed the corporations law into effect. That law operates in accordance with terminology which was voted for by Senator Baume. I am quite sure that the scope of the law, as passed by this Parliament, is well known to the Australian Securities Commission. This independently established statutory authority properly is vested with independence. The personnel of it are clothed with such integrity that it would be quite improper for me to try to give any guidance as to the interpretation of the law which they should bring to bear in relation to the provisions of the law passed by this Parliament. I certainly do not intend to interfere in that regard.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this matter can be left safely to the statutory authority set up by this Parliament. As I have said many times before, I believe that it is quite improper to suggest that some sort of political guidance should emanate from the office of myself or the Attorney-General that interferes with that statutory independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I specifically asked whether the Government was planning to take any action to ensure that if companies can get away with this under the rules, these rules should be changed. I ask the Minister: is he seriously saying that, no matter what the substance of matters raised in the Senate may be, they do not become matters of significance unless they are raised in the House of Representatives? Or is the Minister saying that even though he represents the Attorney-General in this chamber, he is incapable of and incompetent in responding to questions relating to his portfolio?
—Sewer rat.

—I believe that the electors of Tasmania will soon make a judgment as to my competence and I prefer to rest on their judgment than Senator Baume's in that respect. I believe that Senator Baume, even in asking the question, prejudges a qualitative assessment in relation to the law applying to certain matters which he brings forward to the attention of the Senate. I do not believe that I can answer in terms which would reinforce the pre-judgment contained in the premise to his question, and therefore I believe that the matter ought to be left in the hands of the independent statutory authority—the Australian Securities Commission.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. A bit earlier Senator Faulkner called my colleague a `sewer rat'. Surely, that is unparliamentary and he should withdraw it.
—I do withdraw.
—Order! Senator Faulkner has withdrawn. There have been two or three unparliamentary remarks today which I have ignored, and I would ask all honourable senators not to use them.
—Except for me.
—Senator Macdonald, I ignored your first one.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is particularly disorderly to persist in a campaign of action which involves that kind of personal denigration across the chamber. Mr President, as I pointed out to you yesterday, there is a pattern of that kind of personal abuse which is not adequately dealt with by withdrawal. I ask you to take action on that score.

—Mr President, may I speak on that point of order. In light of your previous ruling, Senator Baume should not speak about Senator Faulkner in that way because I think you have already adequately dealt with it.
—Yes, I asked for a withdrawal and I received a withdrawal.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I refer to the annual report of the Textiles, Clothing and Footwear Development Authority for 1991-92 which was tabled in the chamber yesterday. In light of that report, is the Minister able to comment on progress being made by Australia's TCF industries? In particular, can the Minister inform the Senate of the investment in these industries and prospects for the future; and what role has the policy of the Federal Government played in the restructuring of the TCF sector?

—This industry has had difficulties and has been at the eye of the storm in industry restructuring in Australia. But the report of the TCFDA, which was tabled in the Senate yesterday, gives grounds for renewed confidence in the future of the TCF industries and the belief that they can and will be successful in Australia.

PARA.TAB: In the financial year 1991-92 a total of $220m was invested in the industries and total profits were $276m. For the most part, these industries have put behind the sterile debate about the level of tariff and other protection—although Senator Spindler is still raising that issue from time to time. Throughout the country, TCF companies are getting on with the work needed to ensure the future of their businesses. They realise that future will depend on international competitiveness, not tariffs.

In the past 20 years the international marketplace for TCF products has been transformed by the emergence of powerful new industries in the Asia-Pacific region. Fierce competition from countries in this region has been the inducement to improve competitiveness.

Employment levels in the TCF industries have fallen, but the major decline in TCF employment predates the announcement of an accelerated tariff phasedown in March 1991. TCF employment largely fell while the level of protection was steady and high. The TCFDA annual report says that employment in the industry fell 2 per cent in 1991-92 compared with 11 per cent in the previous year.

It is clear from the report that the restructuring, particularly of the textile industry, is well under way. Government policies have played an important part in this. The annual report takes nine pages to list the companies which have received support. That is because the Government has devoted $160m in direct funding to assist restructuring in these industries. The import credit scheme is in addition to that. So it is time that people who talk down the future of the industries in this country stop; it is a hangover from a previous debate. I am very optimistic about the future of the successful restructured TCF industries in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the Minister able to advise the Senate of progress being made by the TCF industries so far as Australian export markets are concerned and the impact of Government policy in that regard?

—Previously, these industries have never been major exporters from Australia. That is in contradistinction, for example, to the equivalent industries in Europe which are major exporters and also significant importers. Clothing and footwear exports have increased by over 280 per cent since 1986-87, although that has been from a low base, as I have pointed out. Total TCF exports in 1991-92 were $418m, up nearly $100m from the year before.

PARA.TAB: The Government supports these exports through an import credit scheme. The report which Senator Loosley referred to in his question recalls that exports of nearly $228m were assisted by that scheme in the first year of its operation and that 95 companies were supported in this way. This is the sort of restructuring proposal for an industry that is totally rejected by the ideologues of the Opposition. Their ideas come out of a hired think-tank and not from the members themselves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to his answer to my question on 3 November 1992 regarding the appointment of Mr Trevor Boucher as the Australian Ambassador to the OECD and the Minister's undertaking to supply the Senate with the terms and conditions of Mr Boucher's appointment. In view of the fact that Mr Boucher is currently paid around $120,000 per annum plus perks, will the Minister now supply the Senate with the documentation and inform us of the value of Mr Boucher's salary and living allowance as OECD Ambassador and the extent to which this package exceeds the current Ambassador's salary of $81,954 and overseas living allowance of $51,000?
—I ask Senator Bishop to put that question on notice.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question.
—How can you ask a supplementary?
—Because, very simply, the supplementary relates to the original question and more information I require.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. On some occasions you have ruled a supplementary question allowable on the basis of a very brief answer and then the putting of it on notice. But in this case, when there was no answer, I put it to you that there can be no supplementary, especially not a typed one that is about to be read.

—The supplementary question is supposed to elucidate information resulting from the original answer. The Minister has asked Senator Bishop to put the whole question on notice. I find it difficult to find a supplementary question.

—Mr President, on the point of order: the practice has been to allow this move. The Minister has already given an undertaking, on 3 November, to supply the documentation. He has not done so, but I am sure you will be interested to know that somebody from within his Department has. I want to know what the Minister has to hide and why we cannot have it on the record, now that Mr Boucher is resigning from the Public Service, taking his superannuation entitlements and double dipping with his new appointment. I would like some information on those questions.

—Order! I do not know how many Question Times we have left. I wish today was the last. However, that was not a point of order; it was a supplementary question. In order to keep the Senate running, I will allow Senator Evans to answer it if he wishes.

—Mr President, the information on this matter is entirely and legitimately within the public domain. When it is available, it will be made available. I have asked Senator Bishop to put the question on notice. I am not going to take it on notice. She can write it down and put it on notice. When I get it, I will respond to it in the ordinary way. She can wait for the answer.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to Telecom's obligation to provide Optus with grid connections at prices below Telecom's cost. Can the Minister assure the Senate that the Federal Government has not made a decision to sell Telecom or, alternatively, that the Government is not pursuing a strategy of preparing Telecom for such a sale? What measures can be taken to prevent Telecom from sliding into a serious loss position as Optus increases its market share? Is the Minister prepared to take such action to put Telecom on a sound footing to avoid any temptation the Government might feel to put it up for sale, which could mean foreign interests getting yet another foothold in Australia's telecommunications industry?

—I can certainly give Senator Spindler those assurances. The Government has absolutely no intention of selling Telecom. It remains committed to the 100 per cent ownership of AOTC. I will provide some little detail, but I have to say that the best way of ensuring that AOTC does not slide into a non-profit situation against the competition from Optus—I know that AOTC is committed to this course—is for AOTC to provide the aggressive, successful, competitive service against Optus that it intends to provide. That will be the best guarantee that it will continue to be the successful company that it now is.

PARA.TAB: The Government established AOTC on a firm commercial basis to ensure that it is in a position to provide that kind of competition and to compete on an equal footing with the second telecommunications carrier and in the international telecommunications marketplace. In establishing AOTC the Government decided last year to convert $2 billion in Commonwealth loans to equity over five years. In providing the additional capital, the Government believes that AOTC will become a world class telecommunications carrier capable of delivering services of the best international standard to consumers and providing taxpayers with a commercial rate of return on their investment in AOTC through dividend payments to the Federal Government.

In the public statement issued in 1991, Mr Beazley indicated that AOTC would not be expected to supply any inter-connection facilities at charges less than cost to them. In addition, the Government has ensured that initial incremental charges for Optus to access the AOTC network have market share triggers to indicate when these charges may be commercially negotiated. We expect that to happen some time next year.

These principles are set out in the Ministerial (Inter-connection and Related Charging Principles) Determination of November 1991. For example, initial charges for all domestic traffic can be renegotiated once Optus has gained 20 per cent of the total minutes of domestic traffic within Australia. This will ensure that the revenue that AOTC derives from providing inter-connection will increase as the Optus market share increases.
As stated, the Government has no intention of selling AOTC and in fact has done all that it can to ensure that the company is well positioned to be fully competitive in the marketplace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. A facsimile message from our Austrade representative in Copenhagen to Canberra dated 22 November 1990 stated that he expected the arrival in Denmark soon thereafter of representatives of the proposed Australian partners in the Danpork pig joint venture. As the same message indicated that the Danes had resolved all outstanding technical issues, principally quarantine issues, related to the project, can the Minister indicate who it was who arrived in Denmark and what they said to our Austrade representative regarding these matters? As AQIS has previously said that it knew nothing of this situation, what was the basis of the comments made by Mr Hansen to our Austrade representative and will the Minister now do as I requested last week, that is, make available to the Parliament all the relevant material on the files of the Department and Austrade?

—As to the last part of the question, I am having those papers examined to see what is appropriate consistent with the principles that govern these matters to put on the public record, including commercial confidentiality and so on. I hope to be in a position to give a response on that tomorrow. I may be in a position by then to give the honourable senator a response on the first part of his question as well. I am not in such a position today.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I assume that is an undertaking from the Minister that we will get an answer tomorrow, because tomorrow is the last scheduled sitting date of this session. Obviously, if the material is to be made available to Parliament, it must be made available when Parliament is sitting. That is axiomatic and any attempt to hide that will be unacceptable. If the Minister is not willing to table the material tomorrow, will he give an undertaking to make it available to the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, because it is within his portfolio and would not breach commercial confidentiality in doing so?
—Senator O'Chee can assume what he likes, but I have nothing to add to what I said in my first response.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is the Minister aware of reported changes to the New South Wales hospital services as a result of the agreement reached between the New South Wales and Commonwealth governments concerning the handover of the Repatriation General Hospital at Concord? Will the health care needs of veterans be properly catered for under the new arrangements and what has been the response by veterans' organisations to the handover of the hospital at Concord?

—There was a ceremony at Concord yesterday attended by the New South Wales Minister for Health, the Hon. Ron Phillips, who described the particular arrangements reached as `a once in a lifetime opportunity to create a new network of hospitals to service Sydney's western suburbs', and indeed it is. Included in the State's planning is the construction of two new hospitals, the largest hospital development ever undertaken in Australia, which will create about 1,200 construction jobs. One can see that it is very good news from many points of view in New South Wales.

PARA.TAB: Concord has a very special place in the hearts of veterans, symbolising not only their service to Australia but also the nation's debt to them. In his speech at the ceremony, Ben Humphreys, the Federal Minister for Veterans' Affairs, said that integration of RGH Concord would bring better options for local treatment for more than 120,000 entitled veterans and war widows in New South Wales.

The repatriation private patients scheme will come into operation from day one, 1 July 1993, so that improved health care arrangements will be available to those entitled veterans and war widows. We know from our research that the overwhelming majority of veterans want better options for local hospital treatment close to their friends and families. That is certainly the pattern of expectation and hope right around Australia.

Integration is a very positive outcome for the hospital and its staff, for the veteran community and for the people of New South Wales. Senator West asked about the role of the returned services organisations. I know that Mr Wal Newington, the State President of the Returned Services League in New South Wales, has certainly supported integration and spoken well of the repatriation private patients scheme. Veterans' organisations welcome the move. Mr Newington said that these good arrangements had been a long time coming.

Along with organisations such as the War Widows Guild, Legacy, the Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council, TPIs, the New South Wales Returned Services League have shown the way to the rest of Australia. Senator Newman will agree that Tasmania showed the way for the rest of Australia in this regard; integration has already happened there. Monitoring committees at both State and national levels will be in place to guard the interests of the ex-service community in the years ahead.

I believe that this is a most important and very welcome move by both governments. I certainly commend Mr Humphreys, the Federal Minister for Veterans' Affairs, who has pursued this matter doggedly, with determination but with a real practical sense of the need to make sure that the scheme does satisfy the real needs of veterans in their hospital and medical care and fulfils Australia's great debt to those veterans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Fiji, led by the Hon. Dr Kurisaqila. On behalf of honourable senators, I take great pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and I trust your visit both to the Senate and to Australia will be informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support aware of the growing complaints of industry about the stalled micro-reform process, as expressed in the Industry Commission's annual report? It states:

QUESTION.PARA: In some areas reform has produced productivity gains but gains do not seem to have passed on to users. Shipping is a frequently cited example.
The retention of cabotage is a restriction on further competition that should be addressed.

Can Australian business look forward to an end to what yesterday's Australian Financial Review calls `the high cost of cabotage', or is shipping what the Prime Minister referred to when he said on 2 December `the big agenda of the mid-80s is largely behind us', and on Lateline when he said that micro-reform was `mostly completed' and `what else do you want me to do?'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Cabinet deliberations on shipping reform will remain confidential; I will not comment on the media speculation about them. Shipping reform in Australia is widely perceived as a model of non-confrontationist, non-divisive reform which has achieved significant gains and improvement for Australian ship users. Just the other day an international shipper was in my office and said, `In the old days before you effected this reform, we could be absolutely sure when our ships would arrive in Australia—we couldn't be sure when they would depart. Now we can be sure of both. Thank you very much, government, for enabling that reform to occur'.

PARA.TAB: As a consequence of our reform, the average crew has been reduced by 25 per cent, from 28 on average to under 21 crew members, thereby matching the level of OECD ships visiting Australia; new ships are now being introduced with crews of 17, compared to 21 three years ago; increased labour productivity over the life of the program will result in long term savings of $50m per annum to the industry; retraining has been provided to more than 1,900 seafarers to facilitate crew reductions through multi-skilling; and industrial disputation has fallen, with only 70 ship days lost in 1992, compared to 1,593 ship days lost in the last year of the coalition government.

The Government's reform program has meant that investors in the industry have been encouraged, and they have invested nearly $2 billion in the launching of 31 more new, modern ships for Australia, with another five on order. That is a mark of the confidence that industry has had in the cooperative and harmonious reform climate we have created on the Australian coast.

In terms of cabotage, the coalition leaves me aghast. What does it want on the Australian coast? Does it want a rust bucket crewed by Asian crews living on a grain of rice a day and a kick up the backside to keep them interested? Is that what the Opposition wants? The Australian industry is a highly trained, highly skilled and highly efficient industry that delivers a very good service that is valued by its users.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Industry Commission recognises the reforms that have taken place but also recognises that the savings have not been passed on to exporters. My supplementary question is: is the Government's excuse for not taking away cabotage that we want to single-handedly solve the problem of the world's dilapidated shipping fleet, at great cost to our exporters and particularly exporters from Western Australia; or is it that Senator Cook does not want to cause any problems with his union mates prior to the next election? What is the reason?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it would be the case that today Senator Campbell would try to work into a question some reference to my alleged union mates. It may escape the notice of the Opposition that this Government acts on principle to bring about reforms in the best interests of the nation without regard to the particular interests of any group, and that concerns some of those people who argue about things that Senator Campbell has just argued about.

PARA.TAB: I said at the beginning of my answer that I will not comment on confidential deliberations of Cabinet. They will be announced in due course. The honourable senator will have to sit quietly and wait for us to do so and respond, if he chooses, then.

As Senator Collins pointed out in a number of interjections, the Industry Commission report should be read in full and not selectively. If it is, and if it is not used as some sort of selective stick to beat us with but rather as a comprehensive understanding of reform, I do not think Senator Campbell will find very much support at all for his contentions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to claims by the shadow Minister for arts and heritage, Senator Michael Baume, that grants to the film industry would be heavily cut under a coalition government in favour of a system of tax incentives for private investors? Has the Government any plans to implement such changes? Secondly, based on previous experience with film financing under division 10BA of the taxation Act, what would be the likely net effect on government outlays of the proposed reductions in grants when offset against the loss in revenue resulting from the tax incentives? What would be the likely effect on the quality of film production and the level of Australian involvement in such production?

—I am aware of those statements because they were enunciated by the shadow Minister recently at a conference of the Screen Production Association, where they went down like a lead balloon, not surprisingly. The Government has no plans whatever to implement this appalling policy proposal. The current film support arrangements were developed following extensive consultation with the film industry, and they resulted in a stable industry at a lower cost to government than previous schemes but without diminishing the quality of Australian films. The 10BA scheme, established in 1981, resulted in a blow-out in the cost to revenue and rortings by some investors. There is no doubt that that occurred. A return to such a tax driven scheme is highly likely to result in the same problems, and Senator Baume knows it.

PARA.TAB: The current system of the Government provides primary support for film production through investment in the Film Finance Corporation. The system has resulted in increased involvement by active investors, which is essential for the development of market skills in the Australian production sector and long term viability. The Government's financial commitment to this very important industry is substantial. Funding for the Film Finance Corporation is $61.9m in this financial year with funding committed until 1995-96.

This financial commitment, the increased active involvement of the private sector and the Corporation's earnings from the films in which it invests are factors which are contributing to stable production levels and a healthy domestic film industry. The need for stability was emphasised at the recent Screen Production Association conference which I addressed and, as I said, where Senator Baume's proposals went down like a lead balloon.

The facts are that the Opposition—and this is in the Fightback document—plans to slash $27m from government support for film and $42m overall from the arts portfolio. Senator Baume does understand that this tax proposal will not work. It is a very thin attempt indeed to hide the fact that Fightback currently proposes to emasculate funding for the film industry and for arts generally.

If, on Friday, this turns out to be another bundle that Dr Hewson has dropped, no-one will believe it. Everyone knows that the Opposition is committed to these levels of funding. If anyone is foolish enough to believe the Opposition, he or she will find out after the election—should the Opposition be elected—when it goes back to this scheme. Senator Baume knows that these proposals will not work and his attempt to disguise this funding cut by going back to a failed scheme has impressed no-one.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Joint House Department: Public Liability Claim

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, my question is directed to you. I refer you to the annual report of the Joint House Department which, of course, you signed and, in particular, to a payment of a public liability settlement of $65,000. I ask you: was that payment made to a member of the House of Representatives?
—Yes, I am aware that a payment was made. I will seek the information which you ask me for and I will give you an answer as quickly as possible—hopefully by the end of Question Time.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am somewhat surprised, seeing you are a signatory to the report. I presume you therefore know to whom it was paid. As you have, in effect, indicated that you do, I ask specifically: was the payment made to the Speaker of the House of Representatives? Was the claim for falling off his bicycle in the parliamentary precinct? Did you approve the payment? As you and the Speaker are jointly responsible for this Department, did somebody represent the Speaker in approving the payment? What were the grounds of the claim?

—I am aware that a payment was made to the Speaker. I believe he took action himself. I did not approve this. I believe this was a legal case which the Speaker took against the Joint House Department. The reason I said I would give Senator Hill an answer later is that I am not sure whether that was the only claim. But there was a claim that concerned the Speaker. As to the rest of the questions you asked me, I will check and give you an answer as quickly as possible.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the lodging of a log of claims by the CFMEU to establish an award on over 1,500 building companies which engage independent contractors. This proposed award is designed to bring independent contractors in the building and construction industry under award conditions. The claim includes: increases in real wages of 5 per cent a year over and above productivity improvements; a 30-hour working week to be cut by 5 per cent per year; weekend work at quadruple time and a half; eight weeks annual leave; 30 public holidays a year; and that every employee shall be required to become and remain a financial member of the union. In view of the fact that the Minister stated the legislation was introduced to stop sham contracts, will the Government be amending the legislation to stop such outrageous claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is based on a false premise and because it is, it is really a false question, not related to any truthful matter. So it is a question that could be rightfully ignored by the Government and not answered. However, I wish to quote—

—On a point of order, Mr President: recently in this place you made a ruling about people telling the truth. Senator Cook has already stated in his answer that this question is not related to anything truthful. He should be asked to withdraw that. What I have said is truthful. In fact, I have here a legitimate log of claims that has been placed before the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.
—I certainly do not think that Senator Cook implied that Senator Crane was telling a lie.

—Thank you, Mr President. By way of preface to my answer, I am about to prove the truth of what I said. I have in front of me a facsimile message from a Mr Glenn Simpson, Director of Industrial Relations of the Master Builders Construction and Housing Association in Canberra, to `All IR Managers'. This circular is relevant to the question asked by Senator Crane. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: I have also been made aware of a new development in HIA's misinformation campaign over independent contractors.
I interpolate: the same misinformation contained in this question. The circular goes on:
The CFMEU is currently engaged in roping in various small builders as respondents to the NBCIA Award. HIA is representing this as a new claim using s.127A of the Act to unionise subcontractors—
which is of course completely untrue.

That is the Master Builders Association, an employer organisation in competition with the HIA. What does it say of the same allegation contained in the question? `Which is of course completely untrue'. Let me go on with the quote:

It is no more what the unions have done for very many years to extend coverage of an existing Award by adding eligible parties. It is interesting that on the terms of the HIA's own letter, the Log of Claims which the HIA refers to was served on 17 July 1992 before the new independent contractor provisions came into operation.

That is what an employer organisation says of the HIA allegations which are the foundation of Senator Crane's question and the reason why I say his question is based on a false premise and is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. This log of claims, which obviously was prepared prior to this legislation becoming law and in anticipation of its becoming law, makes it quite clear in the second point that in fact it is to cover independent contractors, and it is being done under section 195(1A) of the legislation which the Minister introduced into this place. When I asked the Minister whether he intends introducing legislation to force contractors to operate within the award system, he said no. Why did the Minister mislead this chamber by giving that answer at that time?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It takes a lot of gall to accuse me of misleading when I have produced independent evidence from an employer organisation—not a fan of this Government—that the allegations made a moment ago are wrong. It takes supreme gall to be able then to try to pretend that that is somehow my fault.

PARA.TAB: We introduced legislation so that people who are exploited as independent contractors and unfairly dealt with can get redress and be properly dealt with. If building people are unfairly and improperly dealt with in a harsh and unfair way, they ought to have that avenue. I do not believe that the legislation we introduced applies to the building industry. Nonetheless, the HIA has persisted in this campaign not because it is true but because it wants to make a political point against the Government. The HIA is masquerading as a political party, not as an industry organisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Beahan this day, relating to the funding of the Australian film industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard some fairly disgraceful responses to nonsensical questions in the past during Question Time, but this was one of the most appallingly bad responses we have ever heard, in terms both of its integrity and the facts on which it was based. The fact is that this Government is reducing grants to the Film Finance Corporation from last year's $68m to $50m—a reduction of $18m—by 1995-96. That $18m cut was not referred to by the Minister in his disgraceful response. Yet he made great play of the fact that in our term in office we would reduce it by $2m more, by $20m. What a disgraceful response from this Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-seven.

—The Minister seeks to correct himself. The cut that we talked about was $20m from last year's level. The Minister knows what Fightback says, so I can only assume that his interjection was based on a deliberate purpose to mislead. We have a situation where both parties are of the view that there is an excessive dependence on grants in the film industry for a very good reason, and that is that $100 of grant to the film industry results in only $100 getting to the film industry. However, $100 of tax benefit, of tax deduction, for private investors brings $250 to the film industry because it gears up private sector contributions. Both parties agree, despite the fact that the Minister comes in here and masquerades as some kind of phoney defender of films when he is, in fact, a party to a continuing reduction in the grant money being made available to the film industry.

PARA.TAB: Aside from that phoney masquerade, let us see what the reality is. Under our policies, the reduction in grants will be replaced—and, one would hope, massively overwhelmed—by a major increase in private sector funding by providing assistance more by way of tax deduction than by way of grant. We can see what has happened under this Government to tax deductions. On top of this Government chopping grants to the industry, it has also massively reduced the amount of money it is making available by way of tax deduction. In 1987-88, tax relief totalling $131m was made available to private sector contributors to the film industry. By last year this had fallen by two-thirds, to only $43m. So, on both scores, the Government is cutting the grants and reducing the amount of money available by way of tax deduction, providing no incentives whatsoever.

On the other hand, the coalition would have the same order of grants cuts as the Government, but basically would be seeking to replace that money by significant changes in the way people can get tax deductions for investing in the film industry. Under us there will be a big increase in total funding available to film. Under this Government, the amount has been falling dramatically and consistently, both by way of reduction of grant and by way of reduction of tax incentives available for people to invest in the film industry. The Minister's answer was an absolute disgrace in the way he misrepresented the impact of this Government in cutting film funding.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is not even going to respond.
—I have been asked not to.
—You're a disgrace.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is to ask Senator Baume if he would withdraw that imputation against me.
—That is not a point of order.
—Of course it is a point of order. I found it offensive and I ask him to withdraw it.
—Senator Baume, it is unparliamentary to call another senator a disgrace. I ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw it. I just await the Minister's response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to the appointment of Australia's Ambassador to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

SPEECH.PARA: At Question Time the Minister said that I should place the request for information on the Notice Paper. I find that a quaint answer indeed because, in effect, that request for information has been on the Notice Paper since 3 November 1992, when I asked Senator Evans a question in the following terms:
I simply ask whether Senator Evans will supply the Senate with the precise dates on which those conversations took place—

between him and Mr Dawkins. I also asked whether the Minister would table any written correspondence in the Senate concerning the appointments of Mr Boucher and the withdrawal of Mr Borthwick from Paris. I further stated:

I would like to see the terms and conditions of the appointments of Mr Borthwick and Mr Boucher, including the relative salaries and perks that go with them. I also ask the Minister to advise me and to advise the Senate what previous offers were made to Mr Borthwick prior to the one that was tantamount to a recall.
On that occasion, Senator Evans said:
There are no terms yet identified for Mr Boucher's appointment because that appointment has not yet been made, but I will be happy to make that available at the appropriate time.
In answer to my main question, Senator Evans said earlier that Mr Boucher was someone in whom he personally had absolute confidence. The Minister also said:
The formal recommendation has not yet gone to the Governor-General. It will in a matter of days.

But certainly he had made the decision and he would be making the recommendation. In other words, on 3 November, the Minister told the Senate that he would make the recommendation in a number of days and that he would make the information `available at the appropriate time' which, of course, would follow the making of the recommendation. Either he misled the Senate on 3 November, he is outside the 30 day rule, or today he is simply treating the Senate with arrogance and contempt, as he normally does.

PARA.TAB: I would also refer the Minister to the letters signed by Mr Dawkins to him, dated 15 October and 18 September respectively. In those letters, Mr Dawkins told Senator Evans that Mr Borthwick would be returning early from Paris and then he advised the Minister that he was intending to recommend that Mr Boucher be appointed to that position. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Consistent with the arrangements for rotating appointments to the OECD position, I record my understanding that your Department will be called on to nominate a successor to Mr Boucher.

Yet on 3 November the Minister said, `I have not done it yet'. So he had a cosy deal, and Mr Boucher had announced to his own staff that he would be taking leave from the Public Service and that that leave would require a determination from the Minister. I would also like to see that too because Mr Boucher does not go to Paris until February. I would like to know why, Mr Acting Deputy President, and I would like you to rule as to why the Minister has not supplied this information when he gave that undertaking more than one month ago. What has he got to hide?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not a matter for ruling from the Chair. You have made your speech and request to the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I agree entirely that these are not matters for you or the President; they are entirely matters for the ordinary parliamentary process. It is an entirely apt part of parliamentary process for the Minister, who believes that it is appropriate for a question to be put on notice, to ask for that to occur. I did say that on this occasion and I have nothing to apologise for.
—Has the appointment been made?

—Senator Bishop will get her answer in due course. The formal processes associated with this appointment, including the detailed settling of terms and conditions, have not yet been completed. When those processes are complete—
—You told the Senate a month ago `in days'.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Teague)—Order! There are too many interjections.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some of the processes are complete. The nomination has gone forward to the Executive Council. But the terms and conditions are not settled at that stage; they are settled later. Senator Bishop is just demonstrating that endemic ignorance which has become, along with her intransigence and offensiveness, part of the make-up that she brings to this chamber. If she puts that question on notice, in the way that I asked her to do, she will get her answer as soon as it is appropriate for me to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to the position of independent contractors in the industrial relations system.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a few brief comments about the answer that I was given today by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). The Minister claimed that my question was based on a false premise. In fact, he said that it was an untruthful question. I want to make the point that it was not based on a false premise. It was based on what has happened to some 1,500 building companies which engage principally independent contractors and which many have never had a log of claims served on them before.

PARA.TAB: The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 received royal assent some eight to nine days prior to that log of claims being lodged. But that is totally irrelevant to what I was asking. The relevant point is that amendments made to that Act changed the definition of an employee so that it was possible for this log of claims to be lodged against building companies that engage independent contractors. That was the basis of my question.
I particularly want to refer Senator Cook to a quote from his second reading speech on the Contractors Bill. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Independent contractors will not be made into employees—
and clearly the changes in the Act do make them into employees—
and will not be subject to the award system generally. The new arrangements will operate only on a case by case basis, not on a general or class action basis.
In addition to that, in answer to another question I asked, which I have already referred to here today, the Minister gave a categorical `no' as to whether this legislation
will bring independent contractors under the award system.

PARA.TAB: The evidence is absolutely clear that under this legislation independent contractors will be in time brought into the award system. That was the basis of the question I asked today. I also made reference to the outrageous claims that were being made. If the Minister is to maintain the integrity of the statements in his second reading speech and the integrity of his answers to my questions, he has no option but to amend this legislation to stop what is happening. We should return to the original intent of the legislation, which the Minister said was to deal with sham contracts.

Of course, the most outrageous part of this log of claims is the order that is being sought from the Industrial Relations Commission to ensure that all people employed must be and continue to be financial members of the union.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
