TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I am flabbergasted. Try as I may to educate Senator Crane in what the Act really means, I find that he either is unable to understand a simple proposition or deliberately avoids understanding it. He put a proposition to me in a question; I responded by making an assertion that it was untrue and produced evidence to prove I was right. What has Senator Crane done? He has said I am wrong, and his way of establishing that is simply by asserting, and not proving a damn thing. In terms of the scales of logic here, I win, he loses; that is the outcome.

PARA.TAB: But let us go to some of the other facts that I did not have time to cover in a three-minute answer. Senator Crane has said—and I think I have him down correctly as a quote—`The evidence is absolutely clear that it is bringing these people into the award', or words to that effect. The evidence is not absolutely clear at all. There is no evidence to support that proposition because the claim that has been referred to was a log of claims on 23 July, as the Master Builders Association says, of its rival employer organisation, the HIA, before this legislation was in force. The log of claims of 23 July sought to cover exclusively conditions with employees. Read the log of claims. It refers to employees; it does not refer to contractors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Refer to 2(b).

—It does not refer to contractors; it refers to employees. It is what the technicians of industrial relations appearing before the Commission call, and in the parlance of arbitration is known as, `a roping-in application'. These are potential respondents to a Federal award who are not at the moment respondents, who are served by a claim to enable an arbitrator to decide, if the point is contested, whether or not they ought to be covered by an award. So there is no irrefutable evidence here of anything at all, except that in the view of this particular union those particular employers ought to be covered by an award in so far as their employees are concerned. It has nothing to do with their contractors, if they have any, but only with their employees.

PARA.TAB: It may be a union view that the employees of this company are entitled to be covered by an award, and that view may be right. But it has not been tested yet. The obvious response of the employers, if they disagree, will be to contest. It will go to arbitration and go through a process of hearing and determination to find out what is right. If the Commission errs at law, it will go through the courts system on appeal to make the law right.

Senator Crane has no evidence whatsoever to support his contention, which leads me to the next consideration: why in the absence of any evidence does he persist in making the assertions he does? One can be charitable and say he is mistaken—this is Thursday of the last week of sitting—
Opposition Senators—Wednesday!

TALK.START.PARA: —But because there is a pattern here, it would be unreasonable to say that he is simply mistaken. He wants to make a political point; he wants to smear these unions; he wants to kick the anti-union can; and he wants to try to score a few brownie points for himself in the National Farmers Federation or wherever else he thinks his constituency is. I say to Senator Crane: `Well, go for it, that's your right; but don't ever pretend that it's true, because it ain't'.

—I wish to contribute to this debate by saying that listening to Senator Cook shows absolutely conclusively how correct Senator Crane was. It is very obvious that Senator Crane is in possession of all of the facts. He has very skilfully put forward a very good case. Senator Cook has simply been unable to answer it and shows his incompetence. I think Senator Crane deserves congratulations for bringing this very important matter to the attention of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Baume this day, relating to the Prime Minister's investment in a piggery.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) said that this matter of the piggeries of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is not one of substance because it has not been raised in the House of Representatives, apparently justifying the failure of the Government to ever answer substantially any matters of substance that I raise here and to instead depend entirely and basically on personal abuse.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that this matter has been raised in the House of Representatives. Last month, Mr Bruce Lloyd made a detailed criticism of Mr Keating's piggeries' accounts. Mr Keating ducked the opportunity of responding to the detailed accusations made during that debate. I remind you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in the House of Representatives questions run for about 15 seconds and replies go on for a quarter of an hour. So it is appropriate that matters of this kind are raised in debate in the House of Representatives as there is some kind of equal time.

This matter was raised in the House of Representatives and the Prime Minister ducked it. He did not respond. Mr Crean responded in part to some of the matters that had been raised here by Senator Boswell and Senator O'Chee. But the fact is that the Prime Minister ducked responding because he has no response of substance. He has never responded, and a response has never been given in this place by the people who represent him.

The fact is that there was no media criticism of Mr Keating's refusal to respond. There is substance in the Prime Minister's piggery issue. There is a genuine scandal about companies getting away with filing incorrect company returns in breach of the ASC requirements. Nothing was done about correcting those breaches until I reported them to this Parliament and the Australian Securities Commission determined, on the basis of the information provided to this Parliament, to carry out an investigation and to require those companies to correct the returns that had those breaches in them.

There is substance to this matter. It seems to me extraordinary that, according to the view of the media, the substance does not matter but the particular theatre in which the substance is presented does. That is intellectual nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday they were saying the Canberra Times was the greatest paper ever.

—That is a pathetic attempt to develop in some instances a justification for the failure of the media of Australia, with the honourable exception of the Canberra Times and a couple of others which I must commend, to print the facts and the substance of this matter or to defend their failure to do so. However, the Canberra Times has not failed to detail it. (Time expired)

—I would also like to speak to this motion moved by Senator Baume. As a teenager, I watched the odd show on ABC television, one of which was Would You Believe. It was a show with six stars, one of whom was Senator Baume. The idea behind the show was to stand up and tell the biggest possible lie. Even in those days, Senator Baume was a professional liar.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I do not need Opposition senators to stand. Senator Faulkner, it is entirely unparliamentary to call anyone a liar. There has been so much discussion of that point by the President that it is most offensive for you to have made that remark. I ask you to withdraw completely.
—I withdraw, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Senator Faulkner is speaking to a motion to take note of an answer that was given. What he has raised in his contribution has had nothing to do with that answer.
—Oh, come off it!

—It has nothing to do with that answer. He had not even started to get near the subject matter of it. He was talking about something entirely different. Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to keep him to the subject matter.
—I uphold that point of order as well and ask Senator Faulkner to address his remarks to Senator Baume's motion.

—What we have seen in Question Time from Senator Baume is yet another example of Senator Baume doing Dr Hewson's dirty business in this chamber because he does not have the guts to do it in the House of Representatives. Senator Baume is just a stalking-horse for Dr Hewson on this matter and we all know it. We have Senator Bishop and Senator Baume consistently—

—I raise a point of order. The question that started this process concerned the accounts of the Prime Minister's company—or a company in which he has a half interest—and corrections in those accounts in recent times. This contributor to the debate is now speaking on entirely different issues, and that is out of order because it is not relating to the substance of the question or the answer that was given.

—Senator Hill, there is no point of order. Senator Faulkner is addressing the motion that the Senate take note of the answer Senator Tate gave in answer to Senator Baume's question about the Prime Minister and his interests—
—The piggery.
—In the piggery, as Senator Collins says. Senator Faulkner will address that motion.
—I was pointing out that Senator Baume in Question Time and Senator Bishop again in Question Time—both products of the New South Wales Liberal Party—

—I raise a point of order. We are taking note of an answer given in relation to a question asked by Senator Baume. I was not aware that the question related to anything I said at all. Mr Acting Deputy President, would you mind telling Senator Faulkner to relate his remarks to the question at issue.

—There is no point of order. I remind senators that we have in this half-hour period after Question Time the ability for a senator, with leave, to move to take note of any answer, and any other senator may rise and speak to that same motion. I call Senator Faulkner again.

—I was attempting to say that during Question Time we have seen consistently this behaviour—particularly from the New South Wales Liberal senators, Senator Baume and Senator Bishop—of the use of the Senate to smear and slander individuals on a basis that is completely without foundation.
—Rubbish!
—I have said before, and I stand by it, that Senator Baume is the arch slanderer and smearer of the Australian Senate.
—I have said it outside the chamber and you have not sued me. Just tell the truth.
—Order! Senator Faulkner, it is unparliamentary to use the words you have used, and I ask you to completely withdraw them.

—I withdraw them, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Baume, who continues on this absolutely pointless exercise of questions about the Prime Minister's business interests, is, along with a range of other coalition senators, a person who has consistently voted against and opposed the declaration of senators' interests, and that is an example of his gross hypocrisy on this issue. This pointless exercise that has done absolutely nothing else but completely ruin the reputation—

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht interjecting—
Senator Campbell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order, Senator Schacht and Senator Campbell! Senator Faulkner has the call.
—the reputation of—
—Senator Faulkner, I must ask you to resume your seat as your time for speaking has expired.
—In this debate I wish to—
—Order! The time allotted for taking note of answers given in Question Time has expired.

—by leave—I wish to make a personal explanation, as I claim to have been misrepresented. It has just been alleged, falsely, that in this place I voted against the declaration of interests of members and senators. If Senator Faulkner can provide me with evidence of that, I will be grateful, because I do not believe this matter has come before this chamber since I have been a member of it. It may well have, in which case I would be grateful if Senator Faulkner could provide me with that information. My objection has always been—and I have said so—to phoney declarations of interest where people do not declare their interest but hide behind a form of declaration of interest, just as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Independent Review of the Civil Aviation Authority's Tender Evaluation Process for the Australian Advanced Air Traffic System, chaired by the Hon. Ian Macphee, and seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The review was established in accordance with a direction I issued to the Civil Aviation Authority on 10 July 1992 under section 12 of the Civil Aviation Act 1988. It was prompted by concerns expressed inside and outside Parliament, including a recommendation by the Joint Standing Committee on Public Works. I thank Mr Macphee for a comprehensive report which canvasses in considerable detail the background to the proposed contract, the evaluation process and the review's assessment of the roles of key parties.

PARA.TAB: I note in particular that the review has sought to provide not only an assessment of the process to date but also practical recommendations for the future conduct of the evaluation. This reflects the review's expressed aim to see TAAATS proceed on the basis best suited to the needs of the CAA, the general public and the aviation industry. The review states that it seeks to restore the process to one of fairness between the tenderers.

The report endorses fully the strategic direction being followed by the CAA in the TAAATS project. However, it identifies defects in the process that has been followed. In his letter to me, Mr MacPhee has summarised his essential conclusions by stating:

SPEECH.PARA: .the original selection process was soundly based;
.the original selection process was departed from in a manner which was both unsound and unfair;
.the Authority Board was not properly and adequately informed of the results of the evaluation; and
.the responsibility for this lay squarely with the Chief Executive Officer, Mr Baldwin, and with the officer principally responsible for TAAATS, Dr Edwards.

Mr Macphee found many blemishes, some of which he describes as serious and unprofessional. The report raises serious questions about the competence of certain CAA executives. He identifies haste as the single most damaging factor, leading to a chain of imperfections.

PARA.TAB: The report states that the review found no reason to believe that there was any corruption in the process under examination. The reservations expressed by Mr Macphee about certain CAA executives go to issues of competence. The review recommends: the CAA revert to the original requests for registration of interest—that is, ROI—process and Thomson and Hughes be invited to enter specification development and precontract negotiations; and the proposed solutions of the finalists should include interim radar data processing, RDP, systems for both Sydney and Brisbane and should take account of Australian industry participation opportunities.

These recommendations appear to provide an appropriate and practical solution to the difficult situation that the CAA now faces in resuming the assessment process. It is my view that the CAA should make an early decision to adopt these recommendations.

I am forwarding a copy of the report to the board of the CAA now the report has been tabled. In my covering letter I have asked the board to meet with me in the next few days so that I may obtain, first hand, its initial reaction to the report, and to make clear my expectations for the further handling of these issues. In my letter, I am also asking the board for a written response to the report by 31 December this year. I will advise the Senate once I have received, and had an opportunity to consider, the board's response.

In seeking that response, I am asking that the board advise me not only of its views and proposed actions in relation to the recommendations and findings of the review, but also of its response to other matters which have been the subject of adverse comment in the report—in particular, action to be taken about adverse findings relating to certain CAA executives. The report's findings in relation to the two senior executives of action which amounts to `serious incompetence by each of them. . . ' clearly raise for the board's consideration what future role, if any, these officers should play in the TAAATS process.

As the board will not see this report until after its contents have become public through its tabling in the Parliament, they will not be in a position to respond immediately. Therefore, I do not believe I am in a position to form a final opinion on what I must do further until I have heard from the board on these disturbing findings.

The report also raises broader issues of government policy. These are, first, the relationship between government and its government business enterprises—GBEs—and, second, the question of Australian industry participation in contracts.

On the first of these two issues the report does not make any specific recommendations or call for any immediate response by the Government. However, the report raises issues about the nature of the accountability relationship, which the Government has been, and is, examining.

In relation to Australian industry participation, this is also a question the Government has been examining over the past few months. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, expects shortly to announce a major initiative concerning arrangements for the effective coordination of government purchasing and industry policy and the role that government business enterprises, such as the CAA, can play in the development of local suppliers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the report tabled by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Cook. We face an eternal problem in this place of being presented with too little time to pursue reports—in the case of this document around 100 pages of a highly technical argument and a highly complex legal and procedural argument. None of us has had the time to go through it line by line and ponder what is in it. With that proviso, the report's key points are very clear and they are as Senator Cook said.

PARA.TAB: The report is a devastating record of professional incompetence. It confirms my worst fears about the management of the Civil Aviation Authority. It is not correct to see this report in relation to only one matter; namely, the CAA's contract evaluation. It goes across the whole of the operations of the CAA and raises some very profound questions. What I have to say this afternoon is largely critical. I am sorry that Senator Cook is no longer here, but I must comment at the outset on Senator Cook's place in relation to this report.

He inherited this mess in the middle of the year. He has discharged his duties as Minister in an impeccable and laudable manner, showing great integrity and promptness in dealing with this issue. The integrity is most important but, in dealing with a matter of this nature, the readiness to get on with the task and redress what might be wrong is equally important. I believe that Senator Cook deserves great praise for his actions in relation to this report. He inherited a situation that was not of his making. He is a person of not much aviation background or knowledge, and very little background, I would imagine, in a technical sense. But he stands out as a shining example of what a Minister should do in these circumstances. He has proved the old adage which those of us in politics sometimes recognise it takes a great act of faith to honour or to understand; that is, that virtue brings its own reward.

To set the report in context, this was an inquiry into a very expensive new nationwide air traffic control system. I have always been interested in aviation. I have had grave concerns in recent years about the operation of the Civil Aviation Authority in general, and the way we embarked on a new system without any in-depth analysis and without cost-benefit analyses—we just had a system imposed on us de novo, at great expense—aroused my interest. The first public announcement that the Australian companies would be denied the right to tender as prime contractors in that process further heightened my interest.

The world of Australian aviation is relatively small and once I took a public position a lot of people came and talked to me. So I have followed this program through. It was a program that struck me as being highly irregular from the outset. Over the last 30 years in this country we have set in place certain procedures to guarantee that the selection of major contracts is on a basis that preserves the integrity of the selection process. It does not guarantee in any way at all that we always get the right result. But in the past we have always been free of the charge that there was something funny about the way the decision was arrived at to benefit one or other of the tenderers.

In this case a highly irregular selection procedure was adopted by the Civil Aviation Authority. I emphasise that that in itself is not a criticism or an indication that there would be a wrong result or that corruption may be involved. But it is an indication that there is an obligation placed on the people adopting that system to be quite transparent about the way they arrived at the decision, because the Government and statutory authorities are vested by this Parliament with the right to raise taxes, and the right to raise taxes carries with it a concomitant obligation to explain and account for how those funds are spent. That obligation of accountability is something that the Civil Aviation Authority never measured up to and never met at any time through this extraordinary saga of events.

The concerns about the process were not based on party lines; they were bipartisan. All parties within this Parliament and both Houses of the Parliament—both the House of Representatives and the Senate—were concerned about the selection process. I would like to particularly mention the Public Works Committee because the Chairman and the members of that Committee without exception faithfully discharged their responsibilities under the Act in relation to the expenditure of public funds.

One of the ironies of this situation is that, had the Civil Aviation Authority been one bit more intelligent, had it recognised that what we were telling it was its obligation under law, and had it answered the questions, this inquiry would never have been set up. These people would never have been exposed for the incompetent people they were, because neither the members of the Parliament nor the Public Works Committee would have gone behind the evidence, had it been freely given to them. So there is a very ironic twist to the situation we have today.

My primary concern in this matter was the matter of accountability, as I have said. The Civil Aviation Authority absolutely failed to account for its actions when it was called upon by properly constituted authorities to do so. In fact, in my time in the Parliament I have never met people like Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards who blatantly and obstinately refused to cooperate with the demands of the Parliament—and they deserve everything that is coming to them.

The synopsis of the report has been given by Senator Cook and I do not wish to go into that in much detail. I make the general observation that the text is restrained; it is undemonstrative; it is under-stated. It reflects the great tact and courtesy of its author, Mr Macphee. Any person taking time to read the report must read between the lines, because there is a great degree of under-statement. I have not had time to reflect fully on the final chapter of the book which goes into the procedures of the board, but clearly there is a mine of information there for quiet reflection.

What does emerge is the fact that we had a wilful—and I use that word in a literal sense—chief executive officer in Mr Baldwin who, along with his faithful lieutenant or lap-dog, Dr Edwards, rode roughshod over what was a weak and compliant board in the Civil Aviation Authority. The report is redolent with examples of sloppy business practices adopted by the board. I will quote some examples of that. The report states on page 62:

SPEECH.PARA: Despite the vital nature of this Management Evaluation Team meeting, as the basis of what was intended to be the Board's decision on the preferred bidder for TAAATS, the "minutes" of that meeting were not written until three months after the meeting when two worried directors, Messrs Mant and Ayres requested copies of these and other documents which were relied upon by management in making its recommendations.
Mr Butcher and his Board were completely unaware of the fact that they received crucial advice from a meeting for which minutes did not exist.

It goes on and on. There is evidence in the report of clear bias by Mr Baldwin—a man with no technical education at all; a man with very limited managerial experience running a big operation in the Civil Aviation Authority; a man whose sole claim to fame was the fact that he was a real estate agent in a small New Zealand town, with a chequered career in that town.

PARA.TAB: I turn to pages 53 and 85, and deal with the matter of bias. One of the themes that emerges is that the board was not fully advised all the time. The advice it got was biased towards one of the two contenders all the way. The board was known to be sensitive to risks and delays in major electronic contracts. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Board's past experiences had predisposed them to being extremely concerned about development risk and potential time delays. It is difficult to imagine how Mr Baldwin, as a Board member, could not have realised the arresting effect this proviso would have on the other directors. Executive Management and Mr Baldwin highlighted the risks associated with Hughes despite the fact that the operational and technical evaluations had taken account of risk and Hughes had still been evaluated as the top bidder.
It goes on and on, leading to the conclusions of the report. Page 88 states:
Under no test of fair play or professional competence could the methods of inquiry or the quality of the conclusions during the post-December 1991 phase be regarded as being adequate.
Page 90 states:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The advice to the Board by Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards was fatally flawed. It was inadequately researched and tested. Hughes were not assessed fairly.

SPEECH.PARA: The inquiry makes the point that it did not explore criminality at all. It did not explore, in any detail, the abundant evidence that bias existed in the selection process. It rested its case on the fact that there was a mountain of evidence of gross professional incompetence in the selection process and, indeed, that is enough to damn the process irrevocably.

PARA.TAB: I have no quarrel with the recommendations of the report; I think they are fair and reasonable given all the circumstances. I can see that Siemens Plessey has grounds to feel aggrieved. It was technically competent, able to perform the contract in time and, by all accounts, it was by far and away the lowest tenderer. In the same category, Raytheon could well feel that it has been disadvantaged in being debarred initially from being a contractor.

So much for what is in the report. Where do we go from here? The first thing that must happen is that the two principal officers named, Messrs Baldwin and Edwards, should be fired by the board. They should not be given the luxury of tendering their resignations. The report really delineates the inadequacies in the selection process and fully substantiates them. It leaves it broadly to the board to correct those deficiencies and, indeed, that is the burden of the tabling statement made by the Minister a few moments ago. In dealing with the response he expects from the board, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In seeking that response, I am asking that the board not only advise me of their views and proposed actions in relation to the recommendations and findings of the review, but also their response to other matters which have been the subject of adverse comment in the report . . .
So it is really up to the board to take the requisite action.

PARA.TAB: I offer the advice to the Minister that if the board does not act promptly and demand the resignation of those two officers, the Minister should dismiss the board. In any case, the position of the Chairman and the Deputy Chairman of the CAA is totally untenable and intolerable. They cannot remain in that position and they must go. I suspect that the majority of the board members also should fall on their swords and depart public life. It is not clear from the report whether all the members acted negligently. Clearly, there is reference to two board members who questioned some of the inadequate procedures that were in place, but the majority of the board members failed to exercise the responsibilities that are vested in them under law.

There is not only one incident of incompetence on the part of the board in this tender selection process. There have been three cases in the last few years of a prima facie conflict of interest where members of the CAA board have had commercial negotiations with the Civil Aviation Authority—something that is absolutely intolerable. The board has shown no insight at all into the seriousness of these charges.

I put on the record that one of the members of that board, Mr Yates, sat next to one of the best known members of the Australian Parliament on an aircraft flight in Australia. Mr Yates recognised the parliamentarian. The parliamentarian did not recognise Mr Yates. Mr Yates engaged the parliamentarian in conversation and immediately moved to a massive attack on me and the place I have had in setting up this report. He accused me of involving the civil aviation industry in the expenditure of millions of dollars—absolutely nonsensical. Then we had the way the board underwrote the pursuit of a Mr Tom Burton and the Sydney Morning Herald with public funds for merely reporting some of the procedures in Parliament; that is quite intolerable.

The other person who has to answer for his actions is the former Minister in this portfolio, Senator Collins. The attacks that Senator Collins made on me were legion, and unfortunately for him they are preserved for posterity. He made many attacks on Senator Macdonald, Senator O'Chee and anyone else who dared to put a contrary point of view. He said of me:

SPEECH.PARA: I must say that there are similarities between the nonsense that Senator MacGibbon has run consistently in this debate.
Once he referred to me as a `Slimy, sleazy piece of work'.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was when you alleged corruption; Macphee discounts that.

—No, it is not discounted. In the old Scottish terminology, it is not proven. It was not investigated, and that is an entirely different matter. But let me get back to the reprehensible attitude of Senator Collins.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins attacked me in grossly intemperate language. I do not mind that. It is quite proper for Senator Collins to defend his point of view in the political arena. Senator Collins's crime was that he failed to exercise prudence by confirming whether there was any substance to the allegations raised in public about the conduct involved. He responded in an unintelligent and bullying way to all that criticism. He failed to make any inquiries to establish whether the allegations were correct. Furthermore, he defended the CAA. On one occasion, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I want to get one thing absolutely clear. The officers of the CAA have been constantly vilified and defamed in print. I think it is outrageous that Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards were named in a newspaper the other day. . .
On another occasion, he said:
I could not imagine an arrangement which puts the CAA in a stronger position. I have never seen such a strong process in terms of letting a tender.
Later on, he said:
A number of claims have been made about irregularities, some of them quite extraordinary and defamatory, in aspects of the process. . .
And so on. Senator Collins failed to exercise the responsibilities that are vested in him.

PARA.TAB: This is a landmark inquiry with respect to government business enterprises. They all have the same general provision that they operate in a commercial sense, independent of the government, but they are specifically set up under their own Acts of Parliament. Today we are seeing the first Federal Government business enterprise failure. We have seen many in the State arena: the State Bank of Victoria; Tricontinental; the VEDC; and in South Australia, the State Bank of South Australia and the State Government Insurance Group.

The whole concept of government business enterprises and their accountability to the Parliament has to be examined. I have a strong view that if an enterprise can exist in the commercial world, it should be sold out, provided there are competitors. It should not be a government business enterprise. The concept will not work.
If there is a matter of public interest or a monopoly, it should be a department of state, administered by a Minister answerable to the Parliament. Nothing else will work in a democracy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot sell a safety regulator, Senator.
—No, but that becomes a department of state.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I want to comment on the Civil Aviation Authority itself. This great authority has been in decline for 20 years, ever since Mr Charles Jones and Mr Gough Whitlam merged the old Department of Civil Aviation into a transport authority. It has now gone to extremes. It is run by money-grubbers, professional business managers and single issue people—ideologues pursuing concepts like user pays. It is now very low in professional expertise.

There are great and dedicated people still within the Department, but they are almost incapable of being effective. We had the nonsensical situation the other day when the Civil Aviation Authority made a big play out of hiring public relations consultants to oversight its safety procedures. An unknown overseas private company is to advise on the correctness of Australia's civil aviation safety procedures for the next three years. This is required to give an imprimatur of respectability to the CAA.

Donald Anderson or Dickie Williams would turn in their graves. The world used to beat a path to the doors of the old Australian Department of Civil Aviation to find out how safety standards should be implemented. That act of hiring a public safety adviser is parallelled only by the extraordinary situation of hiring a Mr Richard Farmer to act as a lobbyist between the CAA and a Labor Government—a move that is quite extraordinary.

The whole of the operation of the CAA now is suspect. I do not say that lightly. As an old airman, I have very grave fears about the safety of aviation in this country—something that is quite different from the matter which is before us today in this air traffic control report. The risk of a major aviation disaster in Australia is now very high. We are in a situation that is similar to that in the 1960s, when we lost three Viscounts. The lesson that emerged from that was that the Australian public will not tolerate an abasement of the safety standards.

We need to change the whole culture of the CAA. We need to get away from the money-grubbers. We can never go back to the old Department of Civil Aviation, but we must critically, honestly and urgently examine the present system, otherwise the nation will be very much the poorer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will attempt to be reasonably brief, as Senator MacGibbon was. I would like to make a number of comments about the report and about some of Senator MacGibbon's comments. I certainly fully support the one recommendation that Mr Macphee made early in the report, and that is to go back to the beginning of the ROI process with Thomson and Hughes and to start that detailed specification period again. Frankly, I did believe that that would be, at least if not the fundamental recommendation, the major recommendation of the report when I began the process which set this inquiry in train.

PARA.TAB: Like Senator MacGibbon, I have not had any greater opportunity than he has had of reading the report in detail. But there are two matters that I noted in the report which I will deal with first before I actually turn to some of the more general comments made by Senator MacGibbon about the CAA and about the job that it currently does.

On page 64 of the report there is a reference to a meeting where the author of the report talks about—and this was in fact the crucial meeting, which interestingly enough was on Friday the 13th—the absence from that meeting of Mr Yates, who has just been mentioned in not particularly glowing terms by Senator MacGibbon, and of Mr Baillieu. I mention this because in a number of places in this report the author uses the term `atmospherics'.

The atmospherics created by this reference indicate that two of these members had experience in aspects of aviation and so on; in other words, two of the more technically competent people on the board—and I know that both of them are aviators—were absent from the meeting. The impression is created therefore that they did not have the opportunity to express a view on the preferred contractors.

I put a caveat on this comment because I am in the position of Senator MacGibbon and everyone else in that I have not had time to read the report as fully as I shall. I do not doubt for a minute that it will not be the last we hear of it, so I am not concerned about contributing to the debate at this stage. But from my recollection of the events surrounding this meeting, there is an important matter which, if my memory serves me correctly, is omitted from this report but which is very relevant to Mr Yates and Mr Baillieu. This was a recollection I have of a conversation that I had with some board members at the time about what was a very finely balanced judgment process. Mr Macphee makes clear that these were two highly competent companies and the process was finely balanced. Senator Bishop is shaking her head.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am saying dirty work at the crossroads.
—Is Senator Bishop saying that? Is she alleging corruption?
—No; I am making the point that Senator MacGibbon made, that there is no evidence—it is not proven.

—That is precisely the line I would expect from Senator Bishop. Before she goes too hard on it, I suggest she does Mr Macphee the credit of at least reading his report to see what he has to say about that. I have a clear recollection in respect of that meeting from which Mr Yates and Mr Baillieu were absent. The inference created here is that they did not have an opportunity to express a view and the inference clearly hanging in the air—there is no question about it—is that, if they had been there to express a view, it would have been a different view to the one that was expressed. I think any fair reading of the document would indicate that. My clear recollection is that not only did they have a strong view but also that strong view was in favour of selecting Thomson on the basis of their assessment of risk—and it did come down to that in the finish—for the CAA in getting burnt.

PARA.TAB: I have to commend Mr Macphee for the way he has grounded this report in the background he has given to how these board members came into their jobs and how the chief executive came into his job. Mr Macphee lays that out very well. They were preoccupied, as Mr Macphee says—and they were—with the question of placing the CAA at significant financial exposure, considering what had previously happened. Senator MacGibbon is as aware of what previously happened as I was. I think it would be fair to say that Senator MacGibbon strongly supported the changes that were made in the then management of the CAA and its restructuring. I see that he is nodding in assent. It is in that atmosphere, which Mr Macphee has accurately laid out in the report, that they came into this job.

My recollection is very clear. My recollection is that not only did Mr Yates and Mr Baillieu have a clear preference for Thomson on the question of risk assessment for the organisation, that it was a safer bet, a more tried bet—and that is what it really came down to in the finish—but also that they had provided formal proxies to the Chairman of the Board, Mr Butcher, which he then exercised on their behalf. They cast their votes by proxies which they provided in favour of Thomson.

I wanted to put this on the record now so it can be checked—but I place the caveat on it that I am relying on my memory because I have only really had an opportunity to flick through this report today—that I am sure that that is correct. I will check it as soon as I leave the chamber. If it is correct, I think that it is an unfortunate omission from the report. I am not criticising the report's accuracy. I think the details that have been laid out are accurate. In fact, I think most of the report that I have seen is accurate in terms of the picture it paints. But I am certain that Mr Yates and Mr Baillieu, although they were physically absent from the meeting, formally provided written proxies to the Chairman of the Board and that their views, therefore, were not only known but counted at the meeting in terms of those proxies.

I understand that I will be talking to Mr Macphee this afternoon. I have never actually even met Mr Macphee, let alone talked to him to this point. The reason I raise that is that I wish to speak to him about another matter in the report, which is perhaps forgivable on his part. I do not accord it the same significance as the one I have just mentioned.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't call on you to resign.
—It is in reference to that, the only reference that I get in the entire report—
—Page 91.

—I am glad that Senator Calvert has noted it. It is untrue. The difficulty that I have with it is this: Mr Macphee says, correctly—I think he has discharged this to the extent that I understand—that where people come in for critical comment in the report he has, in accordance with natural justice and fair process, contacted them and ensured that they had an opportunity to advise him as to whether the statements made in whatever draft part of the report was going to be produced were fair and correct. I cannot remember which page that is on, but I have certainly read that he has done that. Certainly that did not happen in my case. I do not want to place any more weight on this than it deserves because it is not a major aspect of the report—it is a minor one—but it does help to sketch in the background to the establishment of this inquiry.

PARA.TAB: Mr Macphee says on page 91—and he does this, to give him his due, in praise of Mr Hollis, Senator MacGibbon and so on—that it is significant that Mr Hollis incurred the wrath of his Labor colleague the then Minister, Senator Collins. I have spoken to Mr Hollis, as one would expect. Mr Hollis has assured me that no such information was given by him to Mr Macphee. Mr Hollis told me that he had spoken to Mr Macphee on one occasion that he could recall. It was in the company of a number of other people, including, I think he said, the Assistant Secretary of the Committee. He said that that information had not been sought by Mr Macphee from him and it had not been proffered. I am, therefore, forced to believe, until Mr Macphee tells me differently, that Mr Macphee relied for that information on a column in the Sydney Morning Herald which in very graphic terms described a totally untrue event.

I say on this occasion in deference to the author of that article, whom I have criticised in the past but whom I do not criticise on this occasion, that I do not doubt that somebody in this hotbed of intrigue, Parliament House, conveyed to the author of that article, Mr Burton, that those events occurred. They did not ever occur. That has also been confirmed by Mr Hollis in a conversation that I had with him yesterday.

The reason I raise that is that it is important to note, in respect of the so-called wrath visited on Mr Hollis, that I have not had an angry conversation with Mr Hollis in my life. I have had a number of dealings with Mr Hollis in relation to the third runway construction at Sydney Airport. We moved a motion of urgency in the House of Representatives that he took amiss, and he said so. He was defending his Committee, rightly, as its Chairman. I understand that. We had an amiable conversation about that privately. He certainly trounced me publicly on that occasion for outrageously overturning a reference to the Committee of the third runway issue. I do not apologise for that, by the way; I think that was the correct decision.

Obviously I have had discussions with him related to defence housing matters in the Northern Territory. I had a number of conversations with Mr Hollis about this important question of the CAA. They were not only amicable but positive and constructive. They all related to matters that led to the establishment of this independent inquiry, which I felt, finally, was absolutely the only course of action that could be adopted and set into train the processes that brought it into being.

Certainly on one of those occasions in which I had a discussion with Mr Hollis I suggested to him, in the presence of my staff—at that stage simply as an option—one way of addressing the serious concerns that the Public Works Committee had. I want to say something—and I hope it is taken in context—about the comments, which I think were sound, which Senator MacGibbon made about the lack of knowledge of government processes by people who work for GBEs, because I have serious concerns about that myself. I suggested that one of the options that may resolve the difficulty for the Committee would be an independent inquiry into this entire matter, into the CAA.
Throughout this entire effort—and Senator MacGibbon took a number of selective quotes from me, all of which related to charges that were being made of actual corruption—

TALK.START.PARA: —Not all.

—Most of them. To put Senator MacGibbon's comment into context, one of those charges was directed by him at me—it is in the Hansard—accusing me of taking kickbacks from Thomson over this, which was an outrageous thing to say, and it was said in this chamber. But I do not want to place any more weight on that than it deserves. I have said again and again on the public record that there was no political involvement, as in my view there could not be, in the way the GBEs are set up in relation to government and there was no political involvement in the letting of this tender—I say `substantial tender', and Senator MacGibbon is correct about that—or any other tender. I regularly get visited with complaints from everybody from roller door manufacturers to security systems manufacturers expecting me to make a political decision to award a contract to a failed tenderer. I regularly refer those matters to the GBEs involved. What I have said in this Parliament, in this chamber, in Question Time again and again, is that I did have a number of discussions with the senior executives of the CAA and its board about matters relating to this tender.

PARA.TAB: I formally addressed the Board twice on the matter and I made that information available to this chamber as well. On both of those occasions I scrupulously adhered to personally bringing to the Board's attention the legitimate concern that the Government had about the maximum involvement of Australian industry in this process, and the concern the Government had that that would be exercised in respect of whichever contractor got the—

TALK.START.PARA: —You say they took no notice.
—That is a matter the Government has addressed in a substantive way.
—They took no action.
—The Government has addressed it.
—No fights between the pretender and the incumbent.

—I can assure Senator Macdonald that there is no disagreement between Senator Schacht and me on this. In fact, one of the results of all of this was the bringing to Cabinet, with my full support—Senator Button and I consulted widely on this—of a submission, referred to by the Minister in his tabling statement, to set up new arrangements in respect of GBEs generally and purchasing policy. That has been developed over a long period.

PARA.TAB: One of the things I have to say—and Senator MacGibbon raised it, and correctly, I think—is that one of my concerns very early in this portfolio was that the Government had set GBEs up as commercial enterprises. I disagree with Senator MacGibbon; I think that it is an appropriate, correct and, indeed, largely successful way of operating. In opening the first stage of the new international airport terminal at Melbourne last night—and I am about to go and open the new international terminal in Sydney on Friday—I think it is obviously that there are GBEs that perform spectacularly well in this fashion—as does the CAA generally. Despite his criticisms, Senator MacGibbon, would have to concede that a long term overdue process of reform has been expeditiously carried out inside that organisation. Restructuring has been undertaken that has turned in savings to the industry of $96m in charges last year alone. But one of the problems in this process is that the boards of these organisations, who are almost all responsible for employing their own senior staff—not the Government—go out into private industry, recruit the best people that they can, which is what happened in this case, and then these people from private industry come in, take the job, get on with the job thinking that it is a commercial company, and say, `What are Senate Estimates committees? What is the Public Works committee? We did not know that we had to go and address that. What is the Caucus Committee on Transport and Communications?'

The reason that I raise that point is that in respect of this matter, particularly, those senior officers, at one stage, did almost nothing else except track from one Government committee to another for hours at a time. It came as a shock to Mr Baldwin to discover the reality of these parliamentary processes to which organisations which he expected to run as a commercial enterprise and as a regulator are subjected. That is a matter that I have raised a number of times with my colleagues in Cabinet. But when the situation got to the point where the matters raised by the Joint Committee on Public Works had reached a certain point, I considered that the only way of resolving them was by an independent inquiry.

The reason I make that point is in direct reference to this assertion in the report about the so-called wrathful relationship I had with Mr Hollis, which did not exist; it was the reverse. I can only assume that Mr Macphee has based this on those press reports and the later references to them in Hansard, because Mr Hollis told me that he did not communicate it to him directly; it never happened. What did happen was that a process was put in train by me with the secretary of my Department, Graham Evans, and the associate secretary, Roger Beale, where we had numerous meetings, discussions and detailed advice was given as to the best way of establishing the inquiry; whether it was going to be a single person inquiring into it or two or three people in a tribunal inquiring into it and, indeed, the class of person.

For example, at one stage I can recall that a suggestion was made that it be the Auditor-General that conducted the inquiry. All of this was actively canvassed at the time of the totally unexpected resignation of Senator Richardson and my move from the portfolio. The matter was well in hand at that point, and I know that those senior officers from my Department, Roger Beale and Graham Evans, subsequently provided the same advice to Senator Cook, as the new Minister, as they had given to me, in a far more detailed and coordinated fashion; that is, that the flesh was filled in at that stage on the bones. But the facts are that the inquiry would have proceeded with exactly the same expedition if the unfortunate resignation of Senator Richardson had not occurred. That is a matter of fact that can be demonstrated. I intend, of course, to make those points to Mr Macphee when I speak to him later today.

In respect of the report itself, I think that Mr Macphee has done a good job in setting in context the difficulties the CAA had in the past, the substantial losses that had been suffered—some $48m he correctly asserts—in in-house solutions to replacing our badly outdated air traffic control system around Australia. I welcome his comments in respect of the Cairns radar, where he said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the Review's opinion, the political and media attention given to the difficulties at Cairns and Coolangatta exaggerated the seriousness of the problems being experienced.

He has done a fundamentally good job on this report. His basic conclusion is essential to implement—but of course, I say that in the context of not being the Minister responsible now. In terms of the processes that were set in train, by myself in consultation with the two senior officers I have mentioned from my Department, the fundamental recommendation—and there really is only one—that this be done, did not surprise me.

PARA.TAB: The Government has moved to address some of the emerging problems that have occurred with GBEs generally. The statement that will be made some time in the future by Mr Willis in respect of tighter accountability procedures with GBEs, but in particular, the major initiative that has been taken in respect of the purchasing—major contracts over $30m—of GBEs and Australian content, has also been adequately addressed by the Government.

I conclude by making one other reference to the report. As distinct from the assertions of Senator MacGibbon, Mr Macphee has strongly endorsed the action that was taken by the Board and the senior management to adopt the TAAATS project. Senator Bishop is sitting there shaking her head again. Mr Macphee has done that not only in precise terms, but in great detail. He strongly endorses it. He says that it was, in fact, the correct process. In his covering letter to the Minister, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the original selection process was soundly based.

TALK.START.PARA: —It says a lot more too.
—Correct. But what he did say—and Senator Bishop should refer to it—is this:

SPEECH.PARA: The fundamental decision to abandon the piecemeal, costly and failed process that the CAA had engaged in and to go to the system of a national air traffic control system was soundly based—

and was, in fact, the correct decision. On page 73 he also says this in respect to what happens in the future—and I make this point because I think it should be pointed out in respect of what has been said in here:

Such changes are peripheral to the Review, but part of the atmospherics. There had to be changes of culture reflected in function and staff size. The Board and its then chairman, Mr Smith, deserve credit for beginning the transformation. Whether management might have handled it more sensitively might be fruitfully debated elsewhere. What is clear is that there remains a substantial challenge for the new Chairman, Mr Butcher, and senior management to win the support of the remaining staff and their unions in order to develop a new work ethos. There is certainly no point in re-opening old wounds and wishing for the good old days.

The reason I want to finish on that point is this: the CAA has done a great deal of work in the last few years that has been greatly welcomed and supported by the aviation industry. The people who are senior in that industry have no wish to go back to the good old days referred to by Senator MacGibbon—and that is the reason I make the point—the good old days, when it was a regulator, in which the cost of the regulation was totally divorced from the operation itself.

PARA.TAB: I do not think anyone wants to return to that. A great deal of positive structural change has occurred and is continuing to occur with the civil aviation organisation. That has been of enormous benefit to the aviation industry. There were almost $100m in savings to the industry just last year. That reform will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether the address we heard from Senator Collins was an apology for senior officers of the CAA or an apology for himself. But in both cases it was wholly and utterly short of the mark. The adverse findings against senior officers in the CAA, which are contained in this report on the Thomson radar contract, require their immediate dismissal from the Authority.

PARA.TAB: What is more important of course is that we accept Mr Macphee's recommendation that the tender process for the radar contract be reopened. Everything in this report vindicates my concerns when I first raised this issue at the beginning of this year. The very first question about this matter in this Parliament to Senator Collins concerned changes to the evaluation personnel. From recollection, I was assured that there were no changes to the evaluation personnel. Yet the changes are evidenced in this report, and follow the 18 December 1991 meeting of the board when things started to be changed.

Unfortunately it goes further than that. It appears that senior officers of the CAA were not sufficiently competent to make appropriate decisions for the safety of the Australian travelling public. That is what this is all about—the safety of the travelling public. I am also very concerned about some of the findings that Mr Macphee made about what he described as the `management style' of two of the executives, Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards. Not only did they demonstrate very little management but also they demonstrated no apparent style at all.

The report details a paper trail of documents which included briefing material prepared months after its apparent date. There is also evidence that the critical board meeting which selected the Thomson system was called at two days' notice upon the advice of Mr Baldwin—two days' notice for the calling of a board meeting that was to make what Mr Macphee describes as the most fundamental decision that Authority would make! Not only is this disturbing, but it is quite simply unacceptable that the directors and members of the board should have been expected to read their briefing papers while watching a slide presentation, and then reach a decision in time to catch the last plane out of Canberra. To characterise this as mere incompetence is extremely charitable. Mr Macphee has been extremely charitable to these two gentlemen. I think it really does go beyond incompetence. I will get on to the detailed evidence about that in a moment.
Mr Macphee's comment about that was very telling. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The advice to the Board by Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards was fatally flawed. It was inadequately researched and tested. Hughes were not assessed fairly.

They are very disturbing words. The findings made against them should require their immediate dismissal from the Authority. Could I make this point also for the individuals concerned: I understand that similar matters are being canvassed in New Zealand and that a parliamentary committee of inquiry in that country will be examining this report closely. It is being extremely charitable to say that it is mere incompetence in two countries on either side of the Tasman.

PARA.TAB: It was found that Thomson's main competitor, Hughes, had been recommended as preferred contractor on 18 December 1991 but rejected, and that in the period after that information presented to the board of the CAA highlighted risks related to Hughes but not to Thomson. I think that is very important. I think I ought to go into some of that. On page 53 of the report Mr Macphee outlines the details of that meeting on 18 December. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: It was also recommended to the Board that Hughes be announced as the preferred contractor.
Mr Macphee also noted:

The Chief Executive's comment attached to the Board paper stated that Mr Baldwin supported the recommendation, but requested that the Board note Executive Management's concerns regarding the risks associated with Hughes' proposal.

He then goes on through this report to show that what we had was an unfair treatment of the issue of risk. This is one of the matters that I raised in the Parliament, in the Estimates committee, and in the briefing that occurred.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to go into the briefing but let us go to what Mr Macphee said about Mr Baldwin and the information that was provided. He said this:

SPEECH.PARA: It is difficult to imagine how Mr Baldwin, as a Board member, could not have realised the arresting effect this proviso would have on the other directors. Executive Management and Mr Baldwin highlighted the risks associated with Hughes despite the fact that the operational and technical evaluations had taken account of risk and Hughes had still been evaluated as the top bidder.

TALK.START.PARA: —What page is this?

—This is set out in italics in the very large paragraph at the top of page 53. This was the issue that I raised when I provided Dr Edwards, and other members of the management team, with copies of the evaluation sheets showing that risk was a factor that the original evaluation teams considered. We were given some nonsense story about not understanding what the risk was all about. This report clearly shows that the comments I made were correct, that risk was double counted and, more importantly, that the risk was double counted in a fashion which was clearly prejudicial to Hughes. There have been many doubts expressed about the Thomson radar system. The Australian public can now have very little confidence left about the system. Certainly, to proceed with the contract after all the problems that have occurred in relation to performance and also the awarding of the tender would be very unsound and highly unsatisfactory. The only proper thing to do in the circumstances is to reopen the tender and, if necessary, award it to somebody else.

PARA.TAB: I think it is appropriate to look at some of the background to the awarding of that tender. For example, we previously canvassed in Parliament, either in the chamber or elsewhere, issues about where the Hughes system was working elsewhere in the world. Korea was one of those. A delegation was sent to Korea. However, page 83 of the report is damning of the preparation that was undertaken prior to that team going to Korea and damning of the time and opportunity it had. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the lack of full and fair information many Board members gravely under-estimated the ATC system in Korea and consequently the abilities of Hughes.

I think Senator Collins made a similar mistake in some of his statements in this chamber. An air traffic control system with great civil and military significance was portrayed to directors as simple and very basic. One director showed the effect of these reports when he described the system to the review as `mickey mouse'. Goodness gracious—all the facts were to the contrary.

PARA.TAB: Then we have some very interesting actions by Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards at the 18 December meeting. This is the one where Hughes was the recommended tenderer but they persuaded the board to go the other way.

TALK.START.PARA: —They also persuaded Senator Collins.
—They also persuaded Senator Collins. I want to refer to the written recommendation of Mr Baldwin. Mr Baldwin's comments expressly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Executive Management went through a lengthy briefing and consideration of the evaluation team's assessment and support the recommendations.
In doing so we ask the Board to note:

PARA.TAB: our concerns with the technical risks with the Hughes proposal;
our concerns with the Hughes original time schedule—which our Project Management have subsequently addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: There was no mention of the risks associated with Thomson, none at all, yet there was this canvassing over and over of risks relating to Hughes. The penultimate slide that Dr Edwards showed the board—and the evidence of the extreme impact it had on the board is very interesting—apparently read:
Risks
Hughes
—FDP/RDP development
—commitment to Civil ATC market
—optimistic schedule
:CAA to take steps to mitigate before contract signature

In other words, what was being telegraphed was, `Look, we are recommending this, but we do not think it is sound'—and, of course, they did not present the risks associated with the other contractor. Mr Macphee says:

The effect of the slide on the Board was profound. In the minds of most directors, the risks associated with Thomson had vanished. Indeed, while various risks had been highlighted regarding the Thomson bid, the directors all remembered the emphasis which Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards had placed upon the risk with Hughes.

This whole process has been extremely painful for people on both sides of the chamber who have entered into this in good faith. I note that Senator Schacht is nodding his head in agreement. Some people on this side of the chamber have been subjected to wholly unfair, unsatisfactory and very painful treatment both in this chamber and elsewhere. I think it is appropriate to note the comments that were made by Mr Macphee in saying that the people who were involved in getting this reviewed deserve the thanks of the Australian public. I do not say that in a self-serving way; I say it as a tribute to my colleagues. But I think in retrospect Senator Collins did himself a grave disservice in the way he treated this issue.

PARA.TAB: I reserve my last comment for Senator Cook with whom I do not ordinarily agree. I wish to say on this occasion, because it is most appropriate, that Senator Cook has exemplified very fine conduct as a Minister in picking up the mess that was left by Senator Collins—very fine conduct indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are as transparent as a sheet of glass.

—Senator Collins wishes to interject; Senator Collins was the person who consistently opposed any suggestion from this side of the chamber that the whole project be subject to review, for example, by a parliamentary committee which, for those who wished to give evidence, would have attracted privilege. That was not available to those associated with this report here. I do not mean that in a derogatory way.

PARA.TAB: But Minister Cook has done a fine job; he has done the appropriate thing. I believe it is now appropriate for us to recommend not only the dismissal of Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards but also the reopening of this tender and, if necessary, the awarding of it to another party and a review of the systems that are already in place. The safety of the Australian public deserves it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the report of the independent review of the Civil Aviation Authority's tender evaluation process for the Australian advanced air traffic system which has been tabled today. I have only had a brief chance to read it, as have other honourable senators. However, from about halfway through the report, if we pick up any page and start reading paragraphs almost at random, we find the most sorry litany of mismanagement at the very senior level of the CAA regarding the TAAATS contract.

PARA.TAB: I became interested in this issue many months ago when I saw the reports in the press about the hearings of the Joint Committee on Public Works. When I sat down one night for about 2 1/2 hours and laboriously read the transcript of the Hansard of those first hearings it became clear to me that the senior management of CAA did not understand the parliamentary system and the Westminster system and who was ultimately responsible for running the country. It also became clear to me that the process of awarding this tender from December 1991 onwards had been rorted by the senior management, namely, Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards.

I raised that matter in this Parliament around that time. I also spoke to Senator Collins on a number of occasions expressing my concern. I do know, and I agree with his remarks, that while he was still Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support he was beginning the process of consideration of having a review of the tendering process. However, events overtook Senator Collins with the resignation of Senator Richardson, which resulted in Senator Collins becoming the Minister for Transport and Communications and civil aviation matters going to Senator Cook. I admit here that on the night of the announcement of Senator Cook's appointment and before he was actually sworn in I took the opportunity to get into his office, being a friend of his, to tell him, `The No. 1 issue you have to deal with is establishing an independent review of this tendering process because there is more than enough evidence on the record, in the Hansard of the Public Works Committee, if nothing else, to show that something stinks, something is crook, and the reputation of Australia and its ability to tender fairly and squarely for major items in the public sector is at risk. We will end up being considered like a Third World country'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you tell Senator Collins that?

—I have just said I did, you fool! I have just said that, whilst he was still Minister, I was privately putting that view to him—and Senator Collins is aware of that. But I did take that opportunity when Senator Cook took over, and Senator Cook said, `Well, I haven't even been sworn in, Schachtie; give us a day'.
—I know you are right with Senator Cook, but why didn't Senator Collins do something?

—As I have just said, I did raise it with Senator Collins on a number of occasions in the preceding week or so since I had made a speech in this chamber—I think it was around April or May of this year—saying that something was wrong with the process. I took that opportunity and I agreed with the remarks made by other honourable senators that the appointment of a review headed by Mr Macphee was the appropriate outcome. I remind Senator MacGibbon that at the time of Mr Macphee's appointment and the terms of reference being announced he did make some disparaging remarks about the terms of reference being too narrow. I think it has been shown to all of us that the terms of reference and the review headed by Mr Macphee were more than adequate.

PARA.TAB: The other reason I have become interested over the last couple of years in CAA matters is that the board and the senior management showed absolutely no interest in developing Australian industry in civil aviation matters. When I raised it with board members and senior management in the previous couple of years there was only one answer: `We are here to run a commercially effective operation; our concern is not about developing Australian industry'. If every public sector department, every industry in Australia, took that attitude we would not get any development at all. So I became concerned about the view of management at the senior level of the CAA.

There are a couple of very clear things which emerge from this report. The first is that the process must be reopened in which Thomson and Hughes go back to being the two major contenders and that a proper process of tendering takes place. The second thing that must take place is that Mr Baldwin and Mr Edwards, if as a result of this report they have not resigned their positions before midnight tonight, must be sacked by the board. They can in no conscionable way continue to be the two senior full time executives of the Civil Aviation Authority. This passage from the report has been quoted here before by other honourable senators, but on page 90 the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: The advice of the Board by Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards was fatally flawed. It was inadequately researched and tested. Hughes were not assessed fairly.
Those two sentences mean that those officers have to go. They should have the honour to resign today or by midnight tonight. If not, the board should meet tomorrow and sack them.

PARA.TAB: I also have something to say about the board. We have read about the board making its decision in March of this year. It is quite clear that there are two board members who, in my view, have maintained some honour—Mr Ayres and Mr Mant. In my view, all the rest should resign. I do not believe that the present Chairman and Vice-Chairman of the board can sustain their positions, particularly when we hear about the board meeting in March of this year. When the board meeting took place two members were not present—although, according to Senator Collins, they did put in proxy votes—to make the decision to let the biggest commercial contract in its history.

I believe it would be only reasonable to ensure that all board members were present. I believe that the Chairman of the board should not have allowed that meeting to proceed. Therefore, in view of the findings of this report, Mr Butcher, as Chairman, should also resign. Though Senator Cook has put before the board a course of action to respond to the report, I hope that it does not come to the situation where the Government has to take direct action and ask members of the board to resign or have them sacked. I hope that they do the honourable thing and resign in the next few days. Mr Butcher is also Chairman of the National Rail Corporation. In view of the findings about the operation of the board, he should review his position as Chairman of the National Rail Corporation.

In the brief time available—I know that the Whips want to keep this debate as brief as possible—I will address the area of industry policy, which is dealt with on page 78 of the report. In part, the review says:

SPEECH.PARA: It therefore followed that the Board felt that any consortium member providing services would be a minor consortium member. Further, the Review believes the Board did not explore with Australian industry what it could offer in a TAAATS consortium. TAAATS was, in their minds, an exercise in purchasing goods, and Australian companies did not make RDP or FDP systems.
The report goes on:
In our view, the Australian companies concerned have justification for being critical of the CAA for adopting this approach, especially as it does not accord with the policy of the Government.

At this stage, I give particular mention to one of the heroes in this sorry saga. There are a few heroes. It is very easy for us in Parliament to be heroes and raise issues in debate because we have privilege protection. But I congratulate Bev Clarke, a senior officer of DITAC, who made a number of remarks publicly criticising this process and got her fingers rapped very strongly.

PARA.TAB: While considering this issue of industry policy in an Estimates committee hearing, I asked Mr Baldwin what the CAA was doing about industry policy and what the views of Senator Button were about the CAA's industry policy. As bold as brass, under privilege and oath, Mr Baldwin said, `I've had a discussion with Senator Button. He is more than happy with the industry policy of the CAA'. The next day I took the opportunity to speak to Senator Button about that comment. I said, `Are you happy with Mr Baldwin's view of industry policy in the CAA?', and he said, `Absolutely not; I have never given him that impression'. That is another example where Mr Baldwin, in my view, is very liberal with the truth of what others say.

At that same Estimates hearing I asked whether Mr Baldwin and Dr Edwards were being indemnified by the CAA board for writs that they were personally taking out against journalists. Out came a long saga about a number of writs being taken against particular journalists, guaranteed to a limited amount by the CAA board. In my view, they were completely unnecessary. The board was again derelict in allowing an unlimited indemnity for these writs to be issued.

I return to a consideration of the industry policy. I believe that the CAA, as a public function, should have a properly developed industry policy. In our region, the opportunities to export our technology in aviation, radar and air traffic control are immense. Only three months ago, AWA Australia, a fully owned Australian company, won a $20m contract internationally in China against opposition from other companies to provide air traffic control equipment. It had the opportunity not only to bid but also to show that its technology, Australian developed, was better than any in the world. With the success of that contract, there is now the further opportunity for it to get another contract of $80m in China. That all means exports from Australia and extra jobs in Australia.

When the CAA has been asked to help in that area in the past there has not been a whisker of help. The CAA was asked to provide a letter to AWA to help it in its bid with the Chinese. A more sparse letter of endorsement one would never hope to see. I believe it is something that the AWA would not be willing to use in China because, reading between the lines, it basically says that the CAA does not care about Australian exports from Australian companies in civil aviation equipment.

That is typical of the attitude of the present senior management and board of the CAA. I believe that, if nothing else, we should change the board and its senior management. Getting some decent Australians, who are committed to Australian exports, to manage this operation would be an improvement on hiring doubtful people from New Zealand who do not seem to have any idea about developing Australian industry. I understand that New Zealand had similar views about these people not developing the industry in New Zealand when they ran the New Zealand system.

I believe that this is a seminal report on the way in which we have to look at the running of government business enterprises. There is a conundrum on this issue. How does one balance a commercial board vis-a-vis ministerial responsibility? That debate will continue to go backwards and forwards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly! It is a point I have been trying to make repeatedly.

—If Senator Lewis has the perfect answer, I want to hear it. There is no perfect answer about balancing those two questions. If a Minister were put in charge of a commercial operation, we would all be screaming that he was playing the commercial game and interfering in commercial activities. There would then be arguments about whether he showed influence and so on. If he or she is removed from it completely and the board goes mad and does stupid things, we would all come back in here screaming, `Sack the Minister'. It is an absolute conundrum about how we deal with this issue.
