PARA.TAB: This problem occurred in South Australia. The Act said that the State Bank should be at arm's length from government. In my view, the Premier unfortunately took that point too literally. He let the board go off on its own for far too long. But when it all collapsed the board did not take the rap; the Premier took the rap and had to pay the political penalty, even though the Act said that he could not interfere in the day-to-day management of the bank.

So this is a conundrum. It is a debate that we will always have. There is no perfect solution to it. But, overall, I look forward in the next few days as a result of this report to there being significant new vacancies in the senior management of the CAA.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very quick. I point out that, as described in this report, I am a member of the normally low profile Joint Committee on Public Works. This report has restored my faith in parliamentary committees as it should restore the faith of the public in them.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht has already told us of his involvement in this matter and Senator Collins has told us that he is starting to put an inquiry into place. There were even kind words from Senator MacGibbon about Senator Cook and the way that Senator Cook acted with efficiency and integrity in speedily hastening the production of this report. The report says that if it had not been for the persistence and the diligent inquiries of Senator MacGibbon and the Public Works Committee, particularly the Chairman, Mr Hollis, there is some doubt whether this committee process, the report that we have before us today and the system that was trying to be pushed through would have ever come to light.

I have a feeling that Senator Collins, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support at the time, was in some ways probably snowed. I had the impression that I was being snowed from the day we first met Dr Edwards, in particular, and Mr Baldwin. I had the feeling—I am sure the other members of the Committee also did because we spoke about it afterwards—that we were being absolutely snowed. To some extent, the Minister at the time may have been, because his opinion was that the Hughes system was the better system. But he took advice and changed his mind. I pay tribute to Senator MacGibbon. The report says:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator MacGibbon has won respect for his perseverance on other issues and was no less persistent on this. His call for a review of the decision was made with the public interest in mind, and he shrugged off some pressures to silence him.
That has already been mentioned today. Senator O'Chee had a significant input, as did my colleague Senator Lewis.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I give credit to Mr Hollis in the other place, the Chairman of our Public Works Committee. It is a pity that he was not as strong on the decision about the York Park building which will be brought up this afternoon and which I will mention later. In this case he stuck to his guns even though it does say in the report—and the Minister has denied it—that he was savaged by Senator Collins on more than one occasion. I know that for a fact. The line in this report which sums it all up is:

SPEECH.PARA: The behaviour of the Parliamentarians involved was in the best traditions of the public interest.
Sometimes we forget what we are here for, and the work of both the low profile and the high profile committees in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party has a lot to answer for in this very sorry saga of the Civil Aviation Authority's tender evaluation process for the AAATS. It is all right for Senator Collins and Senator Schacht to come in and claim some credit for what has happened, but Senator Collins should do the honourable thing and resign from the Ministry over this. I say that in all seriousness, because for many a day in this Parliament Senator MacGibbon and Senator Lewis tried to indicate to Senator Collins that there was something wrong. All they got for their efforts was personal abuse all the time. Senator Collins went out of his way to defend the CAA board and these officers against what everybody knew and what we were trying to elucidate at the time.

PARA.TAB: During a hearing of Estimates Committee C on 31 March 1992 at about 4 o'clock in the morning that Committee was trying to show Senator Collins just what was happening. I was working with a series of questions that Senator Lewis had made available to me, because he had been unable to get to that Committee. At all times we were thwarted by the Labor Party.

If senators have a look at the Hansard of that day, they will see that Senator Collins in his usual bumptious style did his best to put us off the track. I say, with some regret, that he was assisted by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Crowley, in trying to get the matter over and done with. Admittedly, it was 4 o'clock in the morning. Honourable senators may remember that Senator Aulich came in at the end and put his bid in, in a screaming match to try to get the Committee to stop asking questions about this incident.

I want to refresh the Senate's memory by quoting a few paragraphs from that Senate Estimates Committee hearing. Senator Bishop was asking about Mr Baldwin, his reputation and his background, and this is what Senator Collins said to Senator Bishop:

SPEECH.PARA: Excuse me, Madam Chairman. I am heartedly sick of these personal inquisitions by Senator Bishop. This constant pursuit by Senator Bishop, in Supplementary Estimates particularly, of people rather than problems has been demonstrated before. . . I will answer this question. I will take the responsibility—as I have said in the Senate before, properly take the responsibility—

Are you listening to that, Senator Collins? You said you would take the responsibility. Why do you not resign and take the responsibility? You said you would do it in a flourish of supposed style, as you are pretty good at doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Address your remarks through the Chair.
—He is pretty good on the rhetoric, but when it comes to it, he never delivers. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will take the responsibility . . . for whatever advice was given in terms of the policy directions. . .
He then proceeded to criticise Senator Bishop. Senator Bishop was inquiring into Mr Baldwin and his worth for this job. Senator Bishop went on to say:
Minister, this is not your personal fiefdom—
after Senator Collins had gone off at one of his tangents—

This is Government money and taxpayers' money that is being expended. Why will you not let Mr Baldwin give to us his background in order that he may assure the Committee as to what qualifications he had to exclude Australian consortiums?
Senator Collins said that it was not relevant, Senator Bishop said it was, and Senator Collins said:
It is not relevant to Supplementary Estimates. In fact, the CAA, having no call on the Supplementary Estimates at all, is not even required to be here.
Senators were trying to point out back in March what we hear today in this report and Senator Collins was trying to stymie the process. Senator Collins went on to say:
In deference to requests from senators—and I have always done this—I am happy to have them—
that is the CAA—
here, but not for the pursuit of some personal inquisition that Senator Bishop specialises in. What I will do is make. . . CV available. . .

He then went on to criticise Senator Bishop for inquiring into this man's background. Later on he continued with that sort of material, trying to stop this Estimates Committee getting the information that was required.

PARA.TAB: It is probably instructive to have a look at some other extracts. At that Committee hearing I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Can I just inquire whether the recommendation from the executive to the board gave full details to the board of all aspects of the Hughes contract?
Mr Baldwin's answer was:
Subsequent to 18 December when IBM fell out, on two occasions we had two meetings with the board on this issue. They were given the full details of both companies in a very fair and correct way.
According to Mr Macphee, that has been shown to be quite incorrect. Mr Baldwin went on to say:
Secondly, I want to assure you, Madam Chairman, and the rest of your Committee that the board was given all the information fairly and very justly on both companies in some considerable detail.
Later in the hearing Senator Collins said:

Can I answer this question in the general sense? Senator Lewis in Question Time in the Senate the other day asked a question relating to the process which Senator Macdonald is now asking questions about, and asserted—and I described this as being rubbish; and it was—that this particular process put the CAA in a `weak position'. In fact it is as good a process for getting the maximum benefit to the travelling public as I have seen, in a sense. . .
One of the recommendations from Mr Macphee says this:
This decision on 2 October 1991 was within the authority of the CAA, but caused a significant loss of negotiating leverage and was, therefore, unsound.

That is the same decision as the one Senator Collins was referring to when we said it would put them in a weak position, and he said that was rubbish. This is the Minister who, at the time, was protecting the board and these people and continued to do so. I will again quote from Mr Macphee's report which states:
The Board was not given the proper and adequate information on which to choose a preferred contractor at any of the meetings of 18 December, 1991, 7 March, 1992 or 13 March, 1992.

Honourable senators might note that 7 March and 13 March are just a few days before that Senate Estimates Committee hearing when Mr Baldwin assured us that they had been given all of the correct information.

PARA.TAB: I will read a couple more extracts from the Hansard transcript of the Estimates Committee hearing which I think are instructive. Senator Collins said:

SPEECH.PARA: I just have to make a short statement in defence of the board and the idea that the board of the CAA is a bunch of mugs that have wandered in off the street and that simply accepts, unquestioningly, whatever the management of the CAA hands it.

He is saying that they are not a bunch of mugs who just accept unquestioningly what the management of the CAA hands them and Mr Macphee has shown that that is exactly what did happen. The CAA management handed them this advice and recommendation which was just accepted by that board.

PARA.TAB: I will go on a little further in that Hansard. Senator Collins then went into a defence of the board and with one of his usual flourishes said, `I'll give you a list and show you what great people they are'. I said to him:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not for a moment doubting the expertise, the competence or the honesty of the board. I just want to know that the board was given the full facts.
Senator Collins said:
Yes, that assurance has been given, I think, three times now by Mr Baldwin. I simply confirm that, but also say that the CAA board is not only a competent but an aggressive board.

My time is running out; my Whip is indicating to me that time is short and I accept that. I do not want to interfere with the running of this chamber. It is a pity that this material is presented on the second last day of the sittings and we are not given the full opportunity to debate it.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I again call on Senator Collins to do the right thing and resign. I join with my colleagues in particularly noting the significant steps that Senator MacGibbon took in this whole procedure and identified the problems right from the start. If only Senator Collins had listened to him in those early days, we would not have had to go through this. Senator MacGibbon deserves congratulations for his role in this matter.

I should also mention my colleagues Senator Lewis; Senator Calvert, on the Public Works Committee; Senator O'Chee; and Senator Bishop, who wanted to make a contribution to this debate today but who is in another committee hearing. I close my contribution to this debate by again paying tribute to Senator MacGibbon's role in this matter and at the same time asking Senator Collins to do the honourable thing and resign because of the mess he has made over this whole sorry saga.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have given my Whip an undertaking that I will only be a couple of minutes, and I shall be only a couple of minutes. There are just a few things I want to say. Firstly, I have repeatedly raised in this Parliament the question of government business enterprises and the contracting arrangements that they enter into. Over a period of many years, certain safety precautions have been put into place when governments enter into contracts in order to make sure that things such as Senator Schacht suggested—that people would say that Ministers were rorting the system—would not happen. When this Government went down the government business enterprise path—not a genuine privatisation—it forgot about those safety precautions. I have warned the Government repeatedly; I still warn it, and I am glad to hear that Senator Schacht says it is a matter which the Government must address. The Government certainly must address it, and privatisation is a matter which our Ministers will have to address as we go down the path of privatisation.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I pose the question: is the Civil Aviation Authority the sort of body that ought to be privatised anyway? It was privatised for one reason, and that was that the Government needed to fix up the salary structure. It could not do that under government arrangements because of the salaries that are paid at government level, so it privatised the authority, fixed up the salary level and was able to employ a chairman at some fabulous salary. He adopted a business approach to this and said, `Let's cut through all the red tape and let's forget about governments and responsibility to the people of Australia and all the rest of it'.

If the Minister goes to the Melbourne airport he should walk around the car park and look at the car parking places that the Civil Aviation Authority people have given themselves. They have taken over the prime car parking positions at the Melbourne airport so that they can park their cars close to the terminal. Members of the public have to park a long way away and walk a longer distance.

TALK.START.PARA: —CAA or FAC?

—I apologise. Senator Collins is quite right, the FAC. That is a typical example of the mind-set, `Because we are running the show, we are entitled to high priority'. Again, I ask Senator Collins: was the Civil Aviation Authority a body that ought to have been privatised? Is that the sort of body that ought to be set into a government business enterprise?

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, I want to mention the abuse by Senator Collins. He ought to be ashamed of himself. He ought to publicly apologise to Senator MacGibbon for what he kept saying to him. I remember that on one occasion I stood up and said, `This smells'. I have a good lawyer's nose and I said, `I don't know a great deal about this, but this smells'. I do not care for any of these parties, I do not represent any of these parties, yet Senator Collins interjected by saying something which implied that in some way or other I was acting as a lobbyist for one of the tenderers, which was quite outrageous at the time. There was nothing I could do about it, except make some personal explanation in the Senate, but it is too late when we get that sort of rough interjection. I say to Senator Collins that there are a number of people in this place that he ought to apologise to, in particular, starting with Senator MacGibbon. I think that Senator Macdonald might be right; the Minister's behaviour in this area is such as to warrant serious consideration as to his entitlement to remain on the front bench.

Finally, I did not know a great deal about this until I started to listen to the questions Senator MacGibbon was asking. I sought information—which Senator Collins could have obtained too—and the moment I started to talk to people about the information, it became clear to me that it was shonky. I raised it in Parliament and got rubbished.

There is another matter going on at the present moment which is shonky. I have raised it in Parliament, and again I have been rubbished. The media will not take any interest in it. Let me tell the Parliament that in the same way that there is something wrong with this particular contract with the CAA, there is something wrong with the accounts of the Brown and Hatton Group and the interests of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the former Minister, Mr John Brown, in it. The Government needs to address it urgently, otherwise there will be an inquiry which will ultimately disclose something about which all Government members will be ashamed.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to bring forward an item scheduled for consideration later on the program.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I present the report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts on physical and sport education, together with the summary of findings and recommendations, the transcript of evidence and submissions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to place on the record at this time my appreciation of the staff, particularly the Secretariat, Mr Keele, Christine and Angela, who so ably assisted the Committee in producing this report in a very short time frame. In particular, I thank my colleagues who have allowed us to address a very constructive issue in a very short time. I seek leave to incorporate the tabling speech in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The report which I have just tabled addresses a crisis in our education system which has allowed physical and sport education to almost disappear from the school curriculum. The Committee has learnt that physical education is being dramatically reduced throughout schools in Australia and that there is a lack of political commitment to address the problems associated with the provision of quality physical education.
The Committee found that the quality and content of physical education, Australia-wide, has declined as a result of such things as:
*the "crowded curriculum" in both primary and secondary schools;
*the inclusion of physical education under the broad umbrella of health education;
*a lack of a coherent physical education policy in any State or Territory;
*the devolution of decision making to local school councils;
*a lack of defined and agreed outcomes for physical education courses compared to other areas of the curriculum;
*a reduction in the number of specialist physical education teachers, particularly in primary schools, and the limited preparation of generalist teachers for physical education;
*a lack of State and Territory education departmental support for teachers supervising physical education;
*a confusion between what is physical education, what is sport education and what is school sport; and
*the use of AUSSIE SPORT and associated sporting programs to justify the withdrawal of physical education from schools.

There is no dispute about the importance of physical education (and school sport as a subset of that), yet there is a serious problem with its delivery. Physical education is an important part of the curriculum because it develops physical skills and contributes to the maintenance of health, fitness and prevention of sickness not only in childhood, but throughout life. Physical education is an educational end in itself, and when properly supervised and taught, can also lead to increased performance in other areas of the curriculum. The emergence of future elite athletes also depends on the provision of quality physical education in schools today.

It is interesting to note that despite the obvious link between physical education and health, the Committee did not receive any submissions from departments of health. (It did receive one submission from the Aboriginal Medical Service in Western Australia)

One of the major concerns highlighted by this report is the development of the proposed national education curriculum. The Committee concluded that the proposed national education curriculum which currently incorporates physical education under Strand 1 of the National Health Learning Area Statement does not adequately reflect the importance of physical education. THE COMMITTEE HAS RECOMMENDED THAT THIS AREA OF THE NATIONAL EDUCATION CURRICULUM BE RETITLED THE NATIONAL EDUCATION STATEMENT ON HEALTH AND PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND THAT PE BE IDENTIFIED AS A SEPARATE STRAND WITHIN THIS.

The Committee was told of widespread community concern about the amount of time and quality of physical education and school sport being offered, especially to our primary school children. THE DEVELOPMENT OF PHYSICAL SKILLS AND HABITS OF FITNESS MUST BE ESTABLISHED AT PRIMARY SCHOOL, and all the evidence before the Committee suggests that this is just not happening. AUSSIE SPORT has been widely accepted throughout the community and in schools, but should complement, not replace, comprehensive and structured physical education programs.

Similarly, the Committee found that Junior Sports Development Officers, who are funded by various sporting associations, can play a very positive role by going into schools and teaching both students and teachers specific sport skills and rules. However, there must be a consistent approach to the role played by these officers. In particular, A UNIFORM CODE OF BEHAVIOUR NEEDS TO BE DEVELOPED FOR THE ROLE OF ALL COMMUNITY MEMBERS WHO ARE INVOLVED IN SCHOOL SPORT.

State and Territory departments of education are responsible for providing all aspects of school based physical education, and the Commonwealth is expected to play a leading role in the development of curriculum and policy. However, the Committee heard in almost every capital city that Departments of sport and recreation, both State and Federal, and community sporting organisations are filling the "physical education gap" left by State and Territory departments of education.

POSITIVE AND COOPERATIVE LINKS BETWEEN DEPARTMENTS OF EDUCATION, DEPARTMENTS OF SPORT AND RECREATION, SPORTING ASSOCIATIONS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES CAN DELIVER QUALITY SPORT EDUCATION AND SCHOOL SPORT, AND THE COMMITTEE BELIEVES THESE LINKS SHOULD BE STRENGTHENED. However, the Committee does not believe that the community should be asked to pick up the pieces left by departments of education, THEREFORE WE HAVE RECOMMENDED THAT THE COMMONWEALTH MONITOR STATE AND TERRITORY RESOURCE ALLOCATIONS FOR PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND GIVE CONSIDERATION TO SPECIFYING A PERCENTAGE OF ITS GRANTS FOR EDUCATION EXCLUSIVELY FOR THE PROVISION OF PHYSICAL EDUCATION IF STATES AND TERRITORIES DO NOT MEET THEIR OBLIGATIONS IN THIS AREA.

PHYSICAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS AT PRIMARY SCHOOLS MUST BE TAUGHT BY TEACHERS WITH APPROPRIATE PHYSICAL EDUCATION SKILLS, however, the Committee found that suitably qualified physical education teachers are not being employed to teach physical education and school sport. There is also evidence to suggest that many teacher training programs are not adequately preparing either generalist teachers or specialist physical education teachers to teach physical education. THE PROVISION OF STRUCTURED AND COMPREHENSIVE PHYSICAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS SHOULD INVOLVE PHYSICAL EDUCATION TEACHERS WHO ARE ABLY SUPPORTED BY THEIR SCHOOL COMMUNITY AND DEPARTMENT OF EDUCATION. Unfortunately in this regard, States and Territory departments of education have wound down or abolished their PE support branches.

Perhaps the most alarming information to be put before the Committee is that children's physical skill levels are poor and declining, children are less fit, more obese, and children's participation in physical education and school sport is declining, especially amongst teenage girls.

THE COMMITTEE FOUND THAT ACCESS AND EQUITY ISSUES NEED TO BE BETTER ADDRESSED IN FUTURE PHYSICAL EDUCATION AND SCHOOL SPORT POLICIES. Not only do girls require greater opportunities, but so too do Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children, children of non-English speaking backgrounds, and children with disabilities.

In the report, THE COMMITTEE DRAWS ATTENTION TO THE NEED FOR MORE QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE RESEARCH TO BE UNDERTAKEN into the levels of fitness and physical skill levels of our children and the participation of girls and boys in, both in and out of school, physical activities. As well, MORE WORK IS REQUIRED IN DEVELOPING AND PROMOTING AGREED AND DEFINED OUTCOMES FROM PHYSICAL EDUCATION COURSES.

Finally, the Committee believes that this report is very timely and that the 40 recommendations it has made provide a realistic and positive strategy which will enable PE to resume its rightful place in the education curriculum.
I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on the implications of United States policies for Australia, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: STATEMENT

On behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I have pleasure in presenting the Committee's Report on the Implications of United States Policies for Australia together with the transcript of evidence. It provides, I believe, a very timely assessment of the impact that the election of a new President and a very substantial turnover in representatives in the United States Congress, is likely to have on Australia.

The inquiry itself has been conducted in a very short time frame. The Senate referred the matter to the Committee on 18 September. Altogether 31 submissions were received. Public hearings were held in the run-up to the U.S. elections.

The evidence canvassed issues of major importance to Australia, both with regard to the policy debates and developments in the United States on economic matters and on the question of security in the Asia-Pacific region.
In tabling the Report, I would like to draw attention to the key conclusions in the report:

First, although there is a widespread expectation of a considerable element of continuity in American policy towards Australia, it would be foolish to underestimate the scope for important, and in many ways unpredictable, change that may confront both Australian and American policy makers during the term of the new President.

Second, the Committee considered that American interest in and understanding of Australia's interests and perspective, cannot be taken for granted, but has to be energetically fostered and encouraged.
It will be a major task for Australia to ensure that the President and his advisers are as well informed of Australia's perspective on issues that matter to Australia as they can be.
President Clinton will be the first in decades not to have had wartime links with the Pacific.

It will also be a major task to ensure that other key players in the United States body politic, players such as Congress, professional and business groups, the media, organised labour, academics, think-tanks and other special interest groups are fully informed of the impact of United States actions on Australia.
There have been tensions in the Australia-United States trade relationship. There is little expectation that these tensions will be resolved in the short term.

Notwithstanding some improvement in the recent past in the prospects of concluding the Uruguay Round of the GATT negotiations, Australia will need to maintain its efforts to improve its bilateral access to United States markets and limit the damage being caused to Australian producers by United States subsidies in third markets.
The Committee has recommended that there be greater emphasis in identifying and working with potential allies within the United States, to protect Australian trade interests.

As the inquiry progressed it also became evident that a factor of utmost importance to Australia is the maintenance of sound United States economic and security links with the Asia Pacific region as a whole.

With one third of its trade already directed to the Asia-Pacific, the United States self-interest in maintaining these links could appear self-evident. However, there is a notable body of opinion that the continued positive relationship of the United States with major countries, especially China, cannot be taken for granted. In the case of Japan, notwithstanding the mutual commitment to the US-Japan security treaty, great care in managing continuing trade tensions will need to be exercised.

Care must be taken to ensure that the consequences and impact of any unilateral United States trade measures on the countries of the region, and China and Japan in particular are fully evaluated. The wider regional effects that may flow from such actions must be fully understood. The Committee recommends that Australia play an active, positive role in ensuring that any dislocation of the current positive elements of the United States' security and economic relationships with Japan and China is avoided.

The Committee agreed with the views of expert witnesses that the APEC forum be developed further energetically. The Committee sees APEC both as a useful tool for further promoting the liberalisation of trade and as a means for reducing the risk of fracture in economic relationships across the Pacific.

The Committee concluded that United States recent and planned defence force reductions in the Asia-Pacific region are not a cause for concern. The evidence put to the Committee that the United States capability is in no way being reduced by changing defence force numbers and forward basing arrangements, was persuasive.

The Committee was, however, concerned that this may not be the view of all regional countries and concluded that Australia needs to be alert to opportunities for reducing regional concerns. One important consideration of course is the potential that such concerns could create for the competitive acquisition of arms by countries of the region. The Committee therefore urged that Australian policy makers review possible ways of drawing the United States into multilateral dialogue on security issues in the Asia-Pacific region.

The Committee concluded that the change in Administration in the United States creates both opportunities and challenges for Australia. It is the Committee's hope that its Report will be of assistance in identifying the opportunities and provide pointers to areas of endeavour that will be of benefit to Australia.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Devereux, on behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports of the Committee: No. 18, Badgerys Creek airport development, stage 1; No. 19, Development of a new international terminal complex at Brisbane airport; No. 20, York Park offices, Barton, ACT; and No. 21, Relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong, New South Wales. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the reports and to have Senator Devereux's tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Devereux's tabling statement
Wednesday 16 December 1992

Mr President, the four reports I have just tabled concludes an extremely busy year for the Committee and particularly in the period since August. The value of the projects in the nine reports that the Committee has tabled this week including five reports on Monday is approximately $750m.
I should acknowledge that today there are two dissenting reports with the Committee being split on party political lines.

In relation to the Badgerys Creek Airport proposal the Committee has recommended that the FAC's Stage 1 proposal not proceed but be replaced by an expanded Stage 1 proposal. The expanded Stage 1 proposal recommended by the Committee should include a 2900 m runway and not a 1800 m runway as proposed by the FAC.

While agreeing that there is a need for a second major airport in the Sydney Basin and that Badgerys Creek is the most suitable location for such an airport the Committee has concluded that the FAC proposal places too much emphasis on passenger demand and does not take account of the potential growth of freight services to the Asia/Pacific region or the scope for industrial growth in the Western Region of Sydney. However the Committee believes that the $152m estimate provided by the FAC for a Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils type proposal is more realistic than the $42.46m estimate provided by the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils.

As I have indicated the Committee believes that the initial development at Badgerys Creek should include a 2900 m runway with the minimum associated infrastructure necessary to allow for both domestic and international operations. This should include the provision of navigational and visual aids and an instrument landing system. Essentially after considering the evidence placed before it the Committee has concluded that the FAC's Stage 1 proposal is inadequate and unlikely to attract potential users.

In recommending that an expanded Stage 1 proposal proceed the Committee has also recommended that the FAC should seek additional Commonwealth funding however should the Government be unwilling to provide the necessary additional funding a consortium including Federal and State Government bodies, local government—through the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils and other interested parties should be formed to develop and operate Badgerys Creek Airport through private funding.
The Committee's nineteenth report relates to the construction of a new international terminal complex at Brisbane Airport.
The out-turn cost of the proposed work is $272m. The Committee has recommended that the work should proceed as planned.
It should be remembered that the Committee, and indeed the Parliament had already approved the preparation of the proposed site, some two kilometres from the new domestic terminal, in 1989.

In arriving at its recommendation that construction should proceed, the Committee examined a number of important matters against the background of the Government's recently announced aviation policy reforms. The siting of the new terminal, the capacity of the existing domestic terminal to handle international flights, two competing terminals and the views of the aviation industry were all examined by the Committee. In fact the Committee considered the various options at great length including the expansion of the existing domestic terminal and a stand alone international terminal.

The terminal design concept has a three-level configuration of 53,000 square metres and will provide seven aerobridge gates, four stand-off positions, four baggage reclaim units and three check-in islands. The main body of the proposed building will be designed to process 1500 passengers per hour, although the initial capacity will be 1065 passengers per hour.

The Federal Airports Corporation assured the Committee that additional aerobridge positions could be added quickly to cater for any increases in demand without disrupting the activity of the terminal.

The proposal for the construction of the York Park Offices for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade on a site in Barton ACT is one that has aroused considerable controversy—indeed the Opposition members on the Committee have dissented from the Committee's report.

However the Committee is satisfied that on the evidence presented to it that the York Park proposal appears to be the most economical of the proposals considered for providing alternative accommodation for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

The Committee concluded that the Administrative Building requires extensive refurbishing to meet current standards for Commonwealth Public Service office accommodation particularly in the areas of fire safety, building services and occupational health and safety.

In relation to the York Park site the Committee believes that it is appropriate for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which is a key policy department to be located close to Parliament House.

The Committee has also recommended that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade continue consultations on a regular basis with staff and staff associations during the design development and construction of the York Park proposal and in particular in relation to the provision of child care facilities. The Committee has recommended that the York Park project proceed at an estimated cost of $186.832m at April 1992 prices.
The final report I have tabled relates to the relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong at an estimated cost of $12.5m.
This is also a project that has aroused some controversy and I acknowledge that the Opposition members have dissented from the Committee's report.

The Australian Hydrographic Office is currently located in unsatisfactory accommodation in Walker Street North Sydney and there was general agreement, that the Australian Hydrographic Office requires new accommodation.

However, the controversy surrounds the issue of loss of staff which may result from the transfer to Wollongong. The Department of Defence advised the Committee that the possible extent of staff losses will not be determined conclusively until all staff have exercised their election to relocate or not. Defence has acknowledged that the production rate of charts could slow for a period during and immediately following the move. However, Defence does not believe that safety of life at sea will be compromised. During the public hearing the Committee was told about the possible loss of key personnel. This argument is always presented when it is suggested that a government department or instrumentality move from a capital city to a decentralised location. It is an argument that I reject, some staff might leave, but then there is always a turnover of staff in any organisation.

The work of the Australian Hydrographic Office could be carried out in almost any location with access to modern communication facilities. The Sydney site at Leichhardt, which the Committee inspected would have a motorway three storeys high cutting through one corner of the block and be directly under the approached flight path of Sydney Airport.
Having considered all the evidence the Committee is satisfied that the relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong will not adversely affect its functions.
I commend the reports to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments on two of those reports, the report on Badgerys Creek airport development, stage 1, and the report on the York Park offices at Barton. In particular, I wish to refer to the report relating to the proposed new Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade offices at Barton, which is just adjacent to the place we are in now.

PARA.TAB: As one of the members of the Public Works Committee from this side of politics who signed the dissenting report accompanying the report that has been tabled, I would like to say that in this day and age when we have a million people out of work and an overseas debt in excess of $200,000m, I do not see how the Government can even contemplate building a Taj Mahal, as it is called in the report—I believe it is affectionately known among other people as a `Gareth Mahal'—at a cost of some $267m, taking into account the refurbishment of the old administration building. This is typical of the attitude that this Labor Party and this Labor Government have to money. There is no doubt that to fund this building the money will have to be borrowed, therefore increasing our overseas debt.

That is a quarter of a billion dollars. I do not know how some honourable senators can go back to their electorates and justify to the unemployed and poverty stricken people there the building of another new structure in Canberra along the lines of the Parliament House we are standing in now at a time of recession engineered by the Prime Minister. The funny thing about it all is that there is a great question over whether it is really needed. When this particular proposal was put to us, involving a cost of $187m just for the sumptuous new offices, one of the reasons put forward for it being needed was that the old building was too cramped. In fact, the Foreign Affairs and Trade Association pointed out in its submission to the Committee that the new building will be about the same size as the one the Department is leaving. I quote from the dissenting report:

SPEECH.PARA: The York Park development is a bigger building than the existing Administrative Building yet provides only the same amount of working area.
That would lead one to suggest, of course, that the building itself was going to be an extravagant building—a bigger building but the same work area, at the cost of $187m!

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a lot of people in the hungry world who would like that.

—Exactly. Coming from the land, as I do, the last thing I would do in the middle of a drought if I had considerable debts would be to go and buy new machinery and put myself further into debt. At a time when, as I said earlier, we have over a million people out of work in this country, another million people who are underemployed, and an overseas debt of huge proportions that is growing every day by $1m, the Government will waste $187m on a sumptuous new structure for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Up until about three years ago, the preferred option was that the old administration building down the road be totally refurbished, including an annex, giving a greater floor space area than the new building would have, at a cost of something like $102m.

PARA.TAB: But no, the Government made a decision—not recommended by anybody—to go ahead with this building. We already know that the office of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) in the old building has been refurbished in the last couple of years at a cost of $240,000. That is just for the Minister's office. He has been in it a handful of times. I know it is used for visiting dignitaries and visiting ambassadors when they come to Australia.

One of the reports says that the two floors—the fourth and fifth floors—of the communications centre were `not in need of refurbishment'. So we have a building which has—as proposed back in 1989—a new annexe which provided 240 extra car spaces and an extra 14,000 square metres. One could take one floor at a time in that new annexe and refurbish the building over a period of time. That was the original proposal. It was approved, no problem at all, and out of the blue, because the Government wished to build another edifice to its great 10 years in office, it is to waste $187m plus another $80m on top of that to refurbish the old building—a total of $267m—so it can put the employees of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in another building of the same size.

On the other report concerning the Badgerys Creek airport development, there is not enough money in the kitty to build a full length airstrip. The Government cannot afford the extra $40m or $50m. The Badgerys Creek airport has great ramifications for trade, freight and infrastructure in Sydney. There, the Government has to go for the cheap option—a 1,800 metre runway—because it does not have the money, yet in this case we can throw in $267m for a new Taj Mahal here in Canberra.

I pay credit to the Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councils which lobbied very strongly to increase the length of the runway. In fact, the Committee has recommended that the initial development should provide a 2,900 metre runway as against the 1,800 metre runway that is proposed by the FAC. Again, we believe it is short-sighted. WESROC, as it is affectionately known, believes it is short-sighted. The new airport is in the best interests of the western Sydney region. We agreed with the proposals put forward by WESROC. It will promote growth in the area and expand the trade between Australia and the Asia-Pacific region. It is not only a freight runway but an alternative to Kingsford-Smith Airport.

I return to the York Park Offices. Earlier today someone said what a great job the Public Works Committee did on the York Park Offices report. I am disappointed that two of my colleagues, who very vocally opposed the York Park building, were heavied and leant upon at the last minute to change their opinion. As of last night, one of the members of the Committee who was going to put in his own dissenting report was pressured into not doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Heavied by whom?

—He was heavied by the same person who heavied Senator Collins over the previous report, the same person he tangled with. The Chairman persuaded two members of the Committee who were going to present a majority report not to do so when it looked as if the Chairman would have to present a minority report. At the end of the day, the numbers came out the other way. I guess that is politics. The point I am trying to make is that most members of the Committee, at one point or another, had grave misgivings about this project—and we still do, as do members on the other side. I point out that at this time in Australia's economic history, this is an extravagance that we can do without.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT HOUSE DEPARTMENT: PUBLIC LIABILITY CLAIM

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill raised an issue with me at the end of Question Time. On 25 April, the Speaker had an accident outside the parliamentary precinct on a bicycle which was hired from the Health and Recreation Centre. The Speaker subsequently sued the Commonwealth for negligence. I did not approve the claim, nor could I legally do so. The matter was handled between the Speaker's solicitors and the Commonwealth law officers, the Australian Government Solicitor. The quantum of the settlement was recommended by the Australian Government Solicitor, not the Joint House Department or the Speaker. If, indeed, a senator made a similar claim against the Department of the Senate this would be a departmental matter and, similarly, I would not be involved.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins—He lost the use of a third of his arm.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the President's statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, your very brief statement raises more questions than it answers. You will not be surprised to hear me say that. We have heard an intervention from Senator Collins who said that, as he understands it, the Speaker has lost the use of a third of his arm in this accident. I do not think, Mr President, that in your statement you even confirmed that $65,000 was the amount of damages.

TALK.START.PARA: —The figure that was printed in the report is correct. There were three claims and that was one of them.

—If I heard you correctly—you seemed to read the statement very quickly—the accident occurred outside the parliamentary precinct. I might ask you whether that is correct. One of the questions I asked earlier today was: what was the basis of the claim? I presume from what you are saying that it was alleged that it was a claim as a result of faulty equipment provided by the Parliament. Why was faulty equipment being used by the Speaker outside the precincts of the Parliament? It seems a very strange situation. If the equipment has been provided by the Parliament, we obviously have an interest in it. We would very much like to know the nature of the fault in this equipment.

PARA.TAB: The rumour around the building—I do not know whether it is correct—is that it was an exercise bike. Mr President, are you saying that the exercise bikes in this building—I gather there are some in the gym—are faulty? If so, what was the fault? Another rumour going around the building is that the Speaker actually assembled this bike outside of the building. I would be interested to know whether that is so. This is really quite an incredible situation.

As I understand the structure, you, Mr President, and the Speaker are in effect the joint heads of this Department. One of the joint heads of the Department has actually been paid a substantial sum of money. It is one thing to say that the Commonwealth Solicitor made a recommendation, but presumably the head of the Department has to authorise the payment, or somebody has to authorise the payment from the Department, and you do not seem to have told us who did so in this instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the question.
—That was one of the specific questions which I asked.
—It was never brought to the attention of the Joint House Committee.

—As Senator Knowles said, it was not brought to the attention of the Joint House Committee. I would have thought that an accident which involved parliamentary equipment would have been brought to the attention of the Committee; it is astonishing that it was not. I know that we have to protect privacy in these matters, but we also have a responsibility to the public to be satisfied that public money is being correctly expended. In these astonishing circumstances of the head of the Department being paid damages, one would have thought that not only would it have been brought to the attention of the Committee but also it would have been stated in the report that it was an office-bearer of the Parliament and the head of the Department who was being paid these damages. But the report did not say that at all.

PARA.TAB: Presumably, the answer will be one of privacy, but I do not think that is a satisfactory answer in this instance. One suspects, rather, there was an intention that it not become known that this occurred. Also, whilst I am hesitant to say it because of the privacy aspect, in this instance the answer is so unsatisfactory that people have to know what the injury was for which damages are being paid.

Also, what medical advice was given? What was the assessment? At the very least, the legal advice that the departmental heads received—you, Mr President and the Speaker in this instance—should also be made public That will presumably be supported by medical advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Speaker contribute to his own injury?

—The question of contributory negligence has not been addressed but this comes into play if the Speaker did assemble this bike outside of the building. These exercise bikes do not normally collapse. And if I know anything about this building, the Joint House Department purchases somewhat expensive equipment. I cannot imagine that it would be anything other than an exercise bike of very high quality, like everything else in this building.
—It apparently occurred on Anzac Day.

—It occurred on Anzac Day! Mr President, I do not think your statement is satisfactory. It raises more questions than it answers. You have obviously decided not to specifically answer the questions that we raised in Question Time. You have not told us who authorised the payment in the Department. I think you said that you did not authorise it.

PARA.TAB: You have not told us whether you were a party to the negotiations or what knowledge you had of the matter. At Question Time I was amazed that you, as the joint head of this Department, could not immediately give us these details. It is, after all, $65,000 of taxpayers' money.

In this brief contribution, Mr President, I have asked you a whole series of further questions to which I respectfully request answers. I would ask you whether the Department will make available the legal opinions upon which the assessment of damages and liability was made. I think the best thing is that I allow you the opportunity to think about this, but you will not be surprised to hear that we do not intend to let it rest at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to Senator Hill, I will get a copy of what he said and I will go right through it. At one stage, I think Senator Hill sought to infer that somehow I had something to do with this claim or that evidence to do with this claim was given to me. I totally reject that. I had nothing to do with it at all. I did not approve the claim. I am not legally allowed to do so. I do not remember even seeing a claim.

PARA.TAB: As I said, the matter was handled between the Speaker's solicitor and the Commonwealth law officers of the Australian Government Solicitor. I will get you answers to the questions that you have raised. I will have to get those from the Speaker and from the Joint House Department because I do not have them at the top of my head. I just went and saw the Clerk and said, `What would happen if a Senator made a similar claim?' He said, `It would be dealt with as a departmental matter. It would never come across your desk'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it seems that I have been an absolute galah because, quite frankly, the lift did not stop level with the floor when I was getting out. I tripped and fell getting out of the lift. As a result, I needed a minor operation on my knee. It was not an extensive operation. But at no stage did it occur to me to make a claim against the Commonwealth or the taxpayers.

PARA.TAB: It seemed that the morally correct thing to do was to blame myself for not being sensible enough to lift my feet and to make sure that the passage out of the lift was adequate. I considered it was my fault that I did not lift my feet properly or high enough to overcome the problem of the lift and the floor not being level. And the attendants who helped me up would verify that what I am saying is correct.

At no stage did it occur to me that I should sue the Commonwealth because I did not have the commonsense to lift my feet high enough to overcome the problem that was obviously before me. I am absolutely astounded that the Speaker—

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely Senator Collins does not agree that the Speaker would sue the Government.
—It is not what I said. I expressed concern about your being hurt because I had not heard of that incident.

—Why would you? It was my fault. I do not go telling everybody that I got hurt because I was silly not to lift my feet enough. But I am astounded that the Speaker would sue the Commonwealth for $65,000 when obviously there was some contributory negligence on his part. I also would very much like to hear the detail of why he would consider it was morally correct for him to do something that I consider would be completely immoral for me to do.

—Mr President, I do not want to enter this debate in a very substantive way but just to take slight issue with my friend Senator Walters. For example, if I was stepping out of a lift at 3 o'clock yesterday morning and the lift was not quite level with the floor and I tripped, I do not know that that would have been entirely my fault because, as the Senate may have observed, the late sittings have been such that I have not been terribly responsible for some of my actions.

PARA.TAB: The other day I found myself sitting in a division on a Bill which I did not intend to vote against. That was a Bill to reduce income tax. I have not and never will vote against legislation which reduces income tax. So I had to get up and explain my situation. TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal with the report relating to the relocation of the Australian Hydrographic Office to Wollongong, New South Wales. Having had a long association with the Illawarra region as my office is in Wollongong, naturally I am keen to see anything that will alleviate the high levels of unemployment in the Illawarra region. I have a concern, however, that Wollongong should not receive unfair treatment ahead of other areas with massive unemployment, for example, the Newcastle region, which I understood was one of the three location options put to the Minister when this whole proposition of moving from the present north Sydney premises was first raised.

PARA.TAB: The three locations were Leichhardt in Sydney, Wollongong and Newcastle. According to the report, these were subjected to detailed financial evaluations using discounted cash flow techniques. The aim was to determine the financial attractiveness of the options by comparing receipts and expenditures with a view to generating a net cash flow over a 12-year period and which, when discounted back, would yield a discounted net present cost.

The figures I had seen from the Navy many months ago indicated that Newcastle was a far cheaper option than Wollongong. It was on that basis that I reluctantly said that it seemed to me to be unfair to give Wollongong this project ahead of Newcastle as both had suffered the same social and economic disasters and that a judgment had to be made based on where the greatest benefit would accrue for the least cost.

Strangely, this report does not further mention Newcastle at all. There is no indication of how it relates to the cost. All we find out is that, if the Department were to select Leichhardt over Wollongong, the Department would be $1.8m better off over 12 years. In other words, it is cheaper to move it to Sydney than to send it to Wollongong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is it now?
—This report recommends that it go to Wollongong.
—Where from?

—From Sydney. In present net value terms, the report says that, having regard to the time value of money, the difference between Leichhardt and Wollongong, which is about $150,000 per year to the disadvantage of the Department, is considered to be marginal in the context of the benefits produced by the organisation. My concern is this: why is it up to the Department of Defence to provide funding for what is a good purpose, that is, to provide assistance in alleviating unemployment in Wollongong? Why is it not open to the Government through its other funding mechanisms to provide that sort of assistance if it needs it? Why does this report totally ignore the Newcastle option which, on the original figures, was far cheaper than the Wollongong option? All I want is for Wollongong to get this on its merits or else for it to be funded by a proper funding structure by way of specific assistance. It is grossly improper for decisions of this kind to be made for what appear to be political reasons if there are good, social and sound—
—That is why we voted against it.

—Yes, but on the other hand I think it is proper for the Government to look at providing specific assistance to projects like this if it wants to put them there for sound social reasons. There is a sound social reason for this office going to Wollongong, but it should not be done at the expense of the Defence Department. It should be as a result of deliberate and determined policy decisions by the Government out of funds specifically appropriated for the purpose. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Loosley, I present the report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on scrutiny by the Committee of regulations imposing United Nations sanctions.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the customary brief statement relating to the work of the Committee during the Budget sittings of 1992.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Statement on work of Committee during Budget Sitting 1992
Overview

During these sittings the Committee continued its non-partisan scrutiny of disallowable instruments of delegated legislation tabled in the Senate. In the course of the sittings the Committee scrutinised 978 such instruments, making a total of 1,754 scrutinised this year. This was a record, both for the sittings and for the calendar year. Less than one quarter of the instruments were in the Statutory Rules series, which are generally superior in drafting, access and presentation to other types of delegated legislation. This confirms a trend which has been evident for some years.

As usual, the Committee scrutinised each one of these instruments to ensure compliance with its four principles which cover all aspects of personal rights and parliamentary propriety. Where the Committee had concerns with an instrument it wrote to the Minister responsible for the legislation. On a number of occasions it also required further information from Ministers after receiving an initial reply. It also gave 15 notices of motion of disallowance of individual instruments, in order to preserve its option to recommend this action to the Senate. However, the Committee is pleased to report that it received a good level of cooperation from Ministers, who undertook to amend 22 instruments to meet its concerns.
The concerns raised by the Committee are described below under each of the four principles which constitute its terms of reference.
Principle (a)
Is delegated legislation in accordance with the statute?

This principle is interpreted broadly by the Committee to cover all aspects of parliamentary propriety apart from whether a provision is more appropriate for parliamentary enactment, which is the Committee's fourth principle. Thus, the committee scrutinises every aspect of parliamentary propriety.

The Committee always checks the legal validity of instruments. Four instruments appeared to incorporate provisions of the laws of foreign countries as amended from time to time, which may not have been possible under the parent Act. Another instrument invalidly incorporated an external publication as in force from time to time.

The Committee is concerned that the quality of drafting and presentation of delegated legislation should not be inferior to that which is reflected in Acts. This standard is generally met by the Statutory Rules, drafted by the specialist Office of Legislative Drafting. However, the quality of instruments drafted by other agencies is often below this standard. The Committee questioned imprecise and unclear drafting, obsolete expressions and inaccuracies in references to other provisions.

The Committee ensures that all procedural formalities are complete, even if these are not legal requirements. Numbers of instruments were not accompanied by Explanatory Statements, others had no system of numbering or citation, and others were missing attachments. In one case an umbrella provision at the end of a set of amending regulations renumbered the entire Principal Regulations. This was a helpful initiative, but the Committee suggested, equally helpfully, that a reprint of the Principal Regulations was now required.

The Committee ensures that an instrument effects its intended purpose as expressed in the Explanatory Statement or as evident from its provisions. One instrument made new provisions without repealing the old. The Explanatory Statement for another advised that its purpose was to make two discretions subject to AAT review, but the instrument only included one discretion. The Explanatory Statement for another advised that its purpose was to increase fees by the cost of living for the last two years, but the increase in one fee was 87%, in another 50% and another 33%.

Any power to delegate in delegated legislation should be as narrow, limited and specific as possible. Under one instrument a decision maker could delegate important powers to any person at all, while under another a major government business enterprise could delegate powers to any employee, no matter how junior. In another case, the Committee asked for an assurance that power to authorise medical treatment to certain persons without their consent could not be delegated.

Any legislative powers provided by delegated legislation should, where appropriate, be subject to tabling and possible disallowance. One set of amending regulations provided for determinations, declarations, directions, permits, signs, authorities, approvals and lists, some of which were certainly legislative but none of which were subject to disallowance.

The Committee always questions a long period of retrospectivity, even if no person other than the Commonwealth is prejudiced. In one instrument members of a statutory authority were paid expenses with more than two years retrospectivity. Another instrument reflected an amendment of the parent Act which had been in operation for more than two years.
Principle (b)
Does delegated legislation trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties?

There is no part of the work of the Committee more important than the protection of personal rights. The Committee interprets in the broadest possible way its mandate to ensure that delegated legislation does not breach personal rights.

The Committee ensures that penalties, taxes and fees are neither harsh nor unreasonable. One instrument increased a penalty from $500 to $5000 with no explanation for the increase in the Explanatory Statement. Another instrument increased a levy with no explanation in the Explanatory Statement whether the purpose of the increase was to raise money, recover costs, deter use, or for some other reason. Another instrument was drafted in such a way that the amount, the imposition and the collection of a fine were all uncertain.

Government business enterprises should treat their customers fairly and equitably. One Explanatory Statement advised that the reason for a progressive increase in fees for applications for certain exemptions was to deter users. The Committee considered that this discouragement of a legislative right could have been a penalty. Another instrument required payment in advance except for regular users with a good record of payment on time. Another instrument provided that long established refunds for certain charges would no longer be paid.

Statutory authorities should not impose harsh conditions on the public. One instrument provided that straying livestock and other animals could be impounded and destroyed with inadequate opportunity for their owners to claim them.

The Committee always questions prejudicial retrospectivity, even in the rare cases where it is legally valid. However, the Committee also questioned one instrument which corrected an oversight for public servants but which did not provide for retrospective operation. Here the Committee considered that the lack of retrospectivity was prejudicial.

The Committee always protects personal privacy. One instrument provided for wide disclosures of personal information to law enforcement and security organisations with no indication that the agency had sought the views of the Privacy Commissioner. Another provided for the mandatory collection of detailed personal information about employees, which may not have been relevant to the stated purpose of its collection.
Principle (c)
Does delegated legislation make rights unduly dependent on administrative decisions which are not subject to independent review of their merits?

The Committee was concerned at a number of instruments which did not provide for merits review of decisions where it may have been appropriate to do so. These included decisions under discretions which conferred power to waive, vary or reduce fees; grant public service allowances; permit public gatherings; extend a time limit for applications; exempt a person from general prohibitions; enable costs to be taxed; grant benefits; pay interest at a particular rate; and control exports. In all these cases the Committee received from Ministers either an undertaking to amend the instrument to provide AAT review, or a satisfactory explanation of the provision.

The Committee raised with Ministers other issues about merit review. In one case it asked for more information about the powers and functions of internal review panels and in others it asked for an assurance that AAT review provisions in the parent Act covered the regulations as well.

The Committee is more vigilant about merit review where the exercise of a discretion is not guided and controlled by objective criteria. It must be. One instrument included subjective criteria such as "the honesty of the applicant" and "the likely efficiency of the proprietor".

The Committee scrutinises review provisions more closely where the discretion is wide and imprecise. One instrument set out detailed objective calculations for amounts which the Minister could determine. However, it then provided that an amount could be "such other amount as the Minister may determine".
Principle (d)
Does delegated legislation contain matters more appropriate for parliamentary enactment?

The Committee raises this principle less often than it raises other principles. However, it is a principle which goes to the heart of parliamentary propriety and as such complements the first principle of the Committee, that an instrument should be in accordance with the statute.

The Committee raised the principle in respect of an instrument which transferred important powers to the government of Norfolk Island. These powers included the maintenance of law and order and the administration of justice; the whole of private law; corporate affairs; regulation of businesses and professions; child, family and social welfare; industry; and mining. The Committee noted that the transfer of similar powers to the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory had been largely implemented by Act.

The Committee also raised the principle when instruments modified, repealed and suspended the operation of Western Australian Acts in their application to Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. In addition, one of the modifications included a "Henry VIII" provision or, in other words, a provision under which delegated legislation may amend an Act.
The above instruments were all legally valid. However, the importance of their provisions was such that they may have been more appropriately included in a Bill and debated in Parliament.
Other Developments
In addition to its core work of scrutinising delegated legislation, the Committee was active in other ways during the Budget sittings.

The Committee tabled two Reports during the sittings, the 92nd and 93rd Reports. The first was on Committee scrutiny of Public Service Determinations 1992/27 and 1992/46, where the Committee found that the Department of Industrial Relations, without proper consultation, effectively entrenched an injustice for some 30,000 former members of the Australian Public Service. The Determinations did not take into account strong recommendations by the Merit Protection and Review Agency that what it described as an "unfair and inequitable" situation should be addressed. Following intervention by the Committee and prompt and helpful cooperation from the Minister for Industrial Relations, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance the matter was resolved by a one line Budget appropriation. The second Report examined the 19 sets of regulations which implemented Australia's obligation to impose United Nations sanctions on Iraq, Kuwait, Libya and Yugoslavia. The Report concluded that it was appropriate to provide for sanctions by regulation rather than by Act.

Senator Loosley also made a special statement on scrutiny of the Australian Postal Corporation Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1992 No.132, which presented problems about possible breaches of privacy.

In suitable cases, the Committee invites departmental officials to attend meetings to brief it on matters of interest. Three officers of the Department of Transport and Communications attended to discuss the amendments of the Australian Postal Corporation Regulations; two officers of the Federal Office of Road Safety assisted with the Australian Design Rules; and the Public Service Commissioner, Mr Denis Ives, and another officer, briefed the Committee on a review of the Public Service Act and regulations.

The Committee made a submission to the inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs into Commonwealth legislative drafting. The Committee also responded to the Administrative Review Council Report on rule making by Commonwealth agencies.

A delegation from the Western Australian Joint Standing Committee on Delegated Legislation visited the Committee to discuss matters of mutual interest. Senator Mal Colston, a member and former Chairman of the Committee, chaired a four hour meeting with the Western Australians, which the Clerk of the Senate, the Legal Adviser, the secretary and others also attended.

The Committee has asked the Legal Adviser to prepare a paper and brief it on the operations of the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977. It has also asked for a paper on the implications for delegated legislation of the use of rulings by the Commissioner of Taxation.

On 20 August 1992 the then Chair, Senator Patricia Giles, resigned from the Committee to represent the Australian Parliament at the United Nations General Assembly. The Committee benefited from her wise counsel during her two years as Chair and seven years as a member, during a period when the Committee had increasing responsibilities. Senator Loosley was then elected as Chairman.

During the sittings the Committee secretary was absent on compassionate leave for six weeks and the Deputy Clerk, Anne Lynch, acted as secretary. It is a compliment to the Committee that the Deputy Clerk, a former secretary of the Committee, considered that its work was sufficiently important and challenging for an officer of her stature to undertake the duties of secretary.
The Committee also records its appreciation for the work of its independent Legal Adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan.
The Committee is grateful for the support which it has received from all Senators during the past sittings.

I will then move—
