As happened with deeming, this savings provision will mean that people with identical incomes and in identical circumstances will be treated differently under the Social Security Act.

The Budget decision to move forward the indexation of pensions and benefits from 20 March 1993 to 28 January 1993 is a poorly disguised, politically motivated bribe in the run-up to the next Federal election. That maybe gives us some clues as to the election date. Single pensioners will receive $6 per fortnight increase while married pensioners will receive $10 per fortnight increase. These pale into insignificance compared with the Fightback commitment to increase the single pension by $24.10 per fortnight and the married pension by $40.20 per fortnight and maintain indexation.

The Government also announced in the Budget that the fringe benefits income test for pensioners would be removed. In theory this would mean all part rate pensioners would become eligible for the fringe benefits provided by local councils and State governments as well as the Federal Government. However, the vast majority of these benefits are provided by the States and this initiative is dependent upon obtaining the agreement of the States about appropriate compensation.

Undoubtedly the initiative in this Bill which has engendered most debate is the Budget decision to treat capital gains and losses from listed shares and securities as income under the Social Security Act. Community opinion in relation to this proposal is divided. On the one hand, leading retirement incomes expert Mr Daryl Dixon supports the initiative, claiming it will reduce the artificial distortions that presently favour some investments over others. The Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Foundation is `generally supportive of the changes themselves' as they will treat people consistently. However, it is concerned about what it perceives to be their retrospective effect. On the other hand, ACOA, the Australian Council on the Ageing, is opposed to the initiative for a number of reasons. Its chief concern relates to its belief that it is a de facto assets test which entails an unacceptably harsh pension withdrawal rate.

A number of points must be made about this proposal. First, it must be remembered that the Government estimates that 60,000 people will be affected by this initiative. This represents 5 per cent of all age pensioners. One-third of these pensioners will have a reduction of less than $10 a week. The Government has stressed that a relatively small percentage of pensioners will be adversely affected to any significant extent by this initiative.

Secondly, it needs to be pointed out that this proposal brings the treatment of listed shares into line with other types of investments such as managed linked investments. In 1988, the Government moved to prevent pensioners from circumventing the incomes test by treating unrealised capital gains from these investments as income. This proposal will rid the system of the current distortion whereby managed investments and listed shares are treated differently under the income test.

Thirdly, in relation to concerns about the retrospectivity of the proposal, it must be pointed out that the Government has decided to apply the new rules from September 1993. This will give shareholders significant time to change their investments if they so wish.

Finally, it should be noted that there remains at least one investment avenue that will continue to be outside the unrealised income test. Income on property is treated on a receipt basis rather than an accrual basis. The Department claims that property has to be treated differently as it is a lumpy investment which usually must be sold as a whole rather than in portions. However, this does not mean that the Department should not be vigilant in ensuring that valuations of property investments are accurate and up to date. This has not always been the case in the past. In fact, one only has to look at the ANAO report in an efficiency audit released in June 1991 to see that this has not always been the case. It should be noted that the Government moved to rectify this situation in the 1991 Budget.

The coalition will support the divisions of the legislation relating to the treatment of unrealised capital gains on listed shares and securities under the income tests. However, I must stress, and it must be remembered, that these amendments will only take effect from September 1993. Consequently, I give notice—and again stress—that the coalition will review these provisions when in government.

The coalition is concerned about the mechanics of this proposal. In particular, we are concerned that the proposed formula to be used may not treat capital gains and capital losses equitably and fairly.

The coalition is also concerned about the amendments in the Bill which will mean that both unrealised capital gains and income applying to allocated pensions will be treated as earned income for the purposes of the age pension assets and income test. The ISC has recently developed rules which expand the definition of annuities in such a way as to include allocated pensions.

Unfortunately, these proposed amendments to the Social Security Act, by denying allocated pensions the same treatment already given to annuities in the income and assets test, may undo that good work and fly in the face of the stated policy of encouraging allocated pensions.

In the evidence to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation the Department admitted a `similarity' between annuities and allocated pensions and advised that it would undertake a review of the treatment of annuities. Given that this proposal has not been the subject of any coordinated review to ensure equity of treatment, the coalition will move in the committee stage to delay the onset of these amendments until 1 October 1993 or until the completion of a further inquiry by an appropriate Senate committee, whichever is the latter. Otherwise, the coalition supports these two Budget Bills, and the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill, although we are extremely concerned about the hasty way that they have been forced through the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I intend to confine my rather short remarks to the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1992. I preface my remarks by quoting from the beginning of Justice Toohey's judgment in the recent High Court case known as Bushell's case, which was delivered on 7 October of this year, only a few weeks ago. Justice Toohey stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The history of legislative attempts to provide a satisfactory formula for the determination of claims for service-related incapacities has not been a happy one. A glance at the index to the series, Administrative Law Decisions, under the heading "Veterans' Affairs", gives some idea of the amount of litigation the relevant legislation has spawned.

The reason I have risen to speak in this debate is that I believe that over the last 10 years or so there have been very strong attempts by the Repatriation Commission to subvert the longstanding intentions of Parliament in favour of claims for war-caused injuries by veterans. In fact, over these years the High Court has continuously by its several decisions supported the intention of Parliament, yet in these years the Government has supported the attempts of the Repatriation Commission to change that longstanding tradition. Fortunately—and I commend the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, who is at the table—the Government has now got up some courage of its own and has been standing up to the pressures and blandishments that it has clearly been receiving from the Commission.

PARA.TAB: The Bill we are debating is yet another classic and the most gross example of all of these legislative attempts which Justice Toohey has referred to as being `not a happy one'. The Bill purports, as previous Bills have, to change the law from the way it has been interpreted by the High Court, and to change it certainly from what has been the longstanding intention of Parliament. This Bill is the last and the worst example of that attempt.

However, the Bill has already been sent to the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As a result of the hearings of that Committee, the Government has now retreated extensively, if not comprehensively, from the position presented to this Parliament in the form of the Bill, the second reading of which we are debating. So I am perfectly entitled to make comments upon the Bill as presented to us. However, the Government has now presented amendments which amount to a massive reversal of what was attempted by the Government in the first place.

Nevertheless, because of the history of these years, the veteran community is still very suspicious and very concerned about the effect even of the Government's amendments, which on the face of it are really a major reversal of the proposals in the Bill as they have been presented to us. I can understand therefore the veteran community wanting more time to fully consider it, because it has every reason not to trust this Government and certainly not to trust the Repatriation Commission in relation to the vital issue of its war-caused disabilities or death.

Therefore, I will certainly be supporting the motion that has already been moved by my colleague, Senator Newman, to defer further consideration of this Bill, after the second reading debate, so that this matter can be properly considered by what is going to be a summit meeting of the veteran community early in February next year. It seems to be only fair to them, as a result of their deep and justified concerns—

DEBATE.TITLE: DATA-MATCHING PROGRAM (ASSISTANCE AND TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1992SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only fair that this chamber, and I hope the Government, will not oppose the proposal that this matter should be further adjourned to enable the veteran community to at least satisfy itself that this long and sorry history of legislative attempts to reverse its basic rights and traditions is not going to be further eroded by the latest amendments put forward by the Government.

PARA.TAB: The issue at stake here is really the question of how it is proved and what is the standard of proof as required for what is called the causation issue in relation to claims by veterans. That is, the veterans have to prove a number of things: that there has been the incident of their war service and that they have an injury or death has occurred. Proving the incident may also be a problem, but the major problem is the issue of causation; whether the injury or death that has been proved has in fact been caused by war service. That is the issue which has been the predominant issue in this line of legislative changes and the High Court and other court decisions over a period now of about 10 years.

My attention has been drawn to a very potted history of veterans' affairs legislation as set out in the explanatory memorandum to the legislation. I want to address myself to that because one can only understand the nature of the present problem and the concerns of the veterans community if we know something about the history of this matter. Since 1929, repatriation legislation has given particular favour to the veterans in their attempts to prove their cases for compensation. The nature of that favour has changed from time to time, but there has always been what is called the benefit of the doubt to which the veteran or his dependant is entitled. Because of the time constraints, I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard the state of the legislation of the Repatriation Act from 1943 through to 1977 in section 47(1).
Leave granted.

47. (1) The Commission, a Board, an Appeal Tribunal and an Assessment Appeal Tribunal, in hearing, determining or deciding a claim, application or appeal, shall act according to substantial justice and the merits of the case, shall not be bound by technicalities or legal forms or rules of evidence and shall give to the claimant, applicant or appellant the benefit of any doubt—
(a)as to the existence of any fact, matter, cause or circumstance which would be favourable to the claimant, applicant or appellant; or

(b)as to any question whatsoever (including the question whether the incapacity from which the member of the Forces is suffering or from which he has died was contributed to in any material degree, or was aggravated, by the conditions of his war service) which arises for decision under his claim, application or appeal.

(2) It shall not be necessary for the claimant, applicant or appellant to furnish proof to support his claim, application or appeal but the Commission, Board, Appeal Tribunal or Assessment Appeal Tribunal determining or deciding the claim, application or appeal shall be entitled to draw, and shall draw, from all the circumstances of the case, from the evidence furnished and from medical opinions, all reasonable inferences in favour of the claimant, applicant or appellant, and in all cases whatsoever the onus of proof shall lie on the person or authority who contends that the claim, application or appeal should not be granted or allowed to the full extent claimed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I quote briefly from the gravamen of this statutory provision, which stood in this legislation for 34 years. That would cover a great deal of the claims of First World War veterans and, indeed, some Second World War veterans. The Act says:

PARA.TAB: (2) It shall not be necessary for the claimant . . . to furnish proof to support his claim . . . the Commission, Board, Appeal Tribunal . . . application . . . shall be entitled to draw, and shall draw, from all the circumstances of the case, from the evidence furnished and from medical opinion, all reasonable inferences in favour of the claimant, applicant or appellant, and in all cases whatsoever the onus of proof shall lie on the person or authority who contends that claim, . . . should not be granted or allowed to the full extent claimed.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think the Department, or whoever is the author of this explanatory memorandum, knows that the Repatriation Commission, at some stage in the 1950s or 1960s, received an opinion from the Attorney-General of the day—who, incidentally, was Sir Garfield Barwick—that the proper interpretation of this provision was, in effect, that the Commission had to disprove the claim; not just on the balance of probabilities, not just on any benefit of a doubt, but beyond reasonable doubt.

PARA.TAB: That opinion was well known to the veterans' community, as I am only too well aware, because I became the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in 1976 and the Toose report had been brought down and my main responsibility was, on behalf of the Government, to implement the Toose report. It was made perfectly clear to me that the veterans community knew all about this and expected that that was its right; that the veterans were entitled to the requirement that the Commission had to disprove their claim beyond reasonable doubt. Although Toose did not actually recommend that formula, we were not in the business of taking anything away from the veteran community and nor was Mr Justice Toose. In redrafting the legislation, we gave the right of proof beyond reasonable doubt, which is now enshrined in the Act, to veterans. It is that particular matter which this Repatriation Commission, in the last decade or so, has been absolutely determined to modify and hopefully reverse. That is my major complaint and the reason why I am speaking here tonight.

In 1977, or thereabouts, in accordance with the recommendations of Mr Justice Toose, but not contained in the same Bill, we introduced for the first time a right of appeal on a question of law from the administrative tribunals, which determine these things and still do, to the Federal Court and ultimately to the High Court. That is where all of this litigation has occurred, as mentioned by Mr Justice Toohey. Indeed, there have been three landmark decisions of the High Court in relation to these matters.

The first case was that of Mrs Law in 1981, the second being the case of Mr O'Brien in 1985 and the most recent case being that of Mr Bushell. The interesting thing about all of these cases is that the facts of them all clearly exemplify why Parliament wanted to give this benefit of the doubt. In the case of Mrs Law, her husband died from lung cancer and the opinion in her favour was none other than Sir Weary Dunlop. What tribunal would not accept, on the case of a prisoner of war, the opinion of Sir Weary Dunlop? There was ample evidence to prove the case, but the Repatriation Commission fought the case bitterly right through to the High Court and, of course, the High Court rolled the Commission comprehensively, and so it should have, because of the state of the evidence.

In the case of Mr O'Brien, there was perhaps some criticism that could be made about some remarks of the majority judges of the High Court, and it was in the dissenting opinion of Mr Justice Brennan that the Department found some comfort and which has been the basis of the recent legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! When the debate began, I indicated that I understood that informal arrangements had been made to complete the consideration of these Bills within an hour and I indicated that when the time had expired, the Chair would remind the Senate of this agreement. I am so reminding the Senate.
—I have not gone as long as several other speakers. After wasting that amount of time, can I just get on and try to finish as soon as I can?

PARA.TAB: In the case of O'Brien, there was a very clear conflict of expert medical opinion. Whether or not the decision was correctly made, and whether or not the majority of the High Court was correct, the fact is that it is precisely the sort of case to which this long legislative history is directed. One does not decide these things as in a court of law. That was the trouble in the O'Brien case. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal thought it had to weigh up the medical evidence, as it would do if it were in a court. But that is not the test. The test is whether or not there is a reasonable doubt which has to be resolved in favour of the claimant. Bushell's case, of all cases, is probably the most striking example of that exercise. Again, there is conflict of specialist medical evidence, and again the results of all the legal appeals, and the High Court decision, were totally consistent with what has always been the intention of this Parliament in this legislation.

That is why I am so concerned by the continual efforts that are being made to reverse that longstanding policy by this Government, no doubt at the instigation of the Repatriation Commission. The Law case was decided when we were still in Government, and we were pressed pretty closely by all the same sort of `shock, horror' about the cost of the things that were presented to us. At least we did not fall for it in government and try to reverse the Law case. But this Government has continually tried to reverse these decisions, which ultimately have been made by the High Court and which the Government does not like. Ultimately, we have these amendments here today which are really a naked attempt not just to ameliorate the High Court decision but to reverse that longstanding standard of proof and onus on the Commission to disprove the claim of the veteran.

I would like to have had time to delve deeper into all the reasons I am making these very strong criticisms of the Commission. I do not propose to do so tonight, but I wish to show where the High Court has ultimately come down on what has been the longstanding intention of Parliament, going back to 1929 and, in its present form, at least to 1943. Even if it is going to cost more money, there is no reason why veterans should be deprived of what has been a longstanding right. Tomorrow we are likely to be debating the dispatch of another battalion to a high-risk situation—Somalia. Only two years ago we were sending our naval forces on another high-risk mission to the Gulf. There is growing demand for our peacekeeping forces. Why should we, in this case, expect these men and women to face risks to their lives and to their limbs if we, as parliamentarians, were persuaded by the sorts of pressures that have been put upon us by the Repatriation Commission and this Government to take away or at least greatly modify the rights which they have traditionally had?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering a bundle of Bills to do with veterans' affairs and social security matters. I think it is the common desire of those in this chamber that these Bills be concluded by 8 p.m. For that reason, in relation to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) I seek leave to simply comment on it extremely briefly, to rebut any suggestion that it is a cynical Budget exercise, as I think was put by Senator Newman. In fact, it contains extremely worthwhile provisions, such as would allow, for example, the Defence Services Homes Act to be amended to allow loans to repair or renovate existing homes or to discharge existing mortgages. That is certainly in harmony with our overall housing and aged care policy. It is not a cynical matter at all, and I do not think the other matters are, either. I am glad to note that the Senate is going to support them.

PARA.TAB: As to the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1992, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement in relation to the Government's intentions in these matters, rather than read the full text; but I would like to highlight some points in that text, having incorporated the statement. I seek leave to incorporate the statement.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: MINISTERIAL STATEMENT TO INTRODUCE GOVERNMENT AMENDMENTS TO THE VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1992

As the Senate is aware, the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1992 was introduced into the Senate on 12 November 1992 and the Bill was immediately referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the recommendation of the Selection of Bills Committee. The Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee tabled its report on 24 November 1992.

The Committee's recommendations were not unanimous but there was broad consensus that the Bill should be amended. The amendments that have been circulated by the Government are in response to this Committee's report and some further concerns raised by representatives of the ex-service community in meetings with the Repatriation Commission.

During the public hearing before the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee there was some difference of opinion as to the consequences of the Bushell decision for the Repatriation pension system. There was argument that the strictly binding aspect of the High Court's decision had a limited application and that there was no need to amend the VEA.

The Government's difficulty with the Bushell decision stems from the judicial statements made in the reasons for decision. While these statements may or may not be strictly binding on decision makers, the Repatriation Commission, as the primary determining authority, recognises that such judicial statements are given considerable weight in the repatriation claims process.

The Government's concern that the Bushell decision has significantly widened the scope of claims that would be successful was initially based on the opinion of the Solicitor-General, Senior Counsel and the Repatriation Commission. These views received further independent endorsement in the Australian Administrative Law Bulletin's analysis of the Bushell decision which recognised the "likelihood that the decision will lead to an unexpected increase in disability and widow's pension payouts" and indicated that the High Court's interpretation is more generous than that which decision makers previously have generally applied.

The Government has also listened carefully to the points of view expressed by the ex-service representatives at the Committee hearings and in subsequent discussions with the Repatriation Commission. The Repatriation Commission has obtained further legal advice as to how these concerns could be met. That advice reaffirmed the need for legislation to set out more clearly the claims determining process.
I am aware that there is a strongly held view in the ex-service community that there is no need to make any amendments to the legislation following the Bushell case.

It remains the Government's view that the Bushell decision, if unchecked, will, in time, result in increases in costs and inequities. Further the Auditor-General in his recently tabled Audit Report No. 8 stated that the Bushell decision "widened the interpretation of the favourable nature of the `reasonable hypothesis'" and could lead to "the great majority of claims being accepted".

As has been clearly stated by the Government, the purpose of the Amendment Bill is to overturn those aspects of the Bushell decision that were considered to be inconsistent with the position that has prevailed under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 as interpreted in a line of Federal Court decisions commencing with the East case and endorsed by a majority of the Full Bench of the Federal Court in Repatriation Commission v Bushell.

What the Government is concerned about in the Bushell decision is the possibility that what the High Court refers to as "raised facts" should be assumed to be true upon their mere assertion by the claimant. While not accepting this is the interpretation intended by the High Court, such a view, if adopted by a decision maker, is likely to go far beyond the position the Government would regard as being acceptable.

The effect of the amendments that I have circulated place a clear focus on the process to be followed by decision makers in determining claims for pension. The amendments leave untouched the present standard of proof provisions as contained in sub-sections 120(1) and (3) of the VEA.

The process proposed makes it clear that, as a first step, the decision maker needs to establish the circumstances of the veteran's operational service and the facts about the incapacity claimed by a veteran or the death claimed by a widow. Following that fact finding process, the possible link between the veteran's incapacity or death and his operational service needs to be assessed. This is to be done on the basis of whether or not a reasonable hypothesis as to a link is raised following an evaluation of all the available material.

By limiting the amendments to changes to ensure a properly structured process of fact finding and evaluation I believe we have met the essential concerns of the ex-service community with the contents of the Bill as originally introduced. The Government believes that in following the process detailed a decision maker will be able to apply the standard of proof correctly. This should lead to better consistency and therefore a more equitable system of claims determination.

This process will ensure that, if after the evaluation of all the relevant material, any reasonable hypothesis of a connection with war service is raised then the claim for pension will succeed. It will not be a matter of preferring one reasonable hypothesis to another.

In the Bushell case, both the majority judgement and that of Brennan J make it clear that a decision maker can reject material raised by a claimant to support an hypothesis of causation on the basis of unreliability of that material or because of the superior reliability of other parts of the material before the decision maker, or, because the raised facts depend on inferences that the decision maker is satisfied cannot be drawn. The Government believes that this interpretation is consistent with its intentions when the 1986 legislative changes were made.

Bearing in mind that the Repatriation System is an inquisitorial process in which the decision maker is required to obtain and to examine all the relevant evidence and that neither the Repatriation Commission nor the claimant bears any onus of proof as in an adversarial system, most people have little difficulty with the procedures I have outlined. Indeed it is consistent with the conclusion reached by the VEA Monitoring Committee chaired by Mr Justice Toose when it said that, if properly followed, the decision in the East case achieved the Government's stated intention for the 1986 legislation.

Mr Justice Toose has seen the amendments I am now proposing and is satisfied that they do no more than confirm and underline the proper process of decision making to be applied in the Repatriation System.

The amendments now proposed do fall short of achieving all of the Government's original intentions for the Bill. For instance, the issue of "opinion shopping" seeking support for tenuous linkages to war service and the related issue of medical or scientific opinion of limited standing are not specifically dealt with. As I have explained the Government is prepared at this point to rely on the revised procedural process to minimise the risk from these problems.

The original explanatory memorandum to the Bill provided an estimate, based on assumptions of increased claims and success rates and mortality rates, of increased program costs. The amendments now proposed will not eliminate all of the anticipated additional program expenditure. The extent to which the Bill meets its original objectives will, therefore, need to be monitored.

On behalf of the Government, the Repatriation Commission will closely monitor, in consultation with the ex-service community, the impact of these legislative changes on the outcomes of the claims process. If these amendments prove to be insufficient to deal with the practical impact of the Bushell decision, thereby causing a blow out in the taxpayers liability under the Repatriation system, then the Government will reconsider its position.

In conclusion Mr President, I would like to make another brief reference to the Auditor General's Report No. 8. As Senator Newman mentioned here on 2 December the report provides a contemporary analysis of Repatriation legislation and practices. The Government agrees that the report can provide a basis for further review of the Repatriation system and is considering how this process might be pursued. The Minister has asked the Repatriation Commission to meet with the ex-service community to hear their views before taking a decision on this matter.

In the meantime, I reiterate the Government's firm view for the need for legislative action at this time to ensure continued fairness for veterans and taxpayers. In reaching this position, the Government cannot be as confident that it's concerns arising from the Bushell decision have been dealt with comprehensively. Nevertheless it recognises the realities of its position in the Senate. The Government is not prepared to open itself to the charge of fiscal irresponsibility or that it has countenanced inequitable application of the law by not making a serious and practical attempt to clarify the confusion created by the comments made in the High Court case that leave open the suggestion that a claim for Repatriation pension might be determined by a less structured process than that which I have outlined above.
Mr President, I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments that have been circulated by the Government are in response to the Committee meeting that was held several Fridays ago and further concerns raised by the ex-Service community in meetings with the Repatriation Commission. Those were extensive, very frank and forthright meetings, and I believe they did lead to a better understanding on all sides of the concerns of both the veterans and the Government in relation to these matters.

PARA.TAB: Of course, it remains the Government's view that the Bushell decision, if unchecked, will in time result in increases in costs and inequities. Further, the Auditor-General, in his recently tabled Audit Report No. 8, stated that the Bushell decision: `Widened the interpretation of the favourable nature of the reasonable hypothesis'. He went on to say that it could lead to `the great majority of claims being accepted'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with that?

—That is a reason, Senator, for the Government to be concerned. As will be seen from the way in which the amendments have been drafted and the Bill has been extensively modified, the Government is not in a position to give the fullest support to some of the claims that have been made about the effect of the Bushell decision. Nevertheless, I believe we have a very valid and real responsibility not only to the veterans' community but, as they too would understand, to the wider Australian community, to ensure that we get this right. For that reason, we have put forward a set of amendments which clearly focus on the process to be followed by decision-makers in determining claims for pension.

PARA.TAB: The amendments leave untouched the present standard of proof provisions as contained in section 120, subsections (1) and (3), of the VEA. The proposed process makes it clear that as a first step the decision-maker needs to establish the circumstances of the veteran's operational service, and the facts about the incapacity claim by a veteran, or the death claimed by a widow. Following that fact-finding process, the possible link between the veteran's incapacity or death and his occupational service needs to be assessed. This is to be done on the basis of whether or not a reasonable hypothesis as to a link is raised, following an evaluation of all the available material.

This has been a series of amendments now structured simply and modified to deal with the process of fact-finding and evaluation. I believe that thereby the Government has met the essential concerns of the ex-Service community with the contents of the Bill as originally introduced. We believe that this should lead to better consistency and a more equitable system of claims determination. The process will ensure that if, after the evaluation of all the relevant material, any reasonable hypothesis of a connection with war service is raised, then the claim for pension will succeed. It would not be a matter of preferring one reasonable hypothesis to another.

Mr Justice Toose has seen the amendments I am now proposing, and he is satisfied that they do no more than confirm and underline the proper process of decision-making to be applied in the repatriation system—and Mr Justice Toose has assented to those words appearing in this statement.

On behalf of the Government the Repatriation Commission will closely monitor, in consultation with the ex-Service community, the impact of these legislative changes on the outcomes of the claims process. If these amendments prove to be insufficient to deal with the practical impact of the Bushell decision, thereby causing a blow-out in the taxpayers' liability under the repatriation system, then the Government will reconsider its position.

In the meantime, I reiterate the Government's firm view for the need for legislative action at this time to ensure continued fairness for veterans and taxpayers. In reaching this position, the Government cannot be as confident that its concerns arising from the Bushell decision have been dealt with comprehensively. Nevertheless, it recognises the reality of its position. The Government is not prepared to open itself to the charge of fiscal irresponsibility or that it has countenanced inequitable application of the law by not making a serious and practical attempt to clarify the confusion created by the comments made in the High Court case that leave open the suggestion that a claim for repatriation pension might be determined by a less structured process than that which I have outlined above.

I commend the amendments to the Senate. I believe that the Senate should favour this Bill as it would be amended by giving the Bill a second reading at this time. We believe that it ought not be deferred in the way that the Opposition and, I believe, the Democrats are suggesting. As I say, we believe that we have a responsibility to at least set in place a decision-making process that can lead to consistent and equitable decision making in this area. As I emphasise, Justice Toose believes that these amendments that would be moved in the committee stage do no more than confirm and underline the proper process of decision making to be applied in the repatriation system. For that reason, the Government will be opposing the second reading amendment moved by Senator Newman and still wishes to commend the second reading to the chamber.

As for the social security Bills, I believe that if I were simply to reiterate, re-emphasise and underline the second reading speeches that have already been made in this place on behalf of the Government, then I would not be doing anything except, as I say, taking up the time of the chamber. Honourable senators are well aware of the merits of the particular Bills, and I believe that it is best that I deal with one or two matters at the committee stage rather than go further into the reasons why, in principle, these social security Bills should receive the support of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I put the question, I would like to make a short statement. In view of the displeasure expressed when I reminded the Senate of the expiry of an informal time limit, I suggest that in the future these informal arrangements be monitored by those involved rather than the Chair. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Newman in respect of the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1992 be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion, as amended, be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —That Bill is deferred until the first meeting day in February 1993 accordingly. The question now is that the remaining four Bills be read a second time.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992

PARA.TAB: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 77, page 54, line 12, omit "30", substitute "50".
2.Clause 78, page 54, proposed paragraph 524A, paragraph (2)(a), line 27, omit "30", substitute "50".

Amendments Nos. 1 and 2 relate to voluntary work. We argue that while the Government increase is welcome, it is nowhere near sufficient and we wish to increase the number of days to 50. Voluntary work is not about filling in people's time; it is about keeping in touch with the community, maintaining social contact, honing one's skills and keeping them relevant as well as what is actually achieved personally and, indeed, for the community. I must note here that it is not actually included as part of GDP, but there is an enormous amount of work done in our community by the volunteers. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the coalition supports the concept of voluntary work, we will not be supporting these amendments. The reason we will not be supporting them is that they do not facilitate a proper work for benefit program, such as the one that has been outlined by the coalition in Fightback. I would have liked to have expanded on that but, given the time that we have, I will not.
—I believe that the Bill is modest but appropriate in this sphere, and we will not be supporting the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clauses 134 to 136, page 80, lines 2 to 25, clauses to be opposed.

This amendment relates to the shares which will now be deemed to have increased in value as far as pension income is concerned. I wish to just remind the Government that this is extremely short sighted and penny-pinching. I do not know whether the Government is aware, but what is most likely to happen is that pensioners will divest themselves of their shareholdings. This will not affect large shareholdings; those people are already out under the assets and income test. This will only affect those pensioners with relatively small volumes of shares, and they do not know whether, indeed, they will increase in value from year to year. It seems, from those who have contacted us, that what is most likely is that they will decide to move their money out of shares. At a time when companies such as Arnotts are under threat from takeover—and we have heard a lot in this place about concerns for that—nothing practical is being done to encourage people to keep their shares in Australian companies. I therefore recommend that we delete these clauses and leave the status quo as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be supporting this amendment. I wish to take the time of the Senate to just review and reiterate what I said in the second reading debate. We will be reviewing these proposals when in government. We are concerned with the mechanics of this hastily conceived proposal. In particular, we are concerned about the proposed formula to be used for assessing unrealised capital gains and losses under the incomes test; we are concerned that the current formula may not treat gains and losses equitably; and we are concerned that the current formula may maximise unrealised gains but minimise unrealised losses. Obviously, an examination of the formula will be a central element of our review of this initiative when we are in government.
—We will be reviewing the matter to make sure at least that it operates equitably, but we adhere to the original proposal.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clauses 137 to 140, page 80, line 27 (page 80) to line 27 (page 81), clauses to be opposed.

My final amendment relates to allocated pensions. Obviously, we will eventually end up supporting the Liberal Party because at least it is moving some way along the right track. But I argue very strongly that we simply should throw out this measure altogether. We should treat all types of superannuation equitably. I think this is, again, a very short-sighted measure on behalf of the Government. What it is basically doing here is discouraging people from investing in funds that, in fact, do what the Government wants people to do—that is, instead of encouraging people to take out lump sums they encourage them spread their income into the future so that they are able to look after themselves and not rely on Government pensions. It is a very short-sighted measure, and I recommend this amendment to delete it to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting this amendment because we have an alternative method of dealing with this which Senator Lees has foreshadowed that the Australian Democrats will be supporting. That is sufficient for me to say at the moment.

"(g)an allocated pension or allocated annuity";
(ab)by inserting at the end of paragraph (1C)(f) the following words "that is not an allocated annuity"
(ac)by inserting at the end of paragraph (1C)(g) the following words "that is not an allocated pension".

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Clause 138, page 81, lines 2 to 16, omit the clause.

As honourable senators will recall, these amendments relate to the Government's decision to treat both unrealised capital gains and income applying to the assets underlying allocated pensions as earned income for the age pension means test and to include the capital value of allocated pensions in the assets test. As I said before, the coalition is disturbed that the Government has acted hastily in introducing a measure that will do nothing to promote an effective, flexible and equitable retirement incomes policy.

PARA.TAB: As my coalition colleagues Senator Watson and Senator Alston have said in their dissenting report to report No. 4 of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation entitled Super—Fiscal and Social Links, there is a real need in Australia for an incomes policy that encourages retirees to use their superannuation benefits to produce a steady retirement income; discourages retirees from dissipating lump sum pay-outs and then relying on a government pension; recognises that conventional lifetime annuities are inflexible, relatively low yielding and do not have a residual value to be passed on and are, therefore, an unattractive option to many retirees; and encourages and promotes the use of allocated pensions, which is vital to prevent double dipping in the retirement area.

Although allocated pensions received the Government's endorsement in its security in retirement policy statement last June, the proposed amendments will do nothing to advance their use. As Senators Alston and Watson have stated in their dissenting report:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amendments to the Social Security legislation, by denying allocated pensions the same treatment as already given to annuities in the income and assets tests, are likely to fly in the face of the (government's) stated policy of encouraging allocated pensions.

It is simply hypocritical for the Government to state now that allocated pensions should be afforded less favourable treatment. Accordingly, the coalition deplores the Government's failure to develop a consistent and equitable retirement incomes policy. On this basis, it is proposing that these provisions should not take effect until the completion of a further inquiry by an appropriate Senate committee or on 1 October 1993, whichever is the latter. Our amendments are designed to achieve that end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Without going into the substantive arguments in this matter, it is important to point out to Senator Lees, for example, that, as I understand it, the new treatment of allocated pensions and annuities was announced on 1 July 1992. The market has shown significant growth since then, so I do not think her fears are well grounded. But what I do fear is that the uncertainty that will be created over the next nine months at least—perhaps longer, if a Senate committee is reporting—will create more turmoil than if this measure were passed into law and one could see exactly how it was going to operate.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that, if one reads Senator Patterson's amendments and tries to envisage what would happen if there were an adverse Senate committee report—according to her amendments, the Bill would then become effective and the provision would come into effect—one could see that this would create a tremendous amount of uncertainty and difficulty. Basically, it is putting off the matter in the hope that the Opposition may come into government and deal with the matter. It is a little opposite to what was happening last night with the Medicare Agreements Bill, so I suppose that Senator Patterson has had her revenge in that respect. The Government will be opposing these amendments because of the uncertainty this would create in this market, which we still think is an important one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am conscious of the hours that the Senate has been sitting. I will be very brief and speak for a only few minutes. I rise to speak on a matter of grave concern affecting South Australia's farming community, particularly grain growers.

PARA.TAB: South Australian Farmers Federation President, Mr Tim Scholz, spoke on South Australian regional radio today about the disaster facing many farmers because of the continuing unseasonal weather which has seen returns for the grain harvest in South Australia decimated in many areas.

The effect of drought and its associated hardships are well publicised and documented, but at least in a period of drought primary producers have the opportunity to prepare themselves and, to some degree, manage their ongoing costs and outlays.

South Australian farmers today have been through a period of record winter and spring rainfall and so most areas were expecting above average to record yields from both grain and legumes. They outlaid extra finance for sprays not normally needed for weed control and crop diseases. Many farmers also purchased new machinery and equipment to cope with a bumper harvest.

But the unprecedented and extreme wet weather has seen their optimism turn to disaster. The continuing wet weather—far in excess of what could be expected—has delayed harvesting, resulting in shot grain and impossible harvesting conditions. Wheat delivered by farmers with more than one per cent of the grain shot has been downgraded from milling grade to stock feed grade.

Most of the wheat harvest on the Eyre Peninsula and other areas normally falls into two categories, Australian standard white or hard, which this year are worth $154 and $168 a tonne respectively. But feed grain put in the general pool is now worth only $135 a tonne. This means the return to growers in some cases can be below the cost of production.

Mr David Lewis, an agronomist with the Department of Primary Industries in Cleve, has had reports from silo staff on Eyre Peninsula that up to 99 per cent of grain receivals are being downgraded. Some wheat has been completely rejected at the silo delivery point and has to be taken back to the property having no current commercial value.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is devastating to the people.

—Yes, it is devastating. The estimated loss to individual farmers on Eyre Peninsula because of this weather damage is in excess of $40,000 per farmer. This comes at a time when ABARE is predicting the average Australian broadacre farmer will lose $25,700 this financial year.

PARA.TAB: Today Mr Scholz estimated the total direct cash loss to grain growers on Eyre Peninsula alone to be $70m. This does not take into account the losses from districts where the grain harvest has scarcely commenced due to the continuing wet weather. The multiplier effect on the State's economy is three to four times. Therefore, we are looking at a disaster of devastating proportions.

The effect on the viability of farmers who have been struggling to survive and whose confidence had been boosted by good rainfall is that they will be placed in an even more precarious position. In addition to the wheat harvest, most of the State's barley crop has been downgraded and the Australian Barley Board says the continual rain has affected malting quality in barley deliveries.

Legume crops have been either wiped out or are at least returning much lower yields. Faba beans and peas are not worth harvesting in many cases and vetch has been affected by rust and other diseases. Farmers on northern Eyre Peninsula and the northern Mallee have been badly affected by a series of crop diseases, including haydie and stem, stripe and leaf rust.

Dr Alan Dube, head of the Department of Primary Industries plant pathology unit, says that haydie—a fungus that thrives in wet conditions—is threatening to wipe $60m worth of grain off the State's cereal crops this year. The weather has also put at risk the grape harvest and the fruit and vegetable harvests.

In 1987, during an extremely difficult period for farmers across the State, the South Australian Farmers Federation conducted a two-day phone-in for farmers. The survey confirmed that farm families were suffering from significant psychological and physical problems as a result of the stress they were under.

Today Mr Scholz said that recent anecdotal evidence suggests that stress levels amongst members of the farming community are likely to be extremely high again as a result of the virtual collapse of prospects because of the unseasonably wet conditions. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: In many respects, this year will be much worse than a drought year . . .
He said that farmers:

. . . have been looking forward to one of the best years in many to help reduce their debt levels and claw their way back to profitability. Their hopes have been dashed and the effects of the disappointment will be enormous.

I understand that the South Australian Farmers Federation is meeting with the Premier and his Primary Industries Minister shortly and I urge the State and Federal governments to consider and respond to any calls for assistance from rural South Australians in the face of this disaster over which they have no control.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not sit by and not support Senator Ferguson's remarks about the devastation to some people in the farming community at the moment because of the heavy rains at a time when the crops are ready to harvest. The same thing is happening in the north of New South Wales; there are a lot of unharvested crops. It is very good for this chamber to occasionally listen to what actually happens to people out in the wider community, especially to the farmers who make such a contribution to all our export income and all our standards of living.

PARA.TAB: Basically, the value of their contribution to our economy is sometimes not realised by the rest of the community. Occasionally we have to think of the people who are suffering hardships out on the farms. For example, Eyre Peninsula had devastating droughts not so long ago and now the crops, which were ready to be harvested, have been devastated by rain.

I know that people could say that that is something that the farming community has to put up with. We do not want people to shed too many tears for the farming community, but we would like the rest of the community to have an understanding of what is going on out there at the moment.

The Government said that it would require primary industry to produce good crops and plenty of export income to help all of Australia out of its problems. I commend to the Senate what Senator Ferguson said, but add that the same problem is happening in the northern part of New South Wales at the moment. I feel very sorry for the farmers there who are having the same problems as are being experienced in South Australia.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 17 June 1992:

PARA.TAB: Considering that the Imputation Credit Scheme does not offer benefits to people whose income does not reach the tax free threshold, is the Government considering altering the scheme to benefit low income earners; if so, what changes are being considered; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (2) not applicable; and

(3) the imputation credit scheme was designed to replace the classical system of company taxation which taxed the profits of the company then taxed the dividends received by the shareholder through the provision of imputation credits. Under this system the profits were taxed twice. With the current arrangements the tax paid on profits is taken into account when the dividends are paid to the shareholder. This is of substantial benefit to most shareholders. Where the taxpayer cannot utilise the excess credits the credit is lost. This situation not only applies to low income shareholders but also tax exempt investors such as State Government authorities and some other shareholders who may be taxable but cannot use all their credits. That the Government has not fully integrated company tax with personal tax so that shareholders who could not use credits get refunds is a deliberate decision reflecting various policy trade-offs, including cost to revenue, in designing the imputation system.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 November 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the draft Superannuation Guarantee Ruling SGR 92/D1 which contains a definition of `ordinary time earnings':

(1) When an employee's employment is terminated and the employee is paid out for long service leave, annual leave, sick leave and `ordinary time earnings', what is the relevant earnings base for superannuation guarantee purposes.

(2) Should the employer make superannuation contributions for that employee in respect of the payment for accrued entitlements (long service leave, annual leave and sick leave) or pay the superannuation guarantee charge.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 requires employers to make a minimum level of superannuation contributions for each employee. This minimum level is calculated as a percentage of each employee's earnings base.
The employee's earnings base will be whichever is appropriate of:

an earnings base defined in the formal documents which administer a superannuation scheme (such as the trust deed). This base may be only used if the employer was contributing in accordance with it before 21 August 1991 or if it is at least as large as the employee's ordinary time earnings, as defined in the Act.
an earnings base provided for in an industrial award.

the earnings base provided for in an occupational superannuation agreement so long as the employer was contributing in accordance with it before 21 August 1991 or if it is at least as large as the employee's ordinary time earnings, as defined in the Act.

if no other acceptable base exists, the default earnings base will be the employee's ordinary time earnings, as defined in the Act. I am advised that, in the opinion of the Commissioner of Taxation, payments for long service leave, annual leave and sick leave are comprehended by the expression `ordinary time earnings'.
(2) Subject to other legal obligations, the employer may choose whether to make superannuation contributions for an employee or to pay the superannuation guarantee charge.

If employers choose to make contributions for their employees, the level of support will be calculated on the appropriate earnings base. The actual base used will determine whether the accrued entitlements mentioned are taken into account.

If they choose to pay the charge, the shortfall calculation is based on salary or wages, which will include payments for accrued entitlements, such as long service leave, annual leave and sick leave. It should be noted that payment of the charge is not tax deductible unlike most superannuation contributions.
